pros: Fantastic people, strong company growth, transparent leadership team,  and amazing culture
cons: A lot of folks in leadership positions joined HubSpot 5-7 years ago.  This just makes me wish I had joined sooner!

headline: Love working at HubSpot
pros:
Job Autonomy
Excellent Culture
Outstanding Co-Workers

I am always excited to come into work- I love the people I work with and feel like I am learning something new every single day.
cons: All-in-all not much to call out here. I think we need to train mid-level leadership better. But I know this is already on leaderships radar, so I am excited about the future!

headline: Unfulfilled promises
pros:
-unlimited PTO
-the people are the number one perk
-dog friendly office
-extroverted atmosphere, you can walk up to anyone and ask a for directions
cons: Specifically in the support org, there is a disparity between what is promised upon hiring (e.g. most people leave after 1 year and find another internal position, there's a pay raise every six months until capping at L3, you can use your off phone hour to pursue other projects). While it is possible to find a job internally, support reps aren't taken seriously in most other parts of the company, and have to re-start at a different entry level position after knowing the technical side of the project inside and out. HubSpot pays far below industry standard in all roles, and internal reps are frequently lowballed when being promoted. The atmosphere and goals have become more authoritarian and less encouraging and certainly more rigid and have a misaligned ideal of what it takes to actually leave support, which is widely recognized as the only reason for joining support in the first place≥

headline: The flexibility and autonomy is fabulous!
pros:
-Very transparent workplace, a lot of faith in management around the company
-Great culture for a flexible work schedule
cons: -Growing pains as they scale, a lot of big questions to be answered (but also makes the work interesting)

headline: Don't count this company out
pros:
Remote Workforce - and not the remote workforce where you feel forgotten about at home. There are some MAJOR initiatives that this company does to make remote workers feel included. Managers have the tools they need to know how to lead a remote sales team and you feel that everyday

Training - The training at Hubspot as a new employee is amazing. They really want to make sure you know the products, inbound methodology, and the company inside and out. 

Clear promotion metrics - all of this is company wide and transparent so there is no guessing games on how to get promoted
cons: I work remote so I can enjoy their beautiful office in Cambridge!!

headline: Good place to start in sales
pros: Great place to start in sales, you will work with and learn from the best
cons: Much lower pay than the rest of the market - a hyper competitive environment. You really have to drink the kool aid as well.

headline: Couldn't be happier!
pros: HubSpot is truly transparent - I never feel like I am surrounded by closed-door meetings. I feel like I know as much information as everyone around me and that we value and enable this transparency so that we can do our job better. This brings me to my second point that we believe there is always more to learn and encourage people at all levels within the organization to continue to learn and grow. I've not seen that modeled to such an extent with other employers. The organization is fairly flat, which gives folks a lot of autonomy and leverage to bring great ideas to the table and it helps us to better elevate the voice of the customer and truly be understanding our customers' needs by hearing from them directly as well as hearing valued feedback from employees who are customer-facing.
cons: I have left this blank for the last 10 minutes while I am trying to think of something... I don't have many cons, if any. I think there are learning curves along the way as any company grows quickly, but even that has been positive since HubSpot realizes its areas that it needs to improve (increasing diversity, for an example) and has proactively worked towards getting better with this.

headline: Work Where You Work Best
pros: HubSpot's flexible work policy and unlimited vacation are unrivaled. I feel lucky to work at a company with such a strong testament to allowing employees to work in the way they work best.  It's also allowed me to follow my passions in life, like travel, and fit my work around my life instead of the other way around. That's not to say there aren't days where I work a little longer or projects that take up more time, but it all balances out and I'm thankful for
cons: As HubSpot grows, naturally there are some growing pains that are going to happen. I think that leaders are really going to have to dig in to  our culture and make sure we're continuing to scale that as HubSpot grows, both within the larger company, but even on smaller departments and teams. We work with amazing people, and we can't fall away from celebrating people or building relationships as HubSpot continues to grow.

headline: An incredible place to work!
pros:
I could list a lot of pros - the benefits, the technology, the mission, the transparency - but two things stand out:

The flexibility: As employees, we work hard to meet high expectations, but we're also encouraged to leverage flexibility to accommodate a work/life balance.  As long as the work gets done, they trust you to work where and when you need to work, which has been so impactful on my work and life and will keep me loyal to the company for years to come. The company also allows remote work, which is an incredible option for those of us who prefer to work from home, are not located close to an office, or may be looking to make a physical move in the future for various reasons.

The community: The company is full of empathetic, helpful, and energizing people, which makes it a really great place to work and learn. From the very top level to individual contributors, I've always felt welcome and comfortable reaching out, collaborating, and asking for help when needed. This type of environment also fosters opportunities to branch out of your own role and explore other functions and possibilities, which has been really helpful to my career growth.

In the three years I've been at HubSpot, I've been able to transition my career into a new space,  pursue a graduate degree thanks to the flexibility in HubSpot's schedule (and their tuition reimbursement!), and grow both personally and professionally in so many ways. It's been the best career move I've made so far and I couldn't be happier.
cons: This isn't  a con, but more setting context - HubSpot is what you make of it. There is so much opportunity, trust, and growth available to every employee, but learning to navigate and take advantage of all of that can be overwhelming at first, so it can take time to find your footing.

headline: Looking to grow with a company? Looking to have a positive impact on others? Look no further than HubSpot!
pros:
It's rare to find a company that has strong values and actually operated to uphold them. Beyond the snacks, coffee garden, flexible work policies, unlimited vacation, career growth opportunities, innovative ideas, and supporting a properly integrated work-life, HubSpot as a tool actually works to help small and medium businesses grow. 

It is rewarding to know that we are enabling individuals to have a better workday, bigger pay check, and aspirational goals through our platform and services. In return, employees are rewarded with a truly remarkable culture and work experience. 

Speaking directly to leaders looking to join HubSpot - come to HubSpot if you want to lead with your authentic style, develop employees for career success not just task success, and have some fun at work.
cons: HubSpot is a place where people are committed. If you are looking to work 37 hours a week, this isn't for you. If you are looking to work slowly, this isn't for you.

headline: I would not recommend hubspot to a friend or colleague.
pros:
Benefits are super
Great office and facility 
Talented employees
cons:
Poor management 
Lack of communication
So much money spent on merch - could be better utilised
Hustle culture - very rarely do people take their full lunch.
Pressure to attend after work events
A lot of unhealthy food always around
Alienating language used constantly

headline: Was great until a manager ruined it
pros: Great coworkers, good product, great location
cons: Facade of transparency, pretending to care, unrealistic expectations

headline: Yay
pros: Great company  to work for
cons: None really. Great people all arohnd

headline: Bigger than a startup - smaller than a corporate company (just right)
pros:
-HubSpot culture is unlike any other I have experienced. Your coworkers are genuinely invested in your success and will extend themselves to ensure you have access to the resources you need.
-Unlimited PTO and work from home flexibility, dog friendly office, smoothie bar + coffee garden + beer gardens, 24/7 building access (great for a weekend workout at the onsite gym), onsite dental and vision, dry cleaning pickup/drop off and no dress code
-HubSpot has an incredible suite of products that are easy to stand behind and have tremendous value to the end user. Great product = easy sell = happy customer
cons:
-No one works at HubSpot because it pays better than the rest of the industry (it doesn't) but you do stay because you become accustomed to the HubSpot lifestyle. If financial compensation is your key motivator then make sure you are clear with your salary expectations when interviewing.
-If you are fresh out of University and looking for an entry level role you will have to pay your dues. The movement through the ranks is again, a bit slower than what you would see at other businesses in this industry, but ultimately a great learning experience and intrinsically more valuable.

headline: Great company
pros: Awesome culture and great learning opportunities
cons: Some roles have do not pay well

headline: Great culture in this company
pros: Great benefits, super managing culture, interesting job
cons: Team spirit can be overrated as there ca be competition between teammates

headline: Great Place to Work!
pros: Senior leadership and management is transparent and actions on feedback. Get to work with high performing teams and talented co-workers. The company's mission is to help millions of organizations grow better, but at the same time, the company is also actively helping its employees to grow better.
cons: Things evolve and change at a rapid pace, as expected of a growing SaaS company, so there is a need to constantly stay on the edge and keep up with the latest information.

headline: Principal Account Executive
pros: Best corporate culture and management in the software sales game (not to mention best in class product... easiest thing to sell). Fact! Dogs, too!
cons: None - absolutely none of you care about your job and understand this grass is VERY GREEN.

headline: Very good place to work
pros:
Good management 
Good life work balance
Lunch alla days
cons: No cons it was a good place where to work

headline: A great overall culture hampered by bad middle management
pros:
- Unlimited vacation is truly unlimited - no tracking system, no red tape, no snide comments from coworkers or management (at least in my experience)

- In spite of recent code red mishaps, I think the software is heading in the right direction. I can't speak to the overall strategy, but for the most part, as both an internal and external user, there's been continuous improvement in functionality, and the UI and general ease of use is considerably better than garbage like Marketo and Pardot

- There are enough people at this point that you'll definitely find like-minded colleagues. People are generally smart and capable (though there's definitely a Dunning-Kruger effect and HubSpot's internal insistence on its meaningless stat that they're harder to "get into" than Harvard certainly doesn't help things), and I've connected with some truly incredible friends and colleagues here
cons:
Two main cons, neither an easy fix:


1. The "Peter principle". Upward trajectory at HubSpot relies heavily on an eventual promotion to middle management. This is seen as "prestigious" or a sign of talent, but the fact of the matter is that across departments, the responsibilities of managers are vastly different from those of individual contributors. Although not universally true, wayyyy too many people get promoted to a management position based on their excellence in their current role, with little regard for whether those skills will translate to middle management (hint: they often do not). HubSpot's only alternative to rewarding excellence besides the management track is pay raises and more senior titles. 


This isn't all that different from how many other companies operate, but it doesn't absolve HubSpot of its poor managerial culture. As the saying goes, "People don't leave their jobs, they leave their managers", and far too many strong contributors are put into managerial roles where they're at best ineffectual and at worst, an active hindrance to employee performance. There's a strong sense that managers view their status at the company as an elevated one, where it should be the reverse: middle managers are there to enable their employees to give their best performance, not to flex their tenure. Ironically, because of this culture, I've seen the converse scenario as well: middle managers stuck in middle management because it's the "mature" thing to do, despite being talented and smart enough to be a better fit as senior members of their team.


2. Diversity and inclusion. There's been a strong push at HubSpot lately to be better about diversity and inclusion, which is great to see. The problem is that most of the top-down directives are coming from a place where the top is neither very diverse nor inclusive. 


About a year ago and a half ago, I personally saw a new POC hire go through the new hire training, and then be let go almost immediately. Apparently, his manager didn't feel that his output was very HubSpotty. I bring this story up because I think it highlights how much work HubSpot still has to do.


There's countless research out there highlighting that no matter how much raw intelligence or talent someone from a low-income or low-privileged background possesses, there's going to be a (usually pretty rough) transition period when they move into a more demanding environment. It's not laziness or lack of fit - it's the natural outcome of trying to adapt to completely new environments, environments which are often very familiar to those who were privileged enough to get tutoring, go to schools with AP classes, attend top tier colleges, etc. I'm not suggesting that it's HubSpot's responsibility to fix systemic inequality. I am suggesting that the company should be more patient with those they hire from, to put it bluntly, less "Martha's Vineyard" backgrounds. The fact that you would hire someone, put them through a month-long training (in which they've presumably turned down any and all other offers of employment), and then fire them right afterward is... not great. I chalk this one up to the individual manager's inability to empathize or just a general lack of D-I training and awareness, but it's a particularly insidious component to the systemic exclusion at the heart of tech that I don't think is talked about enough.

headline: Growth and opportunity through hard work
pros:
HubSpot is the best place I've ever worked, before thoughts drift toward this sounding fluffy, hear me out: 
-HubSpot offers flexibility unlike like I've ever had at past employers. Being a working parent this is one of the several difference makers in my day to day. If I need to leave early or come in late, no one ever questions it. This comes from setting a standard of trust within all HubSpot employees. It's expected that you dedicate your self to working hard and when you need to handle life as we all do, there are no issues at all. During my time here, yes there have been growing pains as there are in any scaling business, that said with incredible growth that I've seen and participated in you do reap rewards from the collective success. 
-HubSpot does a great job hiring smart, driven people. When you are surrounded by that mindset, you too will have a strong desire to success each and every day.
cons: There is a great deal of change that happens constantly, this has produced great results over time but if new processes and products aren't in your wheelhouse HubSpot likely won't be a fit.

headline: A good place for individuals with initiative
pros: Flexibility, autonomy, intrinsically motivated coworkers
cons: Growing pains, over correction, lots of inexperience

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great culture. Everyone there wants you to succeed
cons: A lot of work, none besides that

headline: Great place to learn
pros:
Awesome engineers to learn from
Interesting technical problems
Fun environment to work in
cons: Product isn't super appealing to everyone

headline: Great Perks, but a Culture that Isn't Scaling
pros: It's not hard to get on board with HubSpot's Culture Code (an adaptation of Patty McCord's work at Netflix) and it's "only policy" of "Use Good Judgment." Free snacks, a large open office campus plan with plenty of common spaces, smoothie bar, gym, unlimited vacation, etc. The people are generally pretty smart, talented, and hardworking. The intentions are always good, and this is particularly clear when it comes to their diversity and inclusion efforts. As an individual contributor at the company, I very much enjoy working with my peers. It feels like we're "all in this together." Great health benefits--HubSpot will pay your deductible--and there's a lot of support for parents and caregivers.
cons: HubSpot is finding it increasingly difficult to scale its culture across 9 global offices, and as a result, culture is especially struggling at "home" in Cambridge. As the manager corps expands, there isn't enough training or support available to first-time managers. As a result, the company is seeing a lot of turnover--including folks who've stuck around for 4+ years but didn't find it worth it to make it to 5 to get the company's 1-month sabbatical. Things are particularly tough when it comes to folks working in entry level positions such as customer support. Low pay combined with none of the flexibility the company touts so much means a lot of dissatisfaction among that group.

headline: Autonomy and growth
pros:
- Great deal of autonomy as an individual contributor or manager to work on high impact projects
- Great focus on career growth, and plenty of opportunities to grow as the company does
cons: No major complaints. Things can feel a bit chaotic at times due to the growth of the company and change within the actual product, but the change is almost always for the better and things feel like they constantly improve.

headline: Continuously improving
pros:
HubSpot never rests on its laurels and every department is committed to getting better every day.  

You are given a lot of autonomy which is supported by radical transparency in the business.  This allows you to have all the context needed to make the best decisions to solve for the customer.  There are guidelines and playbooks, of course, but you have a lot of discretion in your day-to-day activities.  

In my group, Customer Success Management, we have a great team and the privilege of serving some remarkable customers.  It's amazing to see the impact we have on our customers' success, their lives, and their careers.
cons: As with many scale-ups, we have some high class challenges:  customer counts, a platform that continues to get both wider and deeper, internal systems keeping pace with business growth.  You have to approach this role with a bit of patience and realizing that you will need to be the change and innovation needed to take this role to the next level.

headline: Working for HubSpot for 6 years and still love it
pros: The best sales environment I’ve ever worked in. It’s competitive, rewarding and with good support.
cons: The product changes quickly so you have to be ready to adapt.

headline: Product Manager
pros: excellent benefits, open to ideas, great attitude
cons: not a lot of process and  priorities change all the time

headline: HubSpot doesn’t care about its service org
pros: The unlimited vacation and office perks like the barista are nice. My coworkers were smart and hardworking. Cross-collaboration - although strained from growing pains - is still achievable with the right channels.
cons:
HubSpot’s Customer Success org is struggling. They’ve had high burnout in this role due to larger than average customer ratios (think 1:200+ in a bad quarter) and impossible targets. You can only offer a certain level of service at those ratios, which makes it impossible to hit target. This leads to high turnover rates, which causes even higher ratios.

Instead of solving the problem, managers blame it on Customer Success Managers not working hard enough and don’t take the concerns of over half of the org seriously, which leads to higher burnout and higher turnover. You see where I’m going with this. Customers can feel the stress in this org, too. 

HubSpot’s a good name to have on your brand, but if you need a job only stay for a year and then move on. The “Best Place to Work” award doesn’t apply to the Customer Success role. There’s a reason why there’s always a “Customer Success Manager” position open, and it’s not because they’re growing in this space (they’re actually trying to cut down on overall headcount in services).

Did I mention lower than average industry pay, too?

headline: Great work environment
pros: Company culture is fun and they really know how to make employees happy.
cons: Super fast paced, which can be intimidating for some people at the start, but if you’re cool with that, you can do just fine!

cons: honestly, cannot complain at all

headline: Bittersweet

* Really dynamic work environment

headline: What an amazing place to work
pros: Great team of smart people around you all fighting for the same mission. The product is ever changing and growing for the better. The culture is awesome and there is a great amount of flexibility - especially when you are doing well!
cons: It’s a tough role, but you are given the resources and tools needed to be successful.

headline: World's apart
pros:
Culture, product, vision, people, autonomy, career progression.. list goes on.
Incredible opportunity to work for a business who's leadership is hyper focussed on the company mission, values and employee happiness.
cons: Sometimes moves so fast with internal decisions that we're left wondering, but has always worked out after a bump or two.

headline: Great place to work
pros: People, product, culture, and opportunity to grow
cons: None that I can think of

headline: engineer

headline: Loved working at HubSpot
pros: HubSpot is an amazing company. I would highly recommend a career in sales at HubSpot. If you are looking for your next role and want to be part of a high growth company selling multiple product lines I would recommend working here in an instant.
cons: I have nothing bad to say about HubSpot at all. Honestly.

headline: Still a great company to work for after nearly 3 years
pros:
- Excellent salary & benefits in Dublin for Engineering
- Unlimited  holiday policy is not just lip service - you can take time off whenever you want in Engineering anyway
- Working hours are really flexible
- Promoted when you deserve it
- Great opportunities for self development
- Fast moving company, growing quickly
cons:
- It's quite enjoyable to work in HubSpot, so make sure you manager your time well and your work life balance
- This is the vast minority but because some of the staff are so well looked after, you see some departments have issues with a sense of entitlement/ego's.

headline: Bittersweet
pros: The flexibility and ability to work from home is great. The office space is comfortable and accommodating.
cons: You don’t always feel valued by management, compensation is on the lower end of the spectrum.

headline: Great sales culture, clutching to "startup" mode
pros: Great product, benefits, leadership, , and coworkers
cons: Growth trajectory limited by luck and internal politics

headline: ups and downs but overall good
pros: Smart team, with lots of great leaders in management
cons: Not a good environment for someone who wants to treat a job as a 9-5, not one big happy family

headline: HubSpot is a remarkable place to work!
pros: HubSpot is an incredible place to work. They encourage a healthy work - life balance, provide remarkable resources such as perks and benefits related to physical and mental health, family, personal and professional support, employee resource groups, and so much more. The best part about HubSpot is the people - you are constantly surrounded by brilliant and caring colleagues who are passionate about their work and solving for their customers.
cons: HubSpot is constantly evolving and growing to solve better for our customers - our processes can take some time to perfect.

headline: Eye opening, and truly amazing
pros:
So many. HubSpot as a company is well planned, growing like crazy, and making an awesome impact on the industry. It's also a great place to work! Good perks, unlimited leave being a big one, and a strong culture that makes working there fun. Training was a highlight for me, given I was in an entry level role.

There's a great vibe at HubSpot, and whilst I'm leaving, I would happily come back one day :)
cons: Not all offices are created equal - whilst the company is amazing, it's best to research the kinds of roles available within each office to ensure that there are opportunities you might want to pursue. For example, the Sydney office is amazing; but it doesn't do engineering, or product - so if that's a goal, you might want to consider your options.

headline: Amazing company
pros: Fast growing company, lot of learning, great people!
cons: None! I really loved my time there!

headline: Great company that enables its employees to get things done
pros: The transparent culture allows collaboration and engagement from all levels
cons: If you are looking to be complacent this might not be the place for you. Continued improvement is encouraged and the pace of work comes at you fast.

headline: Great place to work
pros: culture, senior management, work-life and pay are all great
cons: fast growing - probably not for everyone

headline: Solid technical stack. Unparalleled culture
pros:
- Insane focus on culture, in the best way possible
- Standard front end tech stack with huge focus on internal tooling
- Small autonomous teams yet lots of cross team collaboration and core internal teams that allow for sharing of key functionality
- Great compensation and focus on career growth
- Amazing leadership that actually cares
- Cool product with lots of opportunities for career making projects
- Chance to travel abroad for work
cons:
- Weak 401k match
- May sometimes be placed in isolated buildings away from the rest of the department

headline: Killing off the channel
pros: Flexibility, and a lot of financial upside for sales reps.
cons: Hubspot probably doesn't want to pay commission to its partners, so since 2017 I've seen Hubspot put higher restrictions on the channel. It's sad. I would say, HubSpot is a great place to work, but don't apply to be part of the channel team as it is my opinion that Hubspot doesn't want us there.

headline: Great place to work overall
pros: Free food, great culture in most teams, great people
cons: Pay raises and promotions are often related to time spent in the company, not employees performance.

headline: Good experience
pros: leader on the digital market
cons: stress to reach required targets

headline: Growing better
pros:
When you join a business and go through your training/ onboarding regularly you are fed the cliches around how great the company is. HubSpot is genuinely an environment full of heart, passionate and bright humans and a vision that is so inspiring. Transparency and customer centricity are truly at the center of everything the business does. 
No day is ever the same, change is the norm and even within this fast-paced environment, all Hubspotters are along for the ride. 
Its a place to join if you want to work hard, succeed and be fairly recognized and rewarded.
cons: We have so many acronyms, and for anyone new, there's a lot to take in. We are provided thorough, in-depth training which helps navigate any ambiguity around this.

headline: It's a Complicated Feeling
pros:
The training I was given at HubSpot was nothing short of excellent. I learned a huge amount of technical knowledge, which was definitely a huge investment.

The snack kitchen, free beer, dog-friendly office space, and technical aptitude of the office was really enjoyable.
cons:
Support definitely feels like a cog. You're expected to know more about the whole suite of software than 90% of the company, it changes all the time, you are at work 9 hours a day with an unpaid lunch break, you will inevitably work weekend shifts (though not often), and also work 11-8 shifts, especially when starting out. 

The salary is not great for support. They recently improved it, but it's still not competitive. 
It was really hard to move out of support. The job is presented as a catalyst for growth and moving into other branches of the company. And this was true for some, but it interviewed for no fewer than 5 internal jobs and was not given actionable feedback.

I had two really poor experiences with managers. When I was there 80% of managers where first-time managers, and I never really felt supported by either one. I was giving mixed messages about my performance. My numbers were always good, but it was always implied that I wasn't working hard enough.

These cons added up to a hard to digest lifestyle and poor self-esteem. My manager even suggested I should leave the company because I wasn't happy, instead of asking how she could help. She is a very celebrated manager now. It makes me uncomfortable.

headline: Best Job Ever!
pros: Work anywhere. The people are amazing. The leadership is the best I have seen, with Brian Halligan leading the charge. He is an amazing leader and inspires his direct reports to be amazing alongside him. The dedication we show to clients for satisfaction is second to none and I am glad to be a part of it.
cons: I can't think of a single one.

headline: I love HubSpot
pros: I've been working at HubSpot for many years and have seen the company grow and change. The core principles haven't changed though: ultimate transparency, trusting employees to use good judgment to do their jobs,  and being innovative. These days, working with smart people and having the flexibility to do your job as you wish in a fun environment is worth everything.
cons: This is not  a 9-5 job that you can leave behind when you go home. Also, certain career paths leave less room for growth within the company as the skills don't translate as well to other departments without taking a huge pay cut and starting over (I suppose that's the case no matter where you work).

headline: A happy place with happy people
pros:
- Great work-life balance, no pressure if you feel like taking a day off or working from home
- Very nice atmosphere around the office, there's everything you need from drinks, facilities & food/snacks
- Open door culture, you can always talk to somebody when you need to
- People are happy and don't complain about work like in many other companies, surely there are faults here and there as in any company but it's not something you come across every day. 
- You can be open and honest even to management without having fear of negative consequences.
- Overall it feels good around here, it's busy and can be hectic from time to time, but it's enjoyable rather than annoying.
cons: It can sometimes take a bit longer to progress in the company, mainly because it's so busy so days fly by, but moving to a different role or department isn't the quickest progression at Hubspot, which might actually be a good thing some times.

headline: Flexibility, Cooperation & Trust
pros:
Some people may rave about the free food/snacks, the gym, the beanbags, the beer taps, the cool events and talks...  and that stuff is all pretty amazing. But for me, the real perk at HubSpot is the flexibility to work when and where I need to (within reason) to get the job done. And the fact that I'm trusted to do my job. There's no micromanagement and you end up wanting to work better as a result.

When I was pregnant, and as a parent now, this flexibility is everything to me. Being able to pop out for appointments or work from home when my baby is sick without any stress or hassle is worth more than any amount of free food. They allow you to be your 'authentic self' at work which you probably won't think it a big deal for you, until it's a big deal for you! In my personal experience, HubSpot really cares about their employees. So whether you're pregnant, you're unwell, a family member is unwell or there's something else going on in your life, in my case, HubSpot allows you to do your job around that life event (again, within reason). It sounds too good to be true but it's really a win win. They invest a lot in our training and onboarding when we join so why wouldn't they want to help us continue to work to the best of our abilities. Their systems are also set up to allow us to dial into video chats and access documents from anywhere.  As long as you're working hard and getting the job done, that's what matters. It's a great way of managing employees in my opinion. I used to think work/life balance meant getting out the door on time (which never happened in any other company I worked at) but now I know it means being able to fit work in around my life. 

HubSpotters are generally also amazing at helping each other out. The culture is really set up to make people work together. We're encouraged to thank and recognise colleagues who help us out. I've never been thanked more for just doing my job as I am here. And while that might seem like a corny pro, it actually really makes a big difference to your day.

The company also check in with us quarterly to see what issues are concerning us; what they might need to change. The month I started, there had been a big change in how we sell our services which meant people were going through a phase of working late to figure it all out. It became clear in the survey so HubSpot acted on it. Not only did they continue hiring to meet the needs of the company, they also brought in outside support to help us 'unplug' and manage work/life balance. 

Finally, they genuinely do their best to live by the Culture Code. When I read it (at interview stage) I was skeptical. Seemed too good to be true. So I tested it. I asked a bunch of Qs about maternity leave/pay; what the company is doing to help women thrive in tech etc. I was convinced these would go against me but instead, they were seen as positives - meant I was a good culture fit because I cared about the stuff the company cares about. I also love working at a Customer First company. It makes it much easier to do your job.
cons: It's a fast paced company (no doubt!) so if you're looking for a role where you just settle into the job and do the same thing every day, it's not for you. Our products and systems are constantly changing but most HubSpotters find this challenging and for me, it's actually a pro. Keeps the job interesting! But it might not be for everyone so it's worth mentioning it here.

headline: Autonomy at core of HubSpot
pros:
Get to work on interesting projects
Good employment perks
Promotions possible early in career
Focus on individual to drive their own career
Autonomy at core of HubSpot work
cons: Work life balance sometimes strained due to project deadlines. But this is the exception not the rule.

headline: Best company I've worked for!
pros:
* No micro management
* Ideas are taken seriously
* Friendly, safe workplace
* Fantastic culture
* Feel valued
* Great management
cons:
* A lot of meetings
* My role is new-ish so there isn't a clear way to advance right now

headline: Great and continually improving
pros: They care about employees as people, not just part of a balance sheet. They are transparent when something isn't working and how they are going to fix it. People care about their work and their colleagues. People are respectful of one another. I've also had many meetings with our CEO, CTO, CMO, COO, and none of them acted too busy to meet with me even though I am not an executive. They're very present and engaged no matter what your title is.
cons: As it's gotten bigger, it has gotten more bureaucratic in terms of the pace of decision-making and the hoops you have to go through to get something done.  The pace is still often quite high in terms of projects and deadlines, though. That can be good and bad. It's not boring since it's a high pace, but can be hard to meet the demands of a high-pace environment when there's more hoops to jump through than before, when the company was smaller.

headline: Great and continually improving
pros: They care about employees as people, not just part of a balance sheet. They are transparent when something isn't working and how they are going to fix it. People care about their work and their colleagues. People are respectful of one another. I've also had many meetings with our CEO, CTO, CMO, COO, and none of them acted too busy to meet with me even though I am not an executive. They're very present and engaged no matter what your title is.
cons: As it's gotten bigger, it has gotten more bureaucratic in terms of the pace of decision-making and the hoops you have to go through to get something done.  The pace is still often quite high in terms of projects and deadlines, though. That can be good and bad. It's not boring since it's a high pace, but can be hard to meet the demands of a high-pace environment when there's more hoops to jump through than before, when the company was smaller.

headline: Incredible culture and talent
pros: Wonderfully talented teams, always learning from everyone. Plenty of space and trust to allow true autonomy and feel proud of what you are doing.
cons: From the outwardly facing branding/social media presence, I was hesitant as it seemed too good to be true before I joined, but not sure how that can be fixed. It really is a great place to work.

headline: Love this company
pros:
Great work life balance
Takes care of their employees
No micro management
cons: can make more at other companies for sales roles, however, those other companies don't offer the same culture and flexibility that HubSpot does, which is why I'm staying.

headline: Revolving Door of Employees in Services Org
pros: Awesome Diversity & Inclusion events and initiatives. Ample opportunities for inter-company networking. Good benefits and perks, such as: stocked kitchen with healthy food options, barista bar, etc. Friendly employees across all departments.
cons: Unfortunately, the environment in the Customer Success team does not align with the culture that HubSpot so proudly promotes. More often than not, CSMs work an unrealistic and unhealthy amount of hours in order to keep afloat. It is common to witness CSMs trying to one up one another by highlighting how much administrative work they accomplish in one business day and how quickly they manage their call volume and overall workload. These tendencies were then encouraged by management rather than focusing on the quality of our efforts with customers. HubSpot endorses that their staff “work smarter, not harder”, but these rituals are both toxic and taxing.  A majority of the Customer Success Manager’s job is to juggle the sheer volume of new customers, which unmanageable long term. There are far too many administrative tasks and unnecessary meetings, which distract from “Solving for the Customer” and allow for less time to be spent on the critical component of relationship building with our customer base.

headline: High growth company where you can make big impact
pros: Great benefits and culture, you really feel like you’re driving impact with the work you do
cons: High impact work means high expectations, it’s not for everyone.

headline: Good place to work
pros: (Product) Small independent teams mean possibility of each team having a specific vision and each team member feeling that their work matters
cons: Small independent teams have trouble figuring out how to communicate and organize when larger, cross-team projects arise

headline: Everything changes really fast here
pros: Trending technology, lots of things to learn.
cons: Fast changing, highly dependant teams.

headline: Amazing company to work for
pros: Culture, pay, benefits, growth opportunities, social
cons: I would imagine most people who list cons here were not top producers, or haven't worked anywhere else.

headline: Latin America
pros: Company is growing and a lot of potential opportunities
cons: Growing too fast and lacks strategic vision.  Product driven

headline: Great place to work
pros: Management is outstanding and supportive
cons: Maybe it’s a little overly structured

headline: Stop Treating this like an Entry Level Role
pros: Benefits (unlimited vacation and sick time, ability to work remotely if need be)
cons:
-Not enough time in the day to be both a thorough support specialist that SFTC, and gain skills in a specialized area
-Most reps work 9 hours a day and are praised for working over time, despite minimum pay. working overtime seems to imply you are better (from a peer to peer standpoint, and manager to employee)
-Inappropriate to set a metric for "tickets" as opposed to "customers" at such a high number. I think you would solve for a lot of issues if you hired and trained your support reps in certain areas of the product-- you are doing a disservice to both your support rep and your customer (not setting up anyone for success)
-This role should not be advertised as a way to get somewhere. you need to start hiring people that absolutely love to troubleshoot software--you also need to be way more transparent about the types of troubleshooting that is going to be "encouraged" (namely, writing HTML and CSS. This is a huge skill, learning a language... not something to be excluded from a job description or even the interview)
-Speaking of "encouraged" troubleshooting... It needs to be way more obvious what a support rep should be responsible for doing. This expectation should begin when the customer purchases the product---and also, make this way more clear during training
-Your wiki is disorganized and impossible to find anything relevant, including your Knowledgebase. Noone can find anything in these places by just searching a  subject; Google seems to be the solution. Please organize your resources.
-Your "culture" consists of primarily white people

headline: Inbound Marketing Consultant
pros: Culture, work-life balance, growth opportunities
cons: Favoritism, not all employees given the same opportunities to succeed

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: Fantastic place to work that respects work life balance
cons: Still has work to do to improve diversity & inclusion.

headline: Truly a great place to work
pros:
- Unlimited vacation policy (if you're hitting your metrics)
 -Flexible work from home policy
- Employee Stock Purchase Program
- Restricted Stock Units granted at various levels (usually in association with promotions) 
- Coffee and beer gardens 
- Healthy snacks for free, including cereal, bagels, fruit, veggies, string cheese, etc. 
- Challenging but rewarding work environment - you'll never be bored
- Great support from colleagues - everyone is working to get better
cons:
- Process + system changes can be rolled up a bit clumsily, negatively impacting the day-to-day operations of individual contributors. 
- Benefits are fantastic. Pay has not kept up with the increasing cost of living in the Cambridge/Boston area.

headline: Support is a door that you must force open
pros: Working on the Support team is the best way to learn the product. Period. You get a great perspective  into how customers use the platform in their daily operations, as well as the tru inner-workings of the tool itself.
cons: Often not taken seriously be customers nor higher-tenured colleagues. We're usually the safety net for Salespeople who over-promise illusions of grandeur, or Success Managers who truly don't understand how most of the product works.

headline: Great company & people to work with
pros: Great education programs to get you started in your role and to help you learn more about the company
cons: The daily schedule is full on all the time may not be for some

headline: Awesome company to work
pros: Unlimited time off,  great environment, good work ethic
cons: Prepare to work long hours

headline: Awesome benefits, fantastic products, but not very diverse and very saturated territories
pros: One of the best companies when it comes to benefits, they take really good care of you, have monthly contests, take you to dinners and happy hours on the reg, and provide great health benefits. The people at HubSpot are also very kind and outgoing, so it's not hard to fit in for the most part. Brian Halligan is the man, very motivating, very enthusiastic, and really cares about his employees, as does Dharmesh. Leadership team is excellent, you'll learn more than you could imagine during your time at HubSpot.
cons:
The sales team is huge, and it shouldn't be. I think there's a bit over 500 sales reps, and HubSpot really only needs about 200. The territories are extremely saturated, you're given a few zip codes to work with no matter what vertical of business you go into (small biz, corporate, non profit, etc.) You'll spend about 80% of your time prospecting to companies that have already been reached out to by other reps at HubSpot, so to gain new business can be very difficult unless you dedicate 80 hours of prospecting each week. The sales cycle is long but you have support on all ends to help you finish. Would not recommend being an account exec, but if you start off as an SDR you will definitely learn a lot. They keep hiring more and more account execs which is leading to more than 70% of the sales org not meeting their quota.

It is also not very diverse, but then again, not a lot of companies in Boston are. Most of the people are of course white but it's hard to get other nationalities when that's all that is available in Boston. I was one of the few people of color in the entire organization, so of course I felt like we weren't represented very well. Out of the 1000 plus employees, I would say abut 30 or so aren't white. Having said that, I never felt out of place or insulted or anything, everyone is very welcoming. It would just be nice to have more minorities in the crew.

headline: Good
pros: Good benefits for all employees
cons: Long hours at the office

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Excellent people, good culture, treat employees well.
cons: Culture can be a little full on at times.

headline: A great place to be
pros: Career growth and benefits are great, unlimited vacation plan (if you're on target), work life balance
cons: None that come to mind

headline: Great environment and company culture
pros:
Great working environment, very collaborative and supportive teams
Flexible working hours and remote work available 
Great office space
Strong focus on diversity and inclusion 
Great benefits
cons: No major cons - Very open on addressing employee concerns

headline: I can't believe I get to work for Hubspot!
pros:
- This company is unbelievable.
- I literally wake up every day astounded that I work for such an amazing company.
- The training is incredible.
- The work itself is extremely fulfilling.
- The compensation is phenomenal.
- The benefits are very lucrative.
- The culture is unmatched.
- I'm a remote employee and work entirely from home, so I get an opportunity to "run my own business" but also still feel engaged and a part of the culture from afar! - There is so much opportunity to get plugged in beyong your job description. Despite being very new to the company, I was able to join the Culture Squad for my segment AND I was elected to fill a leadership role within the team!
- I'm constantly surrounded by such strong, high capacity leaders. Really, the hiring process is so thorough that when you finally make it through the door, you realize your in the company of some seriously brilliant peers. 
- I could go on and on. Really, I can't recommend this place to anyone doing the research about it. By far the best job I've ever had, and I am looking forward to growing and developing a long term career here.
- Thank you for everything, HubSpot!
cons:
- Training and Onboarding is INTENSE. Really. You will be fully equipped to succeed if you take training seriously. But onboarding is very intense. You WILL have a moment of "imposter syndrome" at some point thinking that you tricked the managers and that you're not qualified. But YOU ARE. You were hired on purpose. But take training seriously, and manage the pressure well and you will be great!

- The onboard Remote employees is extra tough. I don't say it arrogantly, but I strongly believe that it take a special person to work remotely. HubSpot is constantly improving the remote onboarding process, but be prepared to show your stuff with you ability to figure things out as you go!

- There seems to be limiting formal leadership opportunity for remote employees. I have a ways to go before any sort of promotions, but I'm not sure the management opportunities exist for remote employees today.

headline: Great Work Environment
pros: Young, friendly, hard working peers!
cons: Nothing - great experience! Would recommend to a friend!

headline: Lively and earnest
pros:
- smart and friendly people
- interesting work
- ample opportunity to grow
- autonomous teams are agile and fight bloat
- personal boundaries for work-life harmony are respected
- leadership is genuine when encouraging employees to take time off and recharge
- unlimited vacation/PTO - use good judgement
- flexibility to work remote is awesome
- key job-critical tools are all in the cloud, meaning I can work from different computers if necessary, which makes the work-remote perk even more reliable
- conference rooms with Zoom are PURE MAGIC and really make it easier to connect with colleages in different offices globally
- really excellent healthcare plan
- Cambridge office is gorgeous
cons:
- work-life harmony doesn't just happen, HubSpot is full of go-getters so of course the momentum is to get stuff done; that being said, when you make a clear boundary, people warmly respect it!
- pro tip, unlimited vacation means that you can't get paid for unused days if you were to transition to another company, so, better make good use of them! :)

headline: Easy going and work well with others great leadership
pros: Advancement reread into get up improve company and workplace
cons: Finding the right team or employees, dealing with rejection

headline: IS
pros: Cultural code is very important there
cons: I dont find any cons of working there

headline: Lots of smart people, but they know they're smart.
pros:
Pay is industry standard for most roles- no better, no worse. 

In-office benefits like stocked kitchen, gym, beer, and coffee are nice. 

You learn a lot, and having HubSpot in your resume is always good. 

Fun place to work if you're new to Boston, or just out of college and looking to network with other young people.
cons:
There are many problematic elements about working at HubSpot. Many of them are well-documented in prior reviews so I won’t waste space on them here. But here are a few themes that haven’t been delved into too much here. 

Work/Life balance 
Many teams at HubSpot work harder, not smarter. Employees who work long hours are seen as more committed, and more productive. Employees who utilize the “unlimited vacation policy” are often seen as frivolous and lazy. I was encouraged to take fewer days off after my wedding, and even when my spouse was in the hospital. The expectation was you’d always have your laptop “in case anything came up.” If someone left their desk before 6pm, you’d often hear them say something like “I have to go to an appointment but I’ll be back online by 8.” Oftentimes managers would communicate this as well- reinforcing the idea that you needed to be “online” 24/7. 

Age
Much has been said about HubSpot’s lack of diversity. I do believe there’s a good-faith effort to improve this, and I respect the standards they’re trying to set in the industry in this matter.  But what they seem unwilling to address is the lack of age diversity. Among all the people I collaborated with at HubSpot, I’m struggling to think of even one person who was over the age of 35. There are a lot of problems with this, obviously, but one thing that stuck with me was the “inmates running the asylum” vibe. Over and over again, major problems were left to a bunch of 25 years old employees to solve. While we (I was one of those 25 year olds) struggled to find solutions, these “crises” could have been solved easily through the lens of experience. Reflecting back, I often think about how every day felt like a fire drill at HubSpot, and I think much of that is because we all had no frame of reference. It was nearly everyone’s first or second job, and we all could have really benefited from someone working with us that had longevity in the industry, or longevity even in an office setting. 

Ego 
Now here’s something with a harder solve. HubSpot has an ego problem. Employees are told over and over that they’re the best, the most intelligent, etc etc. and that ethos is internalized by many. There’s a “win at all costs” mentality that causes high tension between employees, and fosters and extremely competitive environment internally. There’s a “watch your back” culture- your teammates WILL undercut you to get ahead. Leaders who’ve had complaints leveled against them time and time again continue to get promoted or shuffled around departments. If you provide results (hit your goals, etc) you’ll be held up as a “golden boy” and protected.

headline: Great place to work/but not perfect
pros: Great culture, benefits, allows an easy work/life balance. They generally try to make it a fun place to work and I can't tell you the number of restaurants I wouldn't have spent the money to try if it wasn't for HubSpot the amount they spend on their employees.
cons: Below average market salary, only outbound position in an increasingly inbound organization, success can be a product of territory and management and doesn't necessarily translate to skill and effort.

headline: inturn at Hubspot
pros: friendly, helpful people everyone is willing to help you and friendly.
cons: There's no big downside to working at HubSpot

headline: inturn at Hubspot
pros: friendly, helpful people everyone is willing to help you and friendly.
cons: There's no big downside to working at HubSpot

headline: A company that is trying to drive growth the right way.
pros:
Really smart, engaged, genuine management team.
Innovating on new products, opening new offices, trying to solve for the customer (SMB businesses). Trying to really drive growth the right way. 
Great healthcare benefits and great place to work for women/new moms. Very supportive community groups.
cons: Normal pains of a start-up growing into scale-up. Going through systems transitions that are necessary for the company to be able to keep growing at this pace & scale.

headline: It doesn't get much better than this for a software engineer
pros: Incredibly sophisticated engineering platform infrastructure; dealing with data scale challenges on the order of 50 million+ reads/second; regular opportunities to move between teams and pick up new skills; flexible hours and WFH; gorgeous Cambridge offices with lots of perks; small autonomous teams; upward mobility if you're willing and able; unlimited vacation; no-deductible health care; very smart, capable and engaged colleagues (who would've thought if you treat your employees very well, they pay you back with awesome performance and productivity); the list goes on...
cons: If you think there are any legitimate 'cons' to working at a place like this, you have lived in one pretty sheltered bubble your whole life my friend.  I would encourage you to get out into the world and gain some perspective.

headline: Learning at break-neck speed
pros: I've been at HubSpot for a little over 3 years now, climbing the sales ladder, from an Inbound Sales Coordinator, to a Business Development Rep, and now to an Inbound Growth Specialist (Account Executive). From never even considering sales as a career in my college days, the amount of coaching and training I've received at HubSpot has been more than I could have imagined. The learning is constant and I always feel there is more to learn. HubSpot as a whole also has exceptional executive leadership that not only cares about the customer and the growth of the company but on it's employees as well. I'm very bullish not only on the growth and market potential we have but also in the Diversity and Inclusion initiatives that our Co-Founders have places as an area of emphasis. As a sales rep that is also Latino, I've felt very comfortable in my time here, surrounded by ambitious, driven, intelligent, and kind people.
cons: The expectations are consistently high and not without it's stress. However, we have an abundance of resources and managers that genuinely care about it's employees in order to handle every day life and acknowledge that life isn't just work.

headline: Great place to grow your career
pros: It's a place where you're constantly challenged, pushed outside your comfort zone (in a good way), and able to learn a lot. You have to be proactive about it, but there's so much opportunity if you make the effort. The company has been on a rocket ship for the past few years and has no intention of slowing down.
cons: Things change quickly and longterm planning isn't a strong suit across departments. Stay adaptable!

headline: Customer Support Specialist
pros: HubSpot does a really good job making employees feel very valued at work. They are flexible with the employees’ work life balance. So people are very happy, creates a very welcoming and friendly environment.
cons:
Do HubSpot employees really have good quality of living though? It is very difficult to live in Boston with this very low salary. I make less than 40 k at HubSpot. There is no transportation benefit, no meals provided, and no bonus unlike other companies. With HubSpot salary, your quality of living is very pathetic. Unless you want to pay very high rent around Boston, you would have to live very far away. For commuters, cooking at home is not an option, especially if your dept requires you to work late shifts. Nobody has time to cook. You either snack your meals with free snacks in the office or spend a lot of money buying food. There are a lot of employees in the office who snack their meals with chips and cereals from the office. They are brining in smoothie baristas next year, but I bet there are going to be a lot of people drinking smoothie to substitute their breakfast, lunch, and dinner. I did not sign up for any health benefits because I cannot deduct any more pay from my salary for that. I just suck it up and suffer through if I ever get sick.

On weekends, you shouldn’t go out with your friends because you would not have any money to save up for your future. They have “unlimited” paid time off, but they should not call it unlimited because who would be dumb enough to take unlimited paid vacation and get fired? Some employees don’t feel comfortable taking vacation because they always say “Use Good Judgement.” 401k? Their match is a joke. You are not going have a bright future here. It is true that they have fun events and food here and there, but they are not even having employee holiday party this year! HubSpot is making a lot of money right now, all time high stocks. Very strange how employees not benefiting much from this. No holiday bonus, awesome. You will not make any fortune out of stock purchase plans. We are not going to be like 1990s Microsoft which every single employees including their janitors made money off of company stock. HubSpot, it’s just an extra income you’d be making if the company does well.

headline: Great company!
pros: Great benefits, amazing co-workers, and a great culture.
cons: Not great 401k matching program.

headline: HubSpot Intern
pros:
Flexible
Works well with school schedule
The hiring team is awesome
The culture is fun, lots of events and free food
cons:
There's a high school vibe at times
Work gets thrown off to the next person often
Culture can be overbearing for some and ostracize them

headline: Highly rewarding, dynamic, modern workplace!
pros:
When I make mistakes, people help me learn and grow from it, and don't focus on blaming me. When I succeed, people help celebrate my success. This culture lays the groundwork for moving fast, failing fast, and continuous iteration which I think is key for success.

Many companies stop caring about their employees' satisfaction as they scale. HubSpot is scaling like crazy and makes sure to invest proportionally in employee satisfaction. I think this will be instrumental in keeping HubSpot as a top destination for talent.

Great product with extreme potential.

I feel like my manager cares about finding work for me that interests me, while addressing the needs of the business.

I have received great mentorship.

Many fun / social opportunities (like mystery dinners, where employees are randomly matched with execs and share a meal together)

Awesome facilities: showers, gym, meditation room, free kitchen, tea-making robot.

Fantastic infrastructure and support for engineers.

Clear communication about requirements for career growth.
cons: 401k matching is weak, some flashy benefits offered but 401k matching lags behind.

headline: Great place to learn and incubate, compensation subpar for some departments
pros:
• Sterling executive management team that is constantly unsatisfied and strives to improve
• Understands that culture is like a shark - continuously moving forward with no steady state; actively invests in thoughtful and genuine initiatives that enrich the employee experience
• Recognizes the complex challenges in tackling diversity, inclusion, and belonging and the nuances between mentorship and sponsorship; attempts to meaningfully improve in these arenas
• Truly believes in transparency and allowing employees the ability to use good judgment
• Best-in-breed business enablement infrastructure that supports flexible working styles
• Supports continual education via tuition and Kindle reimbursements, in addition to inviting external speakers and implementing internal master classes and a fellows program
• Allows dogs
cons:
• Total compensation below average
• Variable quality in middle management

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros:
Very dynamic place. Probably the best managed engineering org I've seen. They've found a balance between process and productivity. Their infrastructure is top notch - you wont have to worry about solving silly infra problems that have been solved  a million times before.  People are nice. I've actually became friends with some of my co-workers, and we still stay in touch.
Their product is great, and customers love it. You actually get to interact with customers as much as you have time for (UX tests, actual dinners with customers, annual conference)
If you haven't so far, at HubSpot you will quickly learn what is actually important when it comes to making software. 
HubSpot is no one trick pony. There is plenty of innovation, new exciting things, and they MOVE FAST!
cons: HubSpot is big on culture and this can be a bit overwhelming. You might feel like you are losing your own identity to it, or that your identity doesn't matter, and it is all about how well you work in the HubSpot system. Whether this is a good thing or not would make for an interesting discussion, but their approach works very well for them.

headline: Excellent place to work with great growth opportunities.
pros: The defining aspect of HubSpot is the culture. The entire organization is welcoming, and I have never seen a company that runs as well as this one. You are genuinely looked after by all members of your team.
cons: Work/life balance can be difficult to work out at first.

headline: Marketing Manager
pros: Everything about this company is amazing!
cons: Not enough guidance on projects.

headline: Great Place for Growth
pros:
-High emphasis on employee growth
-Great benefits to encourage that growth like tuition reimbursement, free book program, professional development fund, etc.
-A network of employees who are passionate about their jobs
-Fun events
-Excellent speakers come in to share their wisdom
-Dog-friendly office
cons: None - while the fast-paced work environment might not be for everyone, I absolutely love it here.

headline: Call   Center   Agent Work From  Home
pros: Able to work   from home
cons: Only two 15 min breaks in an 8 hour shift.

headline: An environment that will constantly challenge you
pros:
- Incredibly smart and driven people who will inspire and motivate you to be better personally and professionally
- As someone on the younger side, I enjoy the fact that work and friends blur a little bit - I like hanging out with coworkers on nights and weekends. It makes work all the more enjoyable!
- Executive transparency
- Excellent managers who give you actual ownership, don't micromanage, and are invested in your career growth, not just their own
- Strong focus on diversity and inclusion efforts in recruiting, promotions, and compensation
cons:
- Fast pace is not for everyone and can definitely be overwhelming. I have felt at times as though I'm constantly playing catch-up
- While I believe in the mission of helping organizations grow better, I sometimes find myself doubting whether or not I'm truly making an impact on others' lives - marketing and sales software isn't my passion. That's personal, though
- Flexibility is a double-edged sword: work/life balance sometimes goes down the drain a bit as a result of seeing that others are online at early/late hours and not defining exactly how much time someone should be spending on work. There are definitely people who manage it well and still crush it at work, but they're few and far between

headline: Fast paced and huge career opportunities
pros:
Genuinely smart and nice to people to work with, good culture
Inspiring leadership at Exec level
They invest in employee growth and education
Fantastic opportunities for growth and progression
Takes very good care of new hires, good training programs
cons: Growing fast can also create uncertainty and changes which not everyone will enjoy

headline: Good Company
pros: Good pay + perks, interesting technical problems, excellent colleagues.
cons: Culture is very positive/gung ho - can be a little much at times.

headline: One of the best places I've ever worked at
pros: As a software engineer with years of experience, I find HubSpot offers a refreshing lack of busy-work. No deadlines, no release management, no all-day sprint planning, no daily stand-ups and no sprints for that matter. We work as small teams with great autonomy. I can push my work into production any time I am ready, as soon as I am ready, and only when I am ready. Getting my work done is practically frictionless. HubSpot employees are eager to offer assistance and share their collective wisdom. There are teams of software engineers whose sole responsibility is to make life easier for other software engineers. This place is quite unlike any other engineering organization I've ever worked at.
cons: This is not necessarily a "con" for everyone, but HubSpot's employees tilt rather young. Some might be uncomfortable with this atmosphere.

headline: A+ Wonderful Colleagues and an ''Always-Learning'' Mentality
pros: Love working at HubSpot because I have great colleagues to rely on and who support my ambitions in every step of the way. Very little politics in my work environment which allows me to do my job better. Truly love how at HubSpot we have great opportunities to continue learning, be it through additional learning opportunities (online courses can be reimbursed!) and a free books program which I fully take advantage of.
cons: Aligning our pricing, product features, and language to better suit non-US customers.  Currently, the wording and the pricing of our products are very strictly focused on growing US (or US-focused) companies, and fulfilling their marketing strategies and ideas.  We tend to lose out to rival companies who have a more local play, adapt to local marketing strategies, and have more flexible pricing and/or contract options.

headline: Content Marketing Manager
pros: I really recommend working for HubSpot, the executive team has a strong vision for the future and there's definitely many initiatives and programs to grow your career. I keep on being impressed with the freedom that each employee has and how information is communicated and shared freely within the company.
cons: The company is growing so fast that it is sometimes hard to keep up with with all the new-hires.

headline: Quick review
pros: Unreal work/life balance. Selling a product that actually works and very innovative leaders. You know you are changing with what the customer is looking for. Working with a lot of smart people.
cons: Quotas go up and territories get smaller (like most sales orgs). Not much career growth besides becoming a manager

headline: Great company
pros: Work, grow, work/life balance and culture are great here
cons: Nothing major come to my mind

headline: Great Company
pros:
- Great culture and benefits
- Very clear growth path. You will be given all the opportunities you need for your career
- Work whenever you want, wherever you want
cons:
- Despite being a customer oriented company, most of the people focus too much on features instead of improving stability
- Working with other teams is not always easy, as some people are not very friendly and will discourage you from making questions

headline: Great place for flexibility, learning and being a part of something BIG
pros:
You are constantly challenged here. It's safe to say that you are always learning and the autonomous nature of how people work here allows to pull on your strengths and work on your weaknesses.

Medical benefits are really good - with the deductible paid at 100% by HubSpot - this is a big perk. 

Parental leave is decent. 4 months for the primary. 

Work from home or flextime is highly supported.
cons: Internal communications are not great. The internal wiki is the source where everything gets dumped, but it's easy to fall behind or not understand what you might have missed. For such a global company, this should be better.

headline: Great place to grow in your career
pros:
HubSpot moves fast and invests in its people. While at HubSpot I have seen a massive effort to improve internal tools and to ensure people have what they need to get the job done. 
You are able to make a large impact because you are responsible for what you do and you own the things you are working on.
cons: Things can get hectic very quick as things move fast and if you aren't into that it could be an issue.

headline: Dream company
pros: HuBSpot has an incredible work culture which in turn attracts amazing colleagues. I have never worked with a more impressive set of individuals. They are amazing at their jobs but are so supportive, kind, empathetic and clever. There is no politics and everyone works hard for the good of our customers
cons: None other than the time zone differences. I personally have to be really mindful about not trying to spread myself too much over 2 time zones. That is a personal challenge not a company one.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: I've worked here for almost three years and have never considered leaving. I am supported in my job, work with amazing people, and have had many opportunities to grow my career. Support for flexible work schedules and remote work is also great.
cons: Like most tech companies, the engineering team is very white and male. However there have been a lot of efforts to try to fix this in the past few years.

headline: Growing Better +1
pros:
transparency
smart, driven people
excellent growth opportunity
stellar perks
cons: I have nothing to share here

headline: Great coworkers, big potential for impact & ownership
pros: Sharp coworkers, healthy and supportive environment, many opportunities for growth & learning, good compensation, very low politics, comfortable office. Engineering group  has a great set of tools to be productive. Product organization means each person can really have significant impact on a part of the products.
cons: Small teams means real responsibility on everyone's shoulders. There has been a lot of focus and investment in D&I over last 2 years  but it still a work-in-progress to be where everyone wants it to be.

headline: Great coworkers, big potential for impact & ownership
pros: Sharp coworkers, healthy and supportive environment, many opportunities for growth & learning, good compensation, very low politics, comfortable office. Engineering group  has a great set of tools to be productive. Product organization means each person can really have significant impact on a part of the products.
cons: Small teams means real responsibility on everyone's shoulders. There has been a lot of focus and investment in D&I over last 2 years  but it still a work-in-progress to be where everyone wants it to be.

headline: Great company
pros: great salary and training
cons: employees become too obsessed

headline: True Autonomy
pros:
A truly remarkable culture where I feel like a trusted member of the team. The organization learns from its mistakes and cares about employees.

Rapid growth and a broad product surface area that presents constant new opportunities. I believe that I have been given more opportunities at HubSpot than I would have at any other company.
cons: With growth comes growing pains.

headline: Great culture
pros: Growing really fast, which is good for career opportunities. Very flexible (unlimited holidays, easy to work from home..). The culture is also awesome, a lot of foreigners, no one judges no one.
cons: The breakfast is a bit early (before 9)

headline: You can feel yourself getting smarter
pros:
- Support. HubSpot is the first company I've ever worked for where I can count on every one of my colleagues to support me when I need it. Departments are so well aligned in their goals, it's almost always in someone's interest to help you, and vice-versa, even if you work for different teams.

- Precision. Brian Halligan (Founder & CEO) recently described this company as a "laboratory for ideas," and that's exactly how it feels. Although the work I do here is consistent with the marketing industry today, HubSpot does it with a precision and at a depth that is hard to come by. You're always given the opportunity to run an experiment or touch a new piece of software that upgrades your business acumen.

- Personal growth. You work with people who are so smart and passionate about their work, it inevitably rubs off on you. I can feel myself getting smarter and faster because of the people I work with every day.

- Amenities. Free food when you need it. Work from home when you want it. The office is so cozy, though, I usually prefer coming in. :)
cons:
The first week of training can be overwhelming depending on the department for which you were hired. A lot of information is thrown at you, and while it is all important, it can be hard to sort out what you'll need to know right away to be successful.

This place is a bit of a bootcamp, at least when you start. You work so consistently hard that it's easy to feel swept up in systems and processes that offer little time to digest and ask questions. (You get much better as you go.)

Work-life balance is a priority here, but it might not be inherent to your position. It's up to you to find that balance and protect it -- even if that means having some patience and/or a conversation with your manager.

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros: Great culture, really smart people, awesome office.
cons: None so far, everything has been great.

headline: Lovely team, great company
pros:
* friendly team
* flexible career planning and progression
* most problems go away in a company that's growing 30% a year, so it's pretty sweet all around
* close relationship with other international offices
cons:
* there is no air conditioning in the office (though we will probably have moved by next summer)
* our developers are based in Dublin and Cambridge, so if you want to hang out with engineers the Berlin office is not ideally located

headline: Great Job to learn new skills
pros: There are a lot of resources to learn new skills for free. You get time every day for self directed personal development. The managers and team leaders want to see you grow. Also health insurance kicks in day 1 and it's pretty good.
cons: The salary is not as much as other "first jobs." You will also have to work odd hours like 11-8 some months.

headline: Couldn't be happier at HubSpot
pros:
-First and foremost, the people are great to work with and we've achieved this by hiring for HEART. Google the "HubSpot Culture Code" for more info.

-Career growth: We're a growing company and we have many challenges we're looking to solve as we scale, we're dead serious about solving them.

-Product: Our business is strong and our product keeps getting better. We care about our customers first, that leads to great outcomes for our business.

-Facilities: Our offices are designed to make you feel comfortable and happy to be at work, we aim to make HubSpot the best place to do your best work and that extends beyond our facilities.

-D&I: We have ongoing initiatives and resources dedicated to ensuring people feel comfortable to be their whole selves at work. It's a priority for all managers and teams.

There are so many more pros that I can mention, but these stand out for me after being here for almost 3 years.
cons: -It's not an easy job, you are constantly challenged to do better.

headline: Everything it's cracked up to be!
pros:
HubSpot presents itself as a fun-loving, highly empathetic, adaptable company and that is exactly what it is. Everyone in this company has more integrity than any other place I've worked.

• Room for growth
• Fast-paced environment
• Upper-level management is open to new ideas and experimentation
• Low-stress, highly productive environment
• Caring, honest,  intelligent co-workers
cons:
• Pay is less than average
• Diversity numbers are typical of a tech company (i.e. low)

headline: Principal Customer Support Specialist
pros:
+ Friendly, supportive and inclusive office culture
+ Manager cares about your career progression.
+ Great benefits (time off, gym and educational reimbursement)
