cons:
- Workload can be overwhelming at times
- Organisational structures continuously changing because the company is growing.

headline: Growing at HubSpot just keeps getting better
pros: I've been at HubSpot for just over 3 years and the opportunities for growth never cease to amaze me. As we grow and scale, people get a chance to experiment with new processes, are empowered to approach challenges with new, creative ideas, and get to partner with colleagues across functions and offices. I've personally found so many opportunities to continue to have an impact and grow and stretch beyond the initial scope of my role. Beyond that, HubSpot cares deeply about its employees and fostering an inclusive environment, which is demonstrated in the continued investment in our employee resource groups, training/development for people managers, and in our benefits. As a working parent who recently went on parental leave, I can't stress enough how much HubSpot's insurance coverage, parental leave, and workplace flexibility has enabled me to fulfill my roles both at work and at home. Can't think of a better place to learn and grow my career.
cons: Things move quickly and we're still figuring out how to communicate change. If you get complacent and don't proactively consume information through our internal communication channels, you can miss critical company news and updates. We've invested in new tools, resources, and people to make this more streamlined, but it's a work in progress.

headline: Great culture, clear career paths and amazing opportunities
author_position: Inbound Marketing Strategist und Marketing Consultant
pros:
I've been a HubSpot fanboy since I've started using it as a customer in 2014/15.

- clear career development paths and opportunity to move across teams
- great benefits (unlimited holidays, gym reimbursement, education allowance, stock options, team outings, etc.)
- amazing new hire on-boarding and continued learning and development opportunities
- great & diverse colleagues to work with
cons:
- Internal comms (in general and around product launches) could be done better
- Development focus sometimes too US centric

headline: best place i have worked in so far
pros:
great employee benefits, constantly reviewing themselves to make sure employees are happy
awesome work culture, everyone is happy and loves working here
cons: young middle management still needs to be trained and honed more but still very promising

headline: Best tech company in Dublin
pros:
I've worked at a number of tech companies in Dublin, and have a bunch of connections working at others. HubSpot for me, out performs them all. 

Work
- Great engineering stack
- Very talented workforce
- You can see your changes have an impact very quickly
- Autonomy is very real
- Fantastic perks + salary
- Less meetings, more getting stuff done

Culture
- Transparency is highly regarded and encouraged
- Active social committee across the company, meaning regular events
- Very flexible working hours and working from home
- Free breakfasts and lunches

Office
- Gym on site
- Vibrant modern office space
- Biking area + showers with towels

Career
- Everyone is responsible for their work
- Great opportunities to move to management or continue on the technical road
cons:
Very hard to find problems that aren't addressed quickly. 

We expect a high standard of employee across the board. Some might find this challenging, but it also means you get to work with high achievers.

headline: Great people and a great culture
pros:
The people are very welcoming and open, its very easy to feel part of the team very quickly.

So much effort is put into creating a great culture, its more than just free pizza and snacks. There are programs around diversity & inclusivity, nutrition, health, respect for others etc.

The company is really flexible with vacations, work from home, bringing dogs to the office and there are lots of relaxed spaces in the office to hold meetings and catch ups with colleagues
cons: The interview process can be challenging but if you put in your best effort it can pay off. Be yourself because that is who they really want to see. Research, practice and enjoy the experience. Work closely with your recruiter as they can really help

headline: From startup to scale up
pros:
As we've grown we've done a great job of scaling the things that make working here great. Engineers still have incredible autonomy, and teams have trust to chase after big, ambitious missions, whether that means working on brand new features, or scaling and ensuring the quality of products that make our users successful today.

We also seem to have some gravitational pull for bringing in caring, humble people, who are incredibly smart and a pleasure to be around.
cons:
Things move quickly. The company's operating system is regularly evolving. We don't always get everything right...

But if you're up for it, those are the things that make it interesting. This is a case study in motion.

headline: Amazing culture. Amazing company.
cons:
- Work can get hectic time to time
- Career progress can be tricky, but that's to do with the fact that the company is growing fast. If you're patient, that will work out! :)

headline: Best place I've ever worked
pros: Best idea wins, no matter who has it. Employees bring a level of passion and dedication to great work, and HubSpot brings a level of passion and dedication to the employees. Your way more likely to encounter too many people contributing to a solving a problem than not enough.
cons: Not a con for me, but it is a fast paced environment with frequent change. If you are the type of person who needs stability and routine to feel comfortable at work, I can see that being a cause of anxiety.

headline: Incredibly low drama place to work
pros: The thing that I love most about HubSpot is there is just so little drama -- the hand-wringing, fiefdom building, energy-sucking drama that exists in so many tech companies. It's a team of people who just want to do great work, and for the most part, people act intelligently and kindly. Do we have moments of drama? yes. Times when communication is derailed? totally. Meetings where a group of very smart people act kind of stupid? ok sure, it happens :) But it's rare, and I love that.
cons: The thing that seems to trip us up most often is trying to do too much, being overly ambitious and forgetting to prioritize and cut rigorously.

headline: Incredibly low drama place to work
pros: The thing that I love most about HubSpot is there is just so little drama -- the hand-wringing, fiefdom building, energy-sucking drama that exists in so many tech companies. It's a team of people who just want to do great work, and for the most part, people act intelligently and kindly. Do we have moments of drama? yes. Times when communication is derailed? totally. Meetings where a group of very smart people act kind of stupid? ok sure, it happens :) But it's rare, and I love that.
cons: The thing that seems to trip us up most often is trying to do too much, being overly ambitious and forgetting to prioritize and cut rigorously.

headline: Growth-focused - Transparent and flexible
pros: HubSpot is extraordinarily flexible - from work hours to location - which makes it so easy to take time off for yourself or for vacation. This comes with HubSpot also being a fast-paced and challenging work environment. The good thing about that though is that leadership is constantly pushing you to grow as an employee. I feel supported in my attempts to advance my career and professional skills at all times.
cons: As the company scales you have to fight a little harder to get resources - from money for team building to program budget.

headline: Channel Team
pros: Amazing freedom to do your work and not be micromanaged.
cons: Pay could be better for Channel Employees.

headline: Blessed
pros: HubSpot is a special place. Not only can you come here and get to work on cool challenges, helping our company to grow while helping our customers, partners, and their customers to grow, but you are empowered to grow as a professional and an individual as well. You are given flexibility to work how you work best, allowing for non-guilty work-life 'fit'. And you have the autonomy and the resources to successfully accomplish your goals. HubSpotters are smart and work hard, so you're constantly learning from your colleagues. There's a lot of great energy here, and employees like coming to work, creating a supportive, inclusive and positive environment.
cons: HubSpot is growing quickly and has a really strong culture- both great things, but this can be difficult to navigate when you're new. There are a lot of people who have been at HubSpot for a long time with a ton of institutional knowledge and who have deep relationships with one another, and this can be difficult to penetrate.

headline: Been here for 5.5 years...not leaving any time soon
pros: Lots of autonomy, big mission, market leader, more work than their are people to do it. So, if you know how to have an impact, this is a place you can build a great career.
cons: We're working through how to be a scale-up. Challenges every day. But, that's more an opportunity than a con :)

headline: Sweet spot from a scale perspective, and amazing people
pros:
- Culture that encourages entrepreneurialism
- Maturity in state of organization that is exciting and helpful (all your efforts have the potential to scale, and you have a good amount of resources to do so)
- Great peers to work with
cons:
- Comes with any entrepreneurial environment, but at times can feel like there is not enough structure and focus
- Could improve diversity in leadership roles

headline: Flexible work culture
pros: Lots of perks (unlimited books program, unlimited vacation, great pantry offerings and fun team activities).
cons: It's a competitive group! So be prepared to always be on the ball

headline: HubSpot has changed my life
pros:
HubSpot has changed my life... and that is not hyperbole. When people ask me why I continue to work at HubSpot, this is how I answer: (1) I'm in love with our mission. We really help businesses grow and that's a powerful force. (2) The people. HubSpot has a rare breed of people that are insanely smart and helpful. That is a rare combination. (3) We're winning. We continue to grow quickly and that means there is a lot of opportunities. Plus, it just feels great to be on a winning team and in a winning culture. 

So when I say HubSpot has changed my life it's been about amazing experiences to learn with wonderful people around me going after an amazing mission to help millions of businesses grow better. And yes, my career and earnings have exceeded all my dreams. HubSpot has changed my life.
cons: HubSpot isn't for everyone. If you can't work hard enough, HubSpot isn't for you. You'll fall in love with HubSpot and our people, but you won't enjoy it fully. We have amazing training and managers to help you, and we have amazing perks like work from home, unlimited vacation, and flexible working hours, but these are perks are tough to use when you don't have the engine to perform. We are a performance driven company and some people just aren't cut out for that.

headline: Incomparable to any other company I’ve seen
pros:
—THE PEOPLE
—HubSpot invests heavily in their employees and provide a ton of opportunities to learn and grow professionally
—Leadership is transparent and allow everyone to have a voice. 
— The benefits are exceptional 
— Work/Life balance
cons: I can’t think of any

headline: Channel Account Manager
pros: Love the flexibility of HubSpot. I can work remotely if I need to and I do not need to worry about "logging hours".
cons: They push the sales org HARD. That isn't the best environment for everyone. Be ready to work for your quota.

headline: A great place to grow and be challenge
pros:
Transparency and education - From the executives to individual contributors what is being worked on is clearly communicated across the organization. Further more it's not just what has being worked on but lessons learned being shared. It's like an on going MBA every day. 
Culture/HubSpot Values - Working with smart, humble remarkable individuals makes going to work both challenging and refreshing.
Growth opportunities - For those that are driven and take initiative there is endless opportunity for growth
cons: We move fast and pivot quickly, sometimes this creates additional work but is worth it in the end.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: HubSpot practices what they preach in terms of transparency.  All employees are kept in the loop on what leadership is thinking, how the company is doing, and what's on the upcoming roadmap.  As an employee, I'm given a creative license to make my role into whatever I'd like it to be and take on any additional projects I'm interested in pursuing.  Additionally, the people here (sounds cliche) make coming to work everyday truly enjoyable.
cons: I don't think there are any cons.  It's a great place to work.

headline: Awesome company with great leadership and vision
pros: Challenging problems to solve, great flexibility, tons of growth ahead
cons: Pace of change is really high

headline: Great company, even better culture
pros:
Hubspot has very transparent culture. 
People work hard and party hard!
The company paid a lot of effort in promoting diversity and gender equality.
cons: 401k much is really low, only 2500

headline: Still the best place I've ever worked
pros:
5 years ago, when I set out to find a new job, I really searched for companies that valued their employees. In some of my previous jobs, that was certainly not the case. 

At the time, Dharmesh was just releasing the Culture Code and I was immediately sold. The autonomy, trust, and positive attitude exhibited at HubSpot are far beyond any other company I've worked for in my 20-year career. 

The management team takes the feedback from quarterly (anonymous) employee surveys very seriously and has proven themselves over the years to fix patterns of issues.

As a manager, I've learned a lot on how to help people achieve their goals and take on more responsibility.

As an engineer, I've been able to carve out time to pursue difficult technical challenges and get recognized for them.

The technical infrastructure is amazing, allowing engineers to iterate quickly and ship stuff.

Hands down, this is the best job I've ever had and I'm terribly concerned that if I ever have to leave, I'll be very disappointed that my next company doesn't live up to my experience at HubSpot.
cons:
The company has grown a lot and while that allows us to get more done, it also drastically increases the coordination and communication needed to launch a project. Sometimes it's not clear who owns what. It's a bit easier for people who have been here a long time, but I think it's really hard on new folks.

With great power comes great responsibility. If you're not comfortable shipping things and then being on call in case it blows up in the middle of the night, then HubSpot may not be for you. Luckily, we have a lot of resiliency in our architecture, so services are much more reliable than in other companies I've worked at.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Inclusive, great benefits, people are dedicated and work hard. Everyone is positive and supportive. The culture does live up to the hype
cons: occasionally people are over-enthusiastic about HubSpot, but most people enjoy this

headline: Inbound Professor
pros: HubSpot has taken my personal and career life to the next level. The team I'm a part of has a mission and values that I believe in that give me a purpose. This is something I've had an issue with in my career, not feeling like I'm a part of something that's making a difference. I see the difference I'm making each day and it keeps me coming back for more.
cons: Honestly, I don't really have a con for working at HubSpot. That being said, you're in control of your own destiny. HubSpot will allow you to grow, but you have to want it. You have to be curious. You have to be dedicated to being the best. If you do, then HubSpot is a place for you, because they allow you to create your own opportunities.

headline: Amazing Place to Work!
pros: I have been with HubSpot for just under a year and have loved every minute of it. The work I do is engaging and my team and managers have been nothing but supportive. As the company is growing so quickly, there have been a lot of changes in the short amount of time that I have been here but also a chance to take on new projects and grow my skill sets. I see a lot of potential for me to grow with this company.
cons: Not really a con but just a couple things to keep in mind when considering if it is the right fit. HubSpot is growing quickly so that means there is always a lot going on and a lot of new projects could come your way, so you have to be adaptable. Another thing HubSpot values is autonomy. You won't find a micro manager which is great, but if you like to have a lot of feed back and a lot direction on what you should be doing you will want to be clear about that with your manager.

headline: Great Place to Work if You're Proactive!
pros: Lovely people, terrific opportunities, transparency, and folks who actually care about all those buzzwords (think: work/life balance, unlimited vacation, diversity and inclusion).
cons: Certain times of the year can be overwhelmingly busy. It can be hard to get help/direction because there's a lot of self-starting/proactivity expected, and other teams might be too busy to help you if your project isn't in their "lane."

headline: This is the best company I've ever worked for.
pros: HubSpot is a fantastic company to work for. They give you the freedom to design your own work projects.  The opportunity to work alongside incredibly smart people and solve big, real-world problems. They actually care about the customers we're solving problems for.  Everyone is seen as a "leader," and the professional growth opportunities are immense. Great ideas, dedication and work ethic, and emotional intelligence are valued more than anything. Plus, the office and all the benefits.
cons: It's challenging, hard work. It can be stressful at times. And as a large company, it's competitive — not only to get hired, but once you're here, too. But it's exciting work, and it'll push you to grow in ways you never thought imaginable.

headline: This is the best company I've ever worked for.
pros: HubSpot is a fantastic company to work for. They give you the freedom to design your own work projects.  The opportunity to work alongside incredibly smart people and solve big, real-world problems. They actually care about the customers we're solving problems for.  Everyone is seen as a "leader," and the professional growth opportunities are immense. Great ideas, dedication and work ethic, and emotional intelligence are valued more than anything. Plus, the office and all the benefits.
cons: It's challenging, hard work. It can be stressful at times. And as a large company, it's competitive — not only to get hired, but once you're here, too. But it's exciting work, and it'll push you to grow in ways you never thought imaginable.

headline: HubSpot is the "Google" of Boston
pros:
Very autonomous environment with a lot smart people who are motivated. But not smart in a  competitive or aggressive way. I've experienced 0 top-down pressure. I feel like I have the freedom to really dive into customer problems and be creative about solving them. HubSpot is customer obsessed and actually means it. The product hierarchy feels really flat.

The culture is so friendly and genuine. People just say "hi" in the morning even if they don't know you. Simple stuff like that really matters. Also, dog friendly environment, UM WHAT. Amazing.

The CEOs don't treat themselves like gods and I literally just saw one of the CEOs (Brian) walking around with his dog. They are very involved, but not in a control-freak type way. Their visions are also sound and reasonable, yet inspiring. They are smart dudes!
cons:
It's a growing company so there are some growing pains obviously associated with that. For example, not every team is on the same methodology...some practice Scrum, some don't practice anything. It's a very engineering focused culture with little project management so sometimes that's stressful because you never know what's going on or what the focus is. It feels like there's an aversion to process because they want to keep that "startup" feel.

As a PM, you really gotta drive that focus or else things feel chaotic. Because each team is autonomous, you can try implementing some new stuff if your tech lead allows you to.

The product culture is also learning how to measure success with releases. It seems like a new topic that they're trying to implement.

There are some weird product/engineering things that need to be fixed, but it doesn't impact my positive feeling of working here. They just need to be open to new things and adopting practices from the top software companies.

headline: Working at HubSpot for 3+ Years
pros: I have worked at HubSpot for over three years now and I continue to learn and grow each and every day. I am surrounded by some of the most intelligent and thoughtful co-workers and on the HubSpot Academy helping in transforming the way the world does business.
cons: There are no downsides to working here.

headline: Forge your own path!
pros:
- HubSpot gives you the opportunity to forge your own path. It's a fast-paced work environment with things ever changing but step up to the plate and you will be recognized. 
- Career growth, HubSpot doesn't just use this as a recruiting gimmick. Managers work with you to find out where your strengths are and what areas of the business you would most thrive in!
- We can't talk about HubSpot without thinking about the company culture. From flexible schedules and endless food/coffee to quality healthcare, retirement, and investment options it's one of the best I've seen in the industry!
- THE PEOPLE! With so many company sponsored events going on, it's not hard to make some lasting friendships.
cons:
- Burnout. I wouldn't say this is necessarily specific to HubSpot but with the fast-paced work environment, it's not hard to feel it from time to time. 

Advice: stick with it, it will get better and the grass is not always greener. If it doesn't get better, raise your hand and work towards a change!

headline: Constant growth and learning
pros: A culture built on learning and stretching your mind. I've been challenged to be very agile in my work and learning from outside sources and my peers to come to a good solution. "This is the way it's always been done" is not part of the conversation here. Which I love
cons: With things moving quickly, sometimes people are working on the same thing at the same time. Silod communication.

headline: Amazing company to work for!
pros:
This company is amazing. I started about 10 months ago and I absolutely love walking into work every single day. The people, culture, lifestyle, inclusivity, and overall growth of the company are just a few of the incredible things I love being a part of. Even in the last 10 months that I have been here, HubSpot has grown at a rapid pace and it keeps the environment so exciting. 
The awareness around work/life balance is also very appreciated. 95% of the time, I love coming into work and collaborating with my peers (and playing with all the dogs). But 5% of the time I need a mental health day, or I would rather work from my couch in pjs. My quality of work doesn't decrease - in fact, knowing that I can do that and not feel weirdly guilty about it like I did at my last job,  increases my productivity. Thank you, HubSpot, for understanding that sometimes we need to listen to our bodies and take care of ourselves....AND we are still dedicated to our careers. Many companies feel like that is an OR statement.
cons: Double edged sword - with the rapid growth and so many new products being launched, it can be really difficult to keep up. However, based on recent surveys we have all gotten, I am sure the product team is working on a more digestable way to release this information to the sales team.

headline: Phenomenal Place to Work
pros:
-Huge opportunities for professional development
-Fantastic work perks
-Great community and culture
-Supportive management
-Clear expectations and goals for promotion
cons: -Lack of flexibility between sales segments in terms of metrics, goals, and opportunities for promotion

headline: Best place to start and grow a career in tech sales!
pros:
Incredible training, an unprecedented amount of transparency in the company, tons of intentional strategies that are put in place to develop the sales team both personally and professionally. Everyone I’ve met so far is very friendly,  helpful, and empathetic.

Being surrounded by super smart people that are all aligned towards the hubspot mission provides a sense of: we’re all apart of something greater than ourselves.
cons:
Diversity is definitely the first thing that comes to mind. There are not a lot of people or color ESPECIALLY in sales. There has been a couple things put in place to make the sales org more inclusive, however, there’s a lot of work that needs to be done. 

A second con would have to be the lack of opportunities to work remote in sales. Most tech companies offer plenty of opportunities to work remote while still developing their career. Unless hubspot is able to come up with more opportunities to work remote, they will lose talent to other tech companies.

headline: Great Company!!
pros: Really great culture and everyone goes out of there way to help you.
cons: As an intern, sometimes things can be slow and some tasks are not as glamorous as others.

headline: The actual best place to work
pros:
- Leadership TRULY CARES about employee experience and making sure we can all bring our authentic selves to work, feel supported both at work and outside of work, and are growing in our careers—it is remarkable
- Huge energy behind diversity & inclusion initiatives from the highest levels of the company—really working to move the needle here in a way that's very encouraging
- You get to work with and learn from the smartest, kindest, most generous folks
- Ownership and autonomy in engineering—you get to make an impact from day 1
cons:
- Pay in engineering is below market
- 401k match is very poor (as mentioned many times in reviews)

headline: Great place to work
pros: Free coffee, snacks, and booze.
cons: Lackluster retirement plan with very limited matching.

headline: Excellent place to work
pros:
* Leaders are passionate, candid, and transparent. Special shout out to Eric Richard!
* Employees are driven, curious, and just fun to be around
* Office building and location are nice
* Autonomy is real. Impact is what you make it
cons: * Diversity is pretty bad, but leadership is working to improve it.

headline: The Hype is Real
pros:
-A leadership and People Ops team who genuinely care for their employees and how to improve their experience
-Flexibility
-Community through employee resource groups
-Great benefits
-No shortage of challenging work
-Autonomy
cons: The pace at which things change can be a bit overwhelming if you're not used to it.

headline: HRIS Manager
pros:
- Great people
- Great benefits
- Good opportunity for growth
- Great flexibility
cons: - Work life balance can be a bit of a challenge within such a rapid growth space

headline: Building a Company Our Grandkids Will Be Proud of
pros:
I come to work everyday feeling challenged.  This place has some of the smartest and most hardworking people I have ever worked with.

Flexibility - we are trusted to get our work done.  There is a lot to do, but I never feel like I am forced to work on someone else's schedule.  Many people on my team work remotely whenever they need to.

Growth trajectory  - We are growing fast.  I feel like we are only in the beginning stages of growth.  This is a positive for the company and also for my personal career growth.  I'm confident my career will grow as the company continues to grow.

 People care - Not only are the people hardworking, but I genuinely feel like the people I work with care about me as a person.  They care about my personal and professional goals.  I come to work everyday feeling like I can bring my whole-self.

Diversity & Inclusion - We still have a long way to go to build a "company our grandkids will be proud of", but there has been significant progress to make HubSpot a more diverse and inclusive team.  Our leadership team has made this a core priority and have put resources behind our diversity & inclusion efforts.
cons: If you don't like working in the "grey" and ambiguity, this may not be the place for you.  We move fast and everyone is empowered to make decisions without always having all of the details.  This is a strength for some, but I've seen it be overwhelming for others.  If you are looking for a more predictable pace and structure, HubSpot is not the place for you.

headline: Great opportunities but stay vigilant
pros:
The entry level tech support position is a great opportunity for someone like me who's switching career paths or just starting in the software industry. The training is thorough and the experience you get working with customers is EXTREMELY valuable - you can completely start your software career from zero here, and the skills are transferrable if you decide you'd like to work at another company. Once you get out of Support, or if you start at a higher position, there's a strong feeling of belonging to a community and being truly respected and appreciated by your colleagues for people who do good work. The benefits are unbelievable so you'll definitely feel comfortable and taken care of. It seems like you also have some pretty extreme job security because the company basically refuses to fire anyone unless they're a colossal failure, but I'm not sure if I would 100% consider that a "pro." 

I have a lot of negative thoughts I'm going to share below but I don't want it to come across the wrong way - the pros GREATLY outweigh the cons at HubSpot. There are only a handful of positions here where you'll feel under-appreciated and underpaid. If you're smart and responsible, you'll move up quickly and you'll have fun doing it. The culture is fast-paced and challenging in an exciting way, Brian and Dharmesh are absolute wonders to be associated with, and you'll have plenty of opportunities to grow and succeed. The benefits are excellent and will make even the less-desirable positions comfortable. Take advantage of the unlimited time off, free healthy food in the kitchen, crazy good health care, and generous sabbatical!
cons:
If you're starting in Support, as many people at HubSpot do, GET OUT AS SOON AS YOU CAN. The work is grueling, hours are long, expectations are ridiculously high, and you'll be abused pretty regularly by customers (although this has gotten a lot better since they've put restrictions on who can call into the support phone line). The success of the company is so heavily reliant on support (a lot of customers list support at the top of their reasons for choosing HubSpot over competitors) but no one cares about you at all except for your direct manager (DIRECT support management is amazing, to be fair). Sales and account managers will throw you under the bus or bully you into spending your whole day on difficult side projects for their customers so they don't have to do their jobs. 

The pay is super low even for an entry level tech support position, and the majority of jobs that are readily available to you after a year or 2 in support come with insultingly measly pay raises. View these positions as stepping stones. You're not getting everything you can out of the company until you're 2-3 steps away from Support. That being said, don't give Support too much of yourself while you're there. You'll get ahead by doing your job well and networking and that's it - don't waste your time on side projects and overtime because it will not benefit you, and the second you show that you're willing to put in extra work, upper management will bleed you dry. Keep your head down and trudge forward if you want to succeed here, and be wary of your low-effort colleagues. For some reason HubSpot refuses to reprimand kids in Support who do *under* the bare minimum and continuously make HUGE mistakes. These people will make your job so much harder because they're looking for every excuse to put their work on your plate so they can go enjoy the free beer. Don't befriend these people, and when their lack of effort starts to effect you, just go right to their manager and move on. They're not worth your time.

Now that I'm out of Support I enjoy my job SO MUCH MORE. In fact, this is my favorite job I've ever had, despite the fact that I'm still not getting paid a competitive rate. I'll take the lower pay for a job I truly enjoy and the feeling of genuine respect in the workplace though. 

The last thing I'll say about HubSpot is that you should be wary of the work culture. Especially when you're in Support, they'll try to distract you with constant social events and parties. It honestly feels like a frat house at times and there seems to be this constant pressure to drink and party, especially when you first start. Like with any other job, just be careful. Go to the social events that seem fun to you or that will actually help you network. If you're going to drink, do so lightly and skip the afterparties. If you're in Support, I would honestly recommend not going to any parties if you can avoid it. Finish your work and go home because otherwise the office will become home and it gets unhealthy really quickly. Since it's so common for people to start drinking at the office, the line of when work ends and time off begins gets blurred and things can get ugly. People have no boundaries and are constantly embarrassing themselves by talking about private/personal things that should NEVER be discussed in the office. Don't be one of them. Trust me, I've made that mistake a few times during my early days at HubSpot and I'm still humiliated.

headline: Approaching my year anniversary.
pros:
-Great people. 
(The folks who work at HubSpot are sharp and empathetic. They help you raise the bar with a truly human approach) 
-Great Culture
(Which is a product of the quality people who are hired as well as the intentional manner that leadership takes to cultivate it.)
-A place where you can build and make a difference. 
(You can really own your interests and develop programs that excited you at HubSpot.)
cons:
-I think we could improve our training/education of existing managers. Since HubSpot grew so fast so quick, I believe that people grew in their careers at an accelerated pace and did not have the correct prior training on becoming a new manager.
(Note: this is something that is currently in the works.  So I am excited to see the future improvements.  Nice work team!)

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Flexible work/life balance. Great location
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Great start to any career
pros:
Hiring process took place through APAC division. It was a very extensive process and they do ask many gruelling questions, always be prepared to give more context and colour if they dig deeper into your answers. 

Even before being hired I felt that I had already picked up a lot of interviewing skills and they openly give you tips on how I could have made my answer or preparation a bit more polished. 

While it wasn't an easy process, but I definitely appreciated what I learnt and it made me realise that HubSpot was somewhere that was genuinely interested in developing my professional and personal capital.

Throughout the entire interview process my two main points of contact were Elayne and Yuan from the Singapore office. They were always available to chat, help fill any gaps in my knowledge of the product, and tried their best to fit the interview times to my schedule (even apologised for a timing mix up). Super appreciative as not all companies care about small details like this.
cons: It's an exhaustive process, so be prepared to answer some tricky questions and for a long application. But it pays dividends in how to better present yourself!

headline: Exciting time to work at HubSpot
pros:
1. There is never a dull moment at HubSpot. Our product is growing, the team is growing, and we are constantly evolving to meet the needs of the industry. 
2. HubSpot's mission is to help millions of organizations grow better, and it's been inspiring to work at a company who believes we can have an impact on the world. Our vision for the future is exciting, and allows for continuous improvement and growth. 
3. The people who work at HubSpot are smart and dedicated, but also human and aspire to create a culture of empathy. I genuinely enjoy coming to work every day.
4.  The flexibility is huge for me, many teams allow you to work remotely and take time off when you need it.
cons:
1. Because we are growing so quickly, it's difficult to stay up to date on information, and sometimes this results in duplicate effort from more than one team. 
2. We are still figuring out how to scale and create a cultural that is globally inclusive and provides the same opportunities for every team in every office. Many of the career opportunities are still at our headquarters in Cambridge although I know leadership is working to change that. 
3. Diversity is a challenge, many employees are young and share a similar worldview. It's part of our goals to change it, but will take time.

headline: It's like grad school with a paycheck
pros: LEARNING. co-workers, engaged leadership, resources, humble, self-aware, appropriately paranoid.
cons: It can be an echo-chamber, you can definitely feel the screws tightening on budgets as the whole company focuses more closely on the stock price.

headline: The greatest company I have ever worked for
pros: I could go on and on about all of the wonderful things that make HubSpot the best place I have ever worked, but I’ll try to be  as concise as possible: the company culture, transparent and communicative management, flexible and healthy work/life balance (+ unlimited PTO), autonomous yet collaborative working environment, exciting products that improve every day, constant opportunities for learning and growth, food/coffee/beer garden, & passionate colleagues who always value and strive for inclusion .
cons: Pay is on the lower side for some of the entry-level positions, but this is pretty standard. On the plus side, there is so much room & encouragement to grow within this organization that HubSpotters have many opportunities for upward mobility.

headline: Strong career growth
pros:
- The company is doing well and growing.... lots of opportunity to try new things and move up with hard work
- Transparency within the organization is real - not lip service. The amount of info we have as employees is empowering
- No micro-management. You have autonomy to do your job
- As a cherry on top - all the perks / benefits you'd want (gym, food, untracked time off, etc)
cons: - Growing super fast has its challenges too in terms of fast change but it's good for the business

headline: I've learned more @ Hubs than any other company I've worked at
pros:
-Scale-up growth = tons of opportunities to learn; you can lean in to the business and become an expert in the industry and/or your function, and be at the forefront of what we're building.
-Scale-up stage also means that there are processes in place, but there's also autonomy to execute on your own; you aren't micromanaged, but still have the support structures/guidance to help you get better at your job.
-Employees are fantastic and what sets the environment apart; they're across the board intelligent, driven, innovative, scrappy, and, unrelated, but everyone has a great sense of humor.
-Challenged every day; no two days are the same. Working here makes you agile. 
-Tons of resources available for you to explore and utilize. 
-Leadership cares about its employees and is receptive to feedback.
-Yes, there's a lot of hoorah about the Culture Code, but I see employees holding each other accountable to it; actions speak louder than words.
-Transparent from the top-down: we're looped in real time on business changes/decisions. The business and its employees take full ownership of mistakes we've made in the past, which helps us push forward and learn from them for the future. 
-The momentum is huge. A lot of people drink the kool-aid, but that's because we believe in what we're building and are excited about where the business is headed.
-Work/life balance is real. Get your *stuff* done and it'll never be an issue to take time off / WFH.
cons:
-Comp could be more competitive for the SaaS space.
-Some business units are prioritized over others (product, sales).
-POps lacks clear promotional paths compared to other departments.

headline: Couldn't fathom working anywhere else
pros: Exponential growth potential and trajectory of our suite of products, culture is hyper customer and employee centric, ton of opportunities to develop as an employee (whether that's our mini MBA program, taking a master class, tuition reimbursement, 1:1 coaching/feedback, moving to a new role internally or via promotion), huge amount of transparency from the top down which establishes trust in our Exec team, and a TON of autonomy and flexibility.
cons: HubSpot is very fast paced and extremely agile, which results in a high level of ambiguity and change. A priority today might change completely by next week, and the more resourceful and flexible you can be, the better. Also, since HubSpot promotes a lot from within, first time managers are common. You'll have to be comfortable articulating how you liked to be managed and offering as much guidance to your new manager as you'd receive from them.

headline: Software engineer
pros: relaxed working atmosphere, benefits, free food, work from home
cons: kids in management, getting calls 3AM when on call

headline: Amazing Place To Work!
pros:
Great Culture 
Amazing Benefits 
Work/Life Balance with unlimited holidays and work from home option
Great People! 
Opportunities to grow
cons: None at the moment

headline: A fast-paced company with Leadership who genuinely cares!
pros:
Caring and transparent Leadership Team
Everyone can contribute and the Leadership is open to listen to new ideas and suggestions
Great location
Focus on Inclusion and Belonging
You will feel challenged every day and you will learn something new every day
cons:
Pension is below industry standards
Fast paced environment and constant changes are not for everyone however if you  love being pushed outside your comfort zone it is the right place for you.

headline: A positive, inspiring place to work
pros: Like most tech companies, HubSpot has competitive pay, great benefits, and a fun work environment. But, to me, HubSpot is leaps and bounds ahead of similar companies because of its people. I've never worked anywhere with so many talented individuals that *genuinely* want each other to learn, grow, and succeed.
cons: We're growing *very* quickly, so there's always some concern that we'll lose what has made HubSpot so special. So far, our Chief People Officer & her team have done a fabulous job of helping us scale with care.

headline: The BEST!
pros: -People who challenge you and push you outside your comfort zone to make you a better person
cons: -Wish we were more data-driven

headline: Great flexibility, mediocre compensation
pros:
- Open forum for resource-sharing, giving and receiving feedback
- Unlimited PTO 
- Fast-paced and GSD mentality
- The opportunity to create your own projects and run with them with very little red tape
- Opportunities for career growth and development
cons: - Compensation is very low for the industry standard

headline: Expanding too fast with no proper structures in place
pros: Great team, great culture, great employee benefits, strict hiring process so that they usually weed out people who are all talk and no brains
cons: Culture is eroding fast due to rapid company expansion. No real growth opportunities. Work-life balance looks more like a metric to hit rather than actually caring about this balance. Employees forced to work back-to-back tasks non-stop all day and pressured to go home on time. A lot of burnout.

headline: Sales
pros: Lots to write here. The month-long new-hire onboarding is very intensive but a good bootcamp for learning about the company, the product, and the industry. As long as you are hitting you're number, you can enjoy the amenities of flexible work (remote). Their investment in building a culture team shows as an employee with numerous events at the office as well as after hours/weekends. My favorite part of working here was the learning - from colleagues as well as the Hub Talks where they bring in executives from other companies to share their story.
cons: In sales, it was a bit of an extra grind with monthly quotas which further amplified "what have you done for me lately" feeling. There would be pressure to oversell/force a sale too quickly at the expense of hitting a monthly number from your direct managers/directors at points. Managers also are overworked/spread too thin so the employees that work under them get limited development/coaching because their manager is often running around in meetings, interviews, etc... This in turn leads to the 1:1s to be about your forecast and spreadsheets and less on coaching and developing with deals. There was also a lack of development for reps wanting to move into manager roles - a lot of it is left to you with the expectation that you won't get a manager job until having interview several times.

headline: Remarkable Onboarding Experience
pros: After 6+ years at agencies, to say that I was nervous to start at HubSpot was an understatement. I was starting in a new role and in a brand new industry, but after my first day of training, I knew I had made the right decision. The onboarding experience was something I had never encountered before and made my transition comfortable. Beyond product training, thanks to my manager I had my own training and onboarding projects that set me up for success. I continue to learn each and every day at HubSpot and love working for a company that is so transparent, flexible and values each and every employee as individuals embracing their strengths and differences.
cons: It's truly up to each and every manager to set up new hires for success. The L&D team is fantastic with robust product training, but I'm not sure I would have felt so secure in my new role if I hadn't had the specific onboarding projects from my manager afterwards, so I would continue to encourage managers to put the effort into thinking about the best way to train new hires for specific roles to ensure success.

headline: Customer Success Manager
pros: Culture is great, people are awesome
cons: Gaps in management, not a direct path for career growth

headline: Great atmosphere and experience
pros: Great opportunities for growth and learning.
cons: very fast paced and not an environment everybody enjoys

headline: Great Sales Experience!
pros: Culture, great product, fabulous employees, great managers, good training's
cons: When there are no puppies in the office.

headline: Eager people
pros: great benefits, lax work culture
cons: very one minded type of person, not very diverse

headline: People are great, Pay is low
pros:
-people you work with are top notch
-there are a lot of opportunities to learn
-the company is growing fast
cons:
-internal promotions are paid significantly less than external hires
-support is not paid or treated fairly
-internal mobility is not as easy they make it seem

headline: Great
pros: Loved it culture, tech, blog, great product
cons: None there are none none none none

headline: Training is Unparalleled
pros: supportive environment, positive culture, and an amazing sales trainer Lauren that will give you ALL the resources you need to succeed
cons: hours can be long at the beginning (but it's worth it in the end)

headline: Great place to work! Great people to work with!
pros: People, flexibility, autonomy, opinions valued
cons: None that I can really think of, expectations are high but I think that's a good thing.

headline: Renewal Manager
pros: Great benefits and overall good place to work!
cons: No cons. This is a phenomenal place to work.

headline: Hands down the best company I've worked for!
pros: Every review is honestly true here. HubSpot is such an amazing company to work for. I've worked for quite a few and without a doubt it's the best. The people are great and you truly feel like you have a say and a voice. Every manager is very reasonable and understands that you have a life outside of work. Really flexible too for working.
cons: I'm not sure I can ever leave because I don't know if I'd find a better company and fit for me.

headline: Great IT environment will keep constrained to  work 365 Days
pros:
Great environment to work from anywhere and anytime
Sales swim lane are well organized unless you willing to stick on the path.
Unlimited vacation!
cons:
well organized vs inflexible ---no exception
 Life of chasing MRR

headline: BDR
pros: Super clear path to promotion - tons of resources available to empower you to succeed, unlimited PTO and can WFH any time - In general, as long as you get your work done, you can essentially do whatever you want! Awesome coworkers - everyone who works here is super smart and willing to help... friendly competition but never stepping on each other's toes.
cons: The tools are constantly growing and improving, sometimes it's hard to keep up! But  they always have trainings to help us stay on track

headline: Still great after 4+ years
pros: I've been at HubSpot now for almost 4 years and there's nowhere else I've even thought about working in that time. Why? HubSpot is a great place to work. I feel like I'm valued. I have a lot of autonomy in how and when and where I work. I feel strongly about the mission of the company. All in all, I'm extremely happy here.
cons: As the company grows, scaling communication and decision making becomes more difficult. Luckily, it's something that's top of mind for many people who are working to make communication easier and better.

headline: Hard work, outstanding opportunity
pros: If you're looking to challenge yourself and learn new things, HubSpot is an outstanding place to do so. The company is full of smart people who CARE, and it shows. Am excellent place for those who want the chance to go "above and beyond".
cons: There's a lot of disorganization and ambiguity - maybe even a little more than I expected coming into a fast-growing company like this. That can certainly be seen as an opportunity at times, but other times it can just be frustrating.

headline: Great personal and career development
pros:
- Incredible pace at product development and innovation, I've not seen a tech company until HubSpot that has product sprints going out on a DAILY basis. [Super important for any tech company to be ahead of the curve and thinking about setting the industry benchmark for what's next]

- Everything is in the Wiki. From the latest marketing experiments (which in my opinion, are pieces written 10x better than any you'd find on growthhackers.com), to the Management team's targets, focus, thoughts, and priorities. I can spend hours going down the rabbit hole in this encyclopedia of knowledge from the smartest people globally. There's best practices and playbooks all documented, learnings and experiences from individuals who've been there done that, that we recently needed to have someone's full time job as a Wiki Manager to organise this world of information.

- Culture. From projects working on diversity and inclusion, to ensuring that there are plentiful employee engagement activities, there's a lot of activities planned, if only you have time, bother to attend, show up, and engage in them.

- Learning. This spans not just your own job scope, but also personal development, and future career growth. There are just so much resources available to tap on, like taking Managerial lessons if you intend to be a Manager one day, to attending workshops like becoming a trusted advisor. Seriously, it doesn't get better than this. There's $5k tuition grant and a free Kindle books program. HubSpot really invests A LOT in educating employees to be the smartest of the lot. 

If you are looking for somewhere to stand, HubSpot is a giant. Anyone driven enough is invited to stand on its shoulders to look further than what one can on him/herself.
cons: One of the biggest cons of a big company is that there are cliques and silos formed within teams. Humans tend to gravitate toward similar people with similar experiences. One of the ways we deal with that is to play musical chairs and physically move people around at their desks so different teams get to be near each other.

headline: Growing Company with Potential for Personal Growth
pros: Great pay and benefits, flexible work hours, intelligent/hard working colleagues, and a great campus
cons: 401k match is low comparatively and work/life balance can be strained during busier periods

headline: How good can it really be? Short: Really good.
pros:
Every part of the interview process was extremely well thought out and honestly enjoyable from a candidate stand point. The team really puts the effort into understanding your baseline for Inbound and if a good fit after the initial video interview (worst, most awkward part for me) and phone screen  making sure the candidate is set up for success when talking to a hiring manager. 

You definitely get put through the gambit during the onsite portion. I spoke to three managers and two directors in 30 minute sequential meetings. All were great, but particularly the Service Director. It really wasn’t an interview after the first minute or two of talking to him. It was a conversation, and an insightful, engaging one at that. A++ 

From the minute you’re brought on, you have a huge wealth of freedom and autonomy to just get things.. done. Everyone deeply believes in the company and the product and I may have had one or the other in previous roles but rarely if ever both with other companies.  Definitely cool.
cons: Training can at times lack structure. There were times during the two week training you would come in, have a session for an hour and have a blank calendar the rest of the day. Perfectly fine if you use good judgement (hint) but you may struggle if you’re not used to building out your own day or if you learn best in traditional student-teacher dynamic.

headline: CSM
pros: It's a great place to work
cons: I have nothing negative to say.

headline: Amazing Company and Culture to work for!
pros:
-- Amazing Culture (HEART is a real thing at HubSpot)
-- Tons of flexibility with coming to the office and working from home
-- Amazing co-workers and excellent management staff
-- Great benefits and unlimited vacation!
cons: -- The only con that keeps me from giving this place a 5-stars, is the starting salary of $35,000 in Support.  This salary is well below industry standards, especially in a place with a high-cost of living like Boston.

headline: Great place to start your sales career, not much flexibility in the role
pros: Great team, managers invest in your career growth & learning, small team so you have lots of skill development & 1:1s, you have a great opportunity to learn the in's and out's of the product before you move up in the sales org
cons: Not much flexibility in the role like there is on every other team in HubSpot, not able to participate in a lot of HubSpot events/learning sessions because we are constantly manning the channels, sometimes you feel micromanaged, role gets tedious after 5 months because your day to day is the same (role is typically 8-10 months), no incentives even though this is a entry-level sales role.

headline: Awesome Company
pros: Great working environment, flexible schedule, option to work from home.
cons: I am still new and have not experienced any yet

headline: Super Culture, Fun Place to Work!
pros:
Encouraged to show autonomy
Rewarded for hard work
Not bureaucratic and really transparent
Feel part of the team!
cons: Work with international offices so time-difference can sometimes be an issue

headline: Best company, best team
pros:
- Career development and opportunities to grow 
- Company culture | Completely transparent 
- PEOPLE | I never met so many remarkable personalities that are at the same time so down to earth
(also a huge thank you to our daily catering ladies)
- Onboarding in the US couldn't be a better start
cons: - Dog policy only on Fridays maybe? ;)

headline: It's all true!
pros:
I'm honestly shocked and amazed how much I love my job and working for HubSpot.
The opportunity to train in the head office in the US was fantastic, you really get sucked into the culture (a word I hate, but it's true). I also made great friends with other HubSpotters
My team genuinely want me to succeed, they want me to do well for my benefit and theirs. 
Completely transparent, it's not just for show
Humility is hugely appreciated and desired in all people - and in turn, everyone you work with is a genuine &nice person. Coming from a marketing/advertising background where people and companies are quite fake HubSpot is a breath of fresh air. 
I actually like coming to work every day
cons: some extra HR info when starting around pay dates etc would be great, this isn't easily found on the company info tool, but this is a teeny critic - literally, the only thing I could think of!

headline: Best culture, best product, best team!
pros:
- Company´s culture
- Best Product
- Amazing team
- Carreer Development and training
cons:
- Dublin´s weather
- At the moment, nothing else

headline: BDR
pros: Good Atmosphere to be around
cons: Interview process don't care about the ones no selected

headline: Account Exec
pros: Amazing atmosphere, community and solution offering!
cons: Personally, I am from Connecticut so the 3 hour drive in a couple times a week is difficult.

headline: Too good to be true?
pros: I have been at HubSpot for nearly a year and I have held off writing a review because to be honest I have been waiting for what I thought was the inevitable slip of the gorgeous, attractive mask but if anything it has only got better and better! Honestly! I geniunely love getting up for my job, I adore the people I work with and finally I feel like I work in a company that looks at me like a human rather than a number. There are so many pros...the benefits (unlimited holidays isnt a myth?!?! Seriously.), the people, the facilities, the opportunities to grow, the different projects, the challenging yet fair environment, did I say the people (?) and most definitely the support of management. A senior management team that actually listens?! Who knew?! I am so proud to work at HubSpot and from this cynic to the cynic reading this in a job where you are stressed out of your mind, there is light at the end of the tunnel just keep going! Times are changing in Ireland and I am so glad that I work in a company that I think are leading the way :)
cons: There is a really really sharp learning curve that can be totally overwhelming but in fairness management are realistic, fair and they listen - actively listen. I work in Support and the starting pay is not great but there are loads of opportunities to grow within the company - mainly outside of Support however.

headline: Great experience
pros: The company culture is amazing and there are many perks to make the out-of-work life good as well
cons: I don't have too much to say that's negative

headline: Great place to progress your sales career
pros:
Completely results driven promotion structure - if you perform you get promoted period.  Typically use to the politics behind in-line promotions from other sales organizations so it's a breath of fresh air to know if you bring value to the company, are a high-producer and a good person to work with you will be rewarded.

I really love the people I work with.. we higher on culture really well and i've seen fantastic sales people not hired as they weren't seen as culture fits.

Unlimited leave and solid balance on work/life balance

Very flat structure - exposure and access to Execs is very easy

One of the most transparent organizations ever, the humility of the C-suite, the regular candid posts and communications on both wins/losses is just amazing considering the size of our org

Top class inside-sales training, you spend a lot of time overseas in product training and have regular training after you come back as well. Once you return you have a senior sales rep to shadow and you are also put on a lengthy "ramp" to get you ready for a full quota.

Regular sales competitions with equity, cash, travel prizes

The product/vision is something you can really get behind if you are passionate about helping businesses grow
cons:
HubSpot has traditionally hired a certain type that really want to over-perform - but this has resulted at times in a sales org that doesn't take as many breaks as necessary. We have unlimited leave (completely paid for) but not as many people feel OK to take it .

Very sales driven org and have seen examples of a top sales rep get away with a lot more discrepancies then typically would be allowed. Really reminded me that results can matter more then doing the right thing but this was the only time I have been disappointed by management.

You have to be either really talented or work very hard when you first begin to do well- a lot of our sales managers are either new or promoted from top senior reps which means they can't teach to sell the solution yet or they are only just learning how to manage people. Expect to pick things up quickly or rely on senior sales reps.

headline: Sales Positions Should be Called "Creative Outreach Rep"
pros: Dogs in the office, food, beer, lots of young employees (feels like college)
cons: The Business Development role and Inbound Growth Specialist role are more so a "creative outreach role."  Almost all training revolves around just getting someone on the phone.  The best performing BDR's were promised a promotion in 10 months but it really ends up being at least 13.  I don't think the product was that good and Corporate Sales is a failing segment.  DO NOT work in the corporate segment at HubSpot.

headline: GREAT interview process and GREAT place to work
pros: Holly, the recruiter I worked with, was absolutely amazing! She went above and beyond throughout my interview process and was very helpful. I also loved training. We were asked to do a new hire project which was challenging but it got me comfortable with HubSpot's tools and solutions. Product training and the new hire project were my favorite parts of training. I have been with the company for a few months now and I love what I sell, I have a supportive/knowledgeable manger, and I love the people I work with. I feel like I have the tools/resources to effectively do my job and hit my number.
cons: I can't think of any!

headline: Dream come true!
pros: It took me three tries to get a job here - totally worth it. Now that I'm here, I can see why the interview process is so selective - literally EVERY single individual is hyper focused on their work and passionate about what they do.  Awesome office, fun benefits #somuchswag
cons: Pressure to work late a lot - can't remember the last time I only worked 40 hours in a week. Not pressure from HubSpot - but because all of your coworkers work a ton, it feels like you need to too.

headline: Awesome place to work at!  Come join us!
pros:
Transparency. 
Passionate about growth 
Remarkable 
Energetic 
Smart people
cons: None that I can think of right now

headline: Life in Sales @ HubSpot Sydney
pros:
Good place to work for, great benefits and recently fixed pay so you can expect to be happy from a compensation perspective. 

If you’re a high achiever, expect good stock incentives, commission and international travel perks, some of the best I have seen. 

You can expect some fairly good flexibility when it comes to taking extended holidays, time off and working away, depending on the manager. 

Really good senior leadership outside of ANZ, although you don’t get to meet a lot of them, expect to still be guided by smart people. 

When leaders do respect you, they do everything they can to help your career at HubSpot. It’s a great atmosphere in that sense. 

You will have a crazy amount of people who want to talk to you and love HubSpot. In order to win here, expect to work hard and smart, be a great at telling stories and have a consultive sales approach.
cons:
Hubspot ANZ focuses too much on internal hiring, which naturally results in the wrong people for the job. HubSpot does a really bad job at sourcing for managers externally, some of the worst I have come across. 

Expect your manager to be incredibly green / new and rely on good reps to mentor you.  If you expect the manager to guide you, you will fail in this setting as you will feel like you’re teaching them how to manage people. This could change in the future, however is a current pain in the office. Managers come in with no training, so in a way you can’t blame them, but just be mindful of this. 

Working flexibility arrangements aren’t the same in ANZ, so be careful about reading the culture code and expecting the same in our office, because it won’t be. This is the same for reps at 70% of target or 150% of target, so don’t expect to be a high achiever and have more flexibility. 

It’s a very young office, so you will need to be okay with heaps of banter, silly chats and young people. I don’t mind this but you will need to be aware of this culture. Average age is probably 24-26.

You might complain about culture, or fill out our quarterly ENPS to give feedback. Expect nothing to be actioned, but constantly here “we’re working on how we can improve this”.  My 2 cents is that because everyone is so green, they don’t know where to start.

headline: BDR
pros: Great company name and recognition
cons: Not as great of an experience as I thought

headline: Inside Sales Account Executive
pros:
- Good Culture
- Fast Paced
- Good benefits / perks
cons: The company has become essentially a frat house. No diversity when it comes to age groups, they simply want to hire the youngest people they can exploit. Unfortunately, the interview process when you eventually get through is a nightmare. They have the most drawn out interview process in the world, and make you jump through so many hoops only to earn a below market salary. They can do this because they make up for it with the culture, but compensation is poor in comparison to what they expect at the interview stage. This shows there is some delusion from the hiring team in thinking this is actually acceptable behavior.

headline: Great place to work - wouldn't want to leave my team
pros: Amazing culture, great learning and opportunity to grow
cons: The waiting time for the free lunch is sometimes a bit long

headline: Product Analyst
pros: nice people; supportive environment; relaxed atmosphere
cons: could have a higher 401k contribution

headline: You Don't Know How Good It Is Until You've Been Elsewhere
pros:
Strong leadership
Innovative
Not afraid to do the hard things in the spirit of doing right by customers
cons: Some mediocre middle management slip through the cracks, overall, not too much to be unhappy about.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great office, flexible working hours, great perks, great autonomy for teams, great people to work with, great place to learn and grow. Great product!
cons:
The food provided (breakfast and lunch) is really not good, I feel like I'm eating low-cost student food for a long time now. I feel like the free food is more like a marketing thing, to attract people, but once you start working there you realise it would be way better to have a slightly higher salary and no food at all.

Especially if we're trying to compare with Google, Facebook, LinkedIn, Intercom, ... HubSpot needs to realise that having free food in Dublin is not really a perk any more

headline: Don't fall for the hype. HubSpot is not what it appears on Glassdoor.
pros: There is an unlimited vacation policy.
cons: To candidates out there: don't pursue this job. The Support department's management is disorganized and either unable or unwilling to advocate for the team. They look for hard working young people excited about the company that will take on endless amounts of work and don't yet have the experience to know to speak up for themselves about how messed up things are here.

headline: Loving It
pros: Unlimited PTO, great work life balance, plenty of resources for you at your disposal.
cons: 401 K can be better supported

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Extremely smart and innovative people. Always a challenging environment. A seemingly limitless TAM. The transparency from the executive team is the best I’ve been around, and the passion of the staff is unmatched.
cons: Humility is hard to find, and there is a certain arrogance associated with HubSpot. Was a great place to work, but the Kool-Aid is really strong there.

headline: HubSpot is the best!
pros:
Incredible company, employees, managers, and customers.
Great benefits and outstanding culture.
cons: Can't think of any at the moment.

headline: Customer Support
pros: The culture is what makes HubSpot so great! And being surrounded by incredibly intelligent people who are so down to Earth at the same time!
cons: It's a fast-paced environment, so if you're not in tune to what's going on around you, it can be easy to fall behind - more of a challenge than a con.

headline: Great culture, great perks
pros: HubSpot is absolutely THE best place to work at, especially if you're in marketing. People are absolutely brilliant and there's just so much you can learn from them.
cons: The company still has a "start-up"-like vibe. Things change quite often (sometimes too often)  so it's hard to be consistent. It's also very stressful.

headline: Sales
pros: Fast-paced always helping mentality.
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Beware of Manager Abuses
pros: The company offers an incredible culture and worklife balance.
cons: The company allows a lot of manager abuses to take place and go unchecked. Depending on the group you are in, this isn't a place to truly grow your career unless you're willing to spend significant time.

headline: If you want to be in tech sales, work here.
pros:
- Brian and Dharmesh are amazing leaders, with a great vision, open to feedback and transparent. 
- An amazing product, and great product fit for the market. The sky is the limit. 
- The culture is real, we walk the walk. 
-
cons: - Sales training/managementtraining can use improvement, but they have heard us loud and clear and are working on it.

headline: Properly looks after their employees
pros: After coming from a position in a highly bureaucratic company, joining Hubspot was like a breath of fresh air. You're setup and productive on day one, with everyone going out of their way to be friendly and supportive. I've been working for nigh on 10 years in the tech industry, and this place is without doubt the best yet. Like Google without the hubris and snobbery!
cons: The only cons are the ready availability of snacks and treats, it's quite difficult to resist things like waffles.

headline: Implementation Specialist
pros: Great culture and team support
cons: Commuting from my home was difficult

headline: Awesome. Period.
pros: Between the free snacks/beer and the gym, I have everything I need at the office. Culture is catered to everyone and the company outlook is great.
cons: It is a pretty competitive culture in the sales org, so if you are not ready to share your performance on a daily basis over lunch...it may be a bit awkward for you.

headline: Very ambitious organisation with the resources and team to achieve their goals
pros:
*The company is on a fast growth trajectory
*Management truly want to make the company the best place to work
*Management have a track record of making the tough decisions to improve the company and address challenges to continue their growth without compromising  on making HubSpot a good place to work.
* Change is constant
cons:
*Change is constant
*Short term property decisions, We keep outgrowing our office, lets get a home to grow into,  not out of
*Pension scheme is still towards the bottom of the market even after a small increase in 2016. In Ireland its one of the few tax benefits the government allows PAYE workers so its a missed opportunity.

headline: Sales
pros: Excellent company - I learned loads working there.
cons: Not many but sometimes the Dublin office felt a little separate to Boston. Which was good and bad.

headline: Email Deliverability
pros: Great company. Everyone has a do-shit-attitude
cons: Sometimes we bight off more than we can chew. Projects are abandoned.

headline: Email Deliverability
pros: Great company. Everyone has a do-shit-attitude
cons: Sometimes we bight off more than we can chew. Projects are abandoned.

headline: Numbers Matter and People Do Too
pros:
Action-Oriented: When something needs to get done, we get stuff done
People Matter: You are valued as a human before an employee.  The benefits are good, and they are becoming great.
Availability: Leadership and management is both transparent and available.  The best ability is availability.
cons:
Quickly Changing: In a start-up to scale-up, changes are inevitable and often.  You have to be able to adapt - I like it, some won't.
Work-life balance: Especially getting started, it's pretty difficult to manage your time, feel prepared and also enjoy life outside of work.  You'll put in the time early.

headline: Partnerships
pros: Diverse backgrounds. Culture of autonomy and trust.
cons: Too early to assess, but nothing stands out so far.

headline: Tons of Opportunity
pros: Great company vision and leadership team in place to execute. Bright future ahead
cons: There is a lack of accountability in sales org, see below in advice to management

headline: Enjoying my time here!
pros: work and social balance, kitchen
cons: as of now, none yet

headline: Things could have been better
pros: it is a nice product to work with and the customers were an absolute pleasure to work with
cons:
Some teams are slightly young and immature
management in some teams need to work on people management skills
some things are too organised and some are less organised such as processed and procedures
i believe that there needs to be a better strategy when it comes to customer retention and providing good customer experience

headline: Great Experience
pros: Great Culture, Hire excellent people
cons: Lack of career growth available

headline: HubSpot is great but be prepared to work hard
pros: Great people, great culture and facilities. Always something new and exciting to work on.
cons: This isn't a con, but life moves fast at HubSpot and it's employees are predominantly under 35 which isn't always for everyone

headline: Positive onboarding and ramping up process
pros: Great people, organized onboarding, well structured job role, good benefits.
cons: Haven't found them yet! Although no company's perfect, HubSpot seems to be trying pretty hard to get as close as it can.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: The engineering department does everything they can to set you up for success. There are so many people that are willing to go the extra mile to help you grow and improve as an engineer.
cons: There are some people who say that the work life balance isn't the best. I definitely agree that some of the core teams work a lot, but I think that those teams are the minority .

headline: So Much Opportunity to Learn
pros: There is always so much going on and so many opportunities to learn. HubSpot is fast-paced and always trying new initiatives, which means there is a lot of opportunity to get involved in those initiatives. Future plans are shared from the top and there is always a positive energy around what is coming next. It is a great place to learn business strategy and be involved in decision making that will have a material impact. The perks are also great, but the best part of working here is definitely the day-to-day substance of our work.
cons: Very metric-driven, which is important, but it can sometimes feel like we are so focused on data that we are looking at data just for the sake of data.

headline: I'm glad I took the opportunity
pros:
The Pay
The People - HubSpot tends to hire great staff
The Culture
One of the coolest offices I have ever worked in
cons:
Work/Life balance
Tends to promote managers based solely on sales performance as a rep

headline: Amazing to work for
pros: Really care about employees !
cons: Cant think of any right now

headline: This isn't just a company or a job. It's a culture and a lifestyle!
pros: Perks perks perks! What's not to love about the autonomy you get in this company? Everyone here is smart enough that the one policy "Use Good Judgement" doesn't get broken. That means free beer, unlimited vacation days, pets in the office, food galore!
cons: As the company continues to grow at a rapid pace, you begin to feel lost in a crowd of unfamiliarity. People who aren't as social or extroverted may begin to feel a little overwhelmed.

headline: Incredible to be a part of it
pros:
* Super smart colleagues
* Everyone wants to help 
* Crazy degree of knowledge you learn in a short period of time
* Potential for growth
cons:
* High school "clicky" vibe at times
* Tough work/life balance

headline: HubSpot
pros: they have an unlimited vacation policy
cons: The low salary does not match competitors

headline: Great company. Great people.
pros:
Worked at HubSpot for just under 5 years, before making a move to take on a bit more risk working at a startup. Everything about HubSpot is great. You have the opportunity to switch roles pretty easily, try out new things, and always be learning. 

Pay is competitive and the benefits are great. Benefits are definitely something that I miss now making the move to a smaller company. 

Still very connected to a lot of friends from HubSpot - people are awesome.
cons: Over my time at HubSpot - the internal politics definitely turned into something that was a little annoying, but not surprising for a company that grew from 100 to 2000 in my time there.

headline: Great company
pros: Great company - face paced learning environment and great team
cons: Career growth opportunities and office politics

headline: Amazing place to work
pros:
- In scale up mode so you get to push yourself further than in most companies, and you get to take on a lot of responsibility
- amazing work colleagues - smart, talented and some of the nicest people I have ever met
- The culture is really special - the company works hard to create and maintain such a great environment and culture but it shows. It is one of the most inspirational cultures I have ever worked in.
