cons: None that I can think of... I have never seen a company that genuinely cares about its employees so much. And if you hire really smart people, treat them really well, give them interesting work to do... bingo... the company does really well!

headline: Sales
pros: Good place to work. Good people.
cons: None, best time ever, great product.

headline: Great first stop for a software engineering career
pros: Strong mentoring culture, autonomy, transparent leadership
cons: Culture variance between engineering teams,  Very young tech leads and managers in some cases

headline: Great environment but can be unrewarding
pros:
- Talented and friendly colleagues.
- Management are very open to hearing your concerns and genuinely try to improve things
- The whole business is very transparent - anything you want to know about how the business works is available to you.
- A good place for talented grads
cons:
- Career progress can be slow, it feels like you get stuck at a level.
- No matter how much they dress it up, you're building marketing automation software and that can be a bit unrewarding.
- Hard to have an impact on a 300+ person engineering org as an engineer
- Experience outside of HubSpot doesn't count once you get in the door - that can make the environment a bit frustrating for experienced engineers.

headline: Technical Lead
pros: Tons of autonomy. If you are smart and driven you can both make an impact and grow a ton as an engineer. There are teams working across a wide spectrum of initiatives and opportunities to move around. The focus is on results, which is something you have a lot of control over.
cons: There are at times some growing pains, as HubSpot is constantly growing quickly and needing to adapt. We don't always get it right, but the management cares a lot is always looking to improve.

headline: Love it here
pros:
I'm a big fan of our mission to help SMB's grow by taking advantage of the internet.  That's something that gets me motivated to work hard.

I like my colleagues.  They are smart, fun, and committed.  I have many belly laughs per day.

I like the perks -- work from home, bring your dog to work, unlimited vacation, sabbatical, transparent decision making, etc.

I like being on a winning team.
cons: Its hard work.  You gotta bring your A game and be good.

headline: This is what I've been searching for
pros:
I've worked in the software industry in the northeast for more than a decade, and while I've been successful there's always been something missing. At HubSpot I feel like I've finally found what I've been looking for (take that, U2). I know that sounds like a big statement but everything I've seen in engineering aligns so perfectly with the values I've practiced and preached, from the top of the stack to the bottom. I don't want to bore you to death with an essay, but here are some of the things that really stand out:

* The technical talent on the team is amazing. I've worked with brilliant engineers in the past, but the consistent level of intelligence, capability, and competence here is impressive.

* The passion the entire team gives and the pride they take in what we're doing is such a motivator and inspiration. I've read the same stuff you have about the 'cult'; it couldn't be farther from the truth. This is hard working people taking pride in what they've accomplished.

* The lack of bureaucracy and process is so refreshing. It's focused on Just Effing Doing It instead of endlessly debating and needing sign-off from eighty nine different levels. This can definitely take some getting used to because leadership is largely just sketching a very rough outline and everyone else is not only filling it in, but erasing the lines and redrawing as they see fit. It can sometimes feel like we're veering around a bit, but leadership does a fantastic job of catching that just as it's beginning to show signs of a problem and correcting it.

* I didn't realize how much the politicking at my old company was affecting me until I came to a place where... well... it doesn't happen. There's a real lack of kingdom building or ladder climbing - and instead it's very much a bottoms-up mentality with a focus on what you've done and not how well you play the game.

* Competence and excellence are recognized and rewarded. It's not about who you know or what group you're in; if you do awesome stuff it's seen and celebrated. I was so tired of needing to brown nose to get ahead. Here I've told my boss to his face he was wrong, or that I disagreed with our leadership, or that I was going to do something and didn't care what he thought, and rather than being smacked down I was thanked for pushing for what I knew was right.

* The culture here is Absolutely. Fantastic. There's an commitment to employee satisfaction that they really do take seriously. There are regular satisfaction surveys, we have people dedicated to making it an enjoyable place to work, the company's very willing to spend money on things that could be considered frivolous - like team lunches, or trivia nights - and any tool you need to do your job better is essentially yours. I'm not naive enough to think that this is all altruism, but it definitely feels like the company cares about us as people. And what's more, that belief and focus is practiced and felt at all levels, by everyone here.

I know that all this sounds too good to be true or like I'm a soulless shill, but I couldn't be happier with my decision to move here. If you're looking for a place that dispenses with the crap, does awesome things, hires amazing talent, and treats its employees with respect and kindness you could do a hell of a lot worse than HubSpot. I'm looking forward to many more years here.
cons:
This isn't a place that caters to passivity. If you're looking for a lot of hand-holding or you need structure in order to be successful then this really isn't for you. Our entire philosophy is based around small, very technical, autonomous teams, and that requires those teams to be extremely self-driven and self-directing. There's plenty of help if you ask, but if you're expecting someone to give your formal requirements, document the steps you should follow, or shepherd you through your day-to-day you're going to be sorely disappointed. We want passionate, driven, opinionated people who aren't going to sit back and let someone else make all the decisions.

Our lack of structure and process is almost a negative, and I'll be the first to admit we probably need a little bit more. We're growing rapidly but we don't do an amazing job of defining defaults that lead people to the right solutions, which means every new tech lead or engineer has to figure a lot out for themselves. I think we could stand to do a better job structuring things (just a tiny bit more!) so that people fall into success more easily.

headline: Great place for both new and seasoned engineers.
pros:
- IMPACT!!!
- You will be pushed hard on interesting projects.
- Smart, hardworking people to work with and learn from.
- Immense amount of trust put in you on Day 1.
- Tons of investment in platform and tooling, allowing developers to move fast.
- Plush office & fun events
cons: No job is perfect, but I can't think of anything unique to HubSpot.

headline: BEST job I've ever had
pros: I'm surrounded all day by brilliant, thoughtful, and ambitious people. Collaboration and ideas from the very bottom of the chain is not only accepted but highly encouraged - I've always felt like HubSpot genuinely values my ideas and seeks them. Everyday I am challenged to learn new skills and continue growing with the company. Couldn't recommend this HubSpot enough, it's easily the best place to work in this industry!
cons: None come to mind, I'm very happy here

headline: Flexibility and Faith in Leadership - A+
pros: Extremely flexible schedule. I work from home once a week and feel fully supported and connected with the team. Great collaboration tools. Office facilities are top notch and great perks (coffee garden, with a TEA BOT, snacks, beer, etc.). Benefits are great.
cons: 401k match could be better. There are some typical office politics but especially with the PeopleOps team which is a little concerning since they are the folks you are supposed to go to when problems arise. That being said, I still fully believe in HubSpot and love working here.

headline: Ideal environment for rapid, challenging personal growth
pros:
- Clear, compelling mission to help small businesses around the world grow and control their own destiny
- "Root for the underdog" mentality
- Results-oriented environment where risk taking is encouraged and rewarded
- Extremely strong peer group
- Terrific customers whose lives we can meaningfully and visibly impact
- Competitive compensation
- Work/life flexibility (may depend on the role, but lots of work-from-home, remote, unconventional work patterns are often fine - unlimited vacation which generally seems to amount to a slightly generous normal vacation allowance)
cons:
- High growth means high pressure
- Tendency to focus on where we are weak/failing which can be exhausting at times
- Depending on the department your job can change meaningfully over the course of even a year (or faster) and it can be hard to get in a groove

headline: The Most Racist Professional Experience Ever
pros: Kitchen, Gym, Technology, Entertainment, Meditation Room
cons:
This is my second time writing a review about HubSpot because I was coerced into removing my criticisms by a third party.  Instead of contacting me about my concerns as a former employee, HubSpot decided to reach out to someone that is tangentially connected to this situation for feedback on an experience that he knows nearly nothing about.  HubSpot epitomizes what is wrong with the world today and is a remarkable example of modern day discrimination, cultural insensitivity, institutionalized racism, implicit white bias and income inequality.   

Martin Luther King, Jr. once wrote that "most whites in America proceed from a premise that equality is a loose expression for improvement."  I stand by my belief that HubSpot is not diverse in the faintest sense.  After having to defend my initial ANONYMOUS post, I actually think that my original grade for effort on diversity of a C is too generous and an F is more appropriate.  Their 2016 numbers speak or themselves, they're 85% white. 

I was uncomfortable being the only black individual in a new hire cohort of 50+ people.  My manager triggered stereotype threat with her poor word choice in our one-on-one check-ins.  She made culturally insensitive remarks and didn't care about how her management was disrupting my learning experience.  I was progressively profiled and given exit papers over the course of three weeks, which makes me wonder why I wasn't interviewed more thoroughly.   Firing someone during on-boarding is essentially condemning their learning style.  

The CEO's personal commitment to diversity is not permeating the organization in a meaningful way.

headline: Been here 2 years, I doubt I'll leave any time soon
pros: Hands down its the best place I've ever worked
cons: Young engineering org so sometimes my team members don't understand the needs of a family but the org gets its and provides a lot of family support

headline: Sales Trainer
pros: An absolutely fantastic work environment.  Very inclusive, great work life balance and wonderful coworkers.  There is plenty of room for growth and I love the opportunities for cross-collaboration across departments.  I'd recommend Hubspot to anyone.
cons: Due to the size of Hubspot, it can feel very large at times.

headline: Truly the best environment!
pros:
Unlimited vacation
Flexible working (remote work)
Dog friendly
Great training program
cons: None to be seen so far!

headline: Amazing Place to work!
pros: Absolutely awesome culture- yes the perks are fantastic (on-site barista,  on-site gym, free snacks, unlimited PTO, etc) but the people, the transparency, the value on the employees and building teamwork, and arming employees with the tools to make them successful are just a few reasons why people love working here.  I've worked in a number of companies up to this point, and I've never felt more like a company actually values me and my contribution than they do here. Everyone who works here is super smart everyone is incredibly passionate about what they do. The energy here is infectious and I absolutely can't wait to see what happens next
cons: I've only been here a short time, so I don't have anything to note regarding cons.

headline: The Culture Isn't Just a PR Play
pros:
Before I joined I was skeptical about the culture and perks being a ploy to mask a less-than-ideal place to work (as is the case with lots of companies) but HubSpot really delivers on its promise of a fantastic culture. 

What most people are most attracted to (unlimited vacation etc.) is actually not what keeps me in my job. I get to work with the best group of people, both here in Sydney and all over the world in our other offices. I have a fantastic manager who pushes me to achieve things I never thought I could (or rather that I never *think* I can, until I look back and see how far I've come).

The Sydney office has a particularly special thing going on. Amazing people, tons of fun, but serious about the goals we have and all the hard work it's going to take us to get there.
cons:
HubSpot is full of super talented, ambitious people and it can be easy to feel like you're not good enough (imposter syndrome is at an all-time high working here!) 

I find my work-life balance has ups and downs. Sometimes I'm flat out and all I think about is work, but on the flipside, I never get downtrodden by it as I have the best team and we're all in it together. The fact I'm able to manage my own schedule (when I work, and where I work) with no questions asked really helps too, as even when things are crazy, I can still fit my job around the rest of my life.

headline: The best people I've worked with in my life.
pros:
* Amazing people that care and are a joy to work with.
* Fast growth creates great opportunities.
* Invests in culture and people better than any company I know.
cons: They will challenge you and push you. They're big believers in constant learning. They'll give you an uncomfortable level of autonomy -- which makes it an intense place.

headline: 18 months in, time to leave a review!
pros:
Transparency and the vision of senior management.  Great to work for a place where you can really believe in the direction senior management is taking.  

I highly recommend HubSpot to anyone looking for a new job regardless of the role.
cons: Sometimes can hire/promote young managers that don't have enough business experience.

headline: Top company in Dublin
pros:
Smart smart people
Amazing facilities (thanks for the seperated recycling EVERYWHERE and addition to pre-packed sandwiches and salads for those working late )
Plenty of activities like yoga, cycling, football if thats your thing
Completely transparent, I know whats going on in product, finance and marketing ahead of the curve and I work in sales
The amount I've learned in a year and a half is hard to comprehend
Compensation is what you'd expect from a leading tech company, lots of bonuses and prizes up for grabs too
cons:
We work hard, that may or not be your thing
An always on culture, but a lot of that is self inflicted 
Work remote/from home is on a team by team basis and some get more leeway than others. I know this is something we're working on but flexibility is a serious plus

headline: Great place to work
pros:
- Wonderful company culture
- Talented workforce 
- Performance is valued over experience
- Opportunities for internal career progression
- You are trusted, and given a lot of autonomy 
- Compensation
cons: Growing pains involved with a scale-up company.

headline: A strong engineering culture
pros:
HubSpot has a great engineering culture. There is a strong platform for engineers to focus on building great software instead of infrastructure. The heavy investment in the platform team makes HubSpot a joy to work for.

HubSpot also has talented engineers who are patient and willing to mentor. I've been impressed with the breadth and depth of work HubSpot engineers have mastered.
cons: It doesn't always feel like there's strong buy-in on getting a project across the finish line, which leads to some project churn.

headline: Best place to work
pros: Smart, humble product team, great management, very transparent
cons: Too much orange everywhere.

headline: Great place for Software Engineers
pros:
- HubSpot doesn't just hire geniuses (like Google), they hire people who can and do talk to one another and make work fun. I hang out with my coworkers outside of work, because I actually like them.

- There is so much opportunity to make an impact

- Being B2B means that our users are using this software day in and day out and running their businesses on HubSpot, which gives you a lot more reason to care about the customers vs working someplace like Facebook

- People are generally automonous with the right level of communication

- Meetings are kept to be as few as possible, as few people as possible, as little time as possible, as productive as possible, so there is plenty of developer time and no time spent in unneccessary meetings

- People work around 40 hours a week, NOT 50-60

- No the unlimited vacation doesn't mean you can just not come to work, but it also doesn't mean you can't take time off. People take more time off on average than companies with a fixed amount of PTO. I'd rather not have to save up time off just in case I need it than have my leftover PTO paid out when I leave.

- Working from home is not frowned upon

- Upper management is transparent

- It never gets boring because we never get complacent, everything is always changing, growing, moving forward

- No deductible on health insurance
cons: Everything I can think of to put here is things other people might not like, like all the change and fast pace, but I don't see that as a con myself

headline: Highly Recommend
pros: What you hear about the culture at HubSpot is real- it's an incredible place to work. The high level of transparency from the leadership team allows me to walk in the door every day excited to help our customers grow their businesses with the software (not to mention think critically about our own business challenges as we scale). I highly recommend the experience of working/collaborating/learning with the HubSpot team.
cons: There can be long hours - but there is flexibility to work remote.

headline: Never a dull moment
pros: I've been here a while now and have really enjoyed my time here. Every quarter or year there are new challenges that my coworkers and I are eager to solve. It's fascinating watching the entire company change year over year.
cons: The culture and daily life is somewhat opinionated (documented well by the Culture Code presentation). There are always tradeoffs and HubSpot is no different.

headline: Account Executive
pros: The chance to work with like minded individuals and some of the most intelligent and  driven colleagues one could hope to work alongside.
cons: Work/life balance on the sales team is weak even with no vacation policy given high sales quotas and expectations on culture participation.

headline: There's always a bad side.
pros:
A lot of great people working really hard.
Amazing expansion and yet feels like an small company.
Great culture (on paper).
Good benefits.
Amazing facilities - it does make your job easier.

If you're part of the company where people live, work by the company's culture deck, congrats you must be having the time and experience of your live. If any of the cons below sounds a bit familiar, move within or out of the company, seeing those things in 2017 is not worth it.
cons:
Subtle misogyny and sexism exists. It's saddening things like:

"Be careful on what you write on interview reviews, European candidates can request transcripts", and those emails are not talking about confidential information but about language, disguised sexist jokes.

I've seem post-interviews starting with: let's hire the attractive one to boost moral.
Jokingly comments like: Be impartial even though girls are not you thing - directed to a male employee.

Upper management acting inappropriately towards other employee, making suggestive (and highly questionable) comments on private subjects.

It's not rare to hear comments like "That's how that person is" or " They do a great job, it was just a silly comment", when things like the ones above described come up in conversations.

It's conflicting and infuriating to see a lot of people playing along (power/hierarchy situation) makes one wonder: are they trying to survive or is this just how they truly are?

headline: A great mix of fun, culture and hard work.
pros:
Great salaries, especially for the Dublin area
Great perks including free lunch and education grants
Nice relaxed offices 
Interesting and talented workforce
Great remote working policies
Very family centric and work life balance focussed
cons: I haven't found any, not just saying that.

headline: Great place to grow your career
pros: Autonomy, Mentorship, Small Teams, Strong leadership, engineering focus, Growing quickly
cons: None for me.  Some might that teams have too much autonomy, that the pace is a bit quick, or that the team is a bit young (average age is 28), but I like it.  Also, a small percentage of people have been here for more than 5 years, though those people tend to have a lot of influence.

headline: Consultant
pros:
Great place to work! The people are the best - very friendly and ready to help you. I work on the consulting side, and I love it. The product itself is incredible and is always being improved and grown.  An awesome place to learn - cannot stress enough how much I have grown in my two years. Oh, also the benefits are amazing!! The culture team is fantastic and always has events and great opportunities. 

Come here if you have HEART!
cons:
It is a big company, and if you are in an international office then you could feel disconnected from HQ in Cambridge.  HubSpot is also always changing, which I like, but I know constant change is not for everyone. There is also a big push for greater diversity, but the company is still not very diverse. I know it is a priority for the leadership team, but the lack of diversity is a con. 

Another con is compensation - salary is less than competitors.

headline: Scaling up is hard to do
pros:
Benefits 
People
Dog-friendly office
Lots of snacks and food
cons:
Managers are inexperienced
Internal mobility is difficult
Ego driven culture
Inconsistency among teams and how they're managed

headline: Great place to thrive as a high performer
pros:
If you're dedicated and self-motivated, you'll do very well at HubSpot. It's not and never will be a place to blend into the scenery. You've got to do more than your job description and be eager and proud to do so, and I think that's where the "drink-the-kool-aid" comments come from. As you'll see, I'm solidly not that, but I love HubSpot, warts and all, and I firmly believe that the company has nowhere to go but up.

I've seen people go from zero to near-C-level in under two years here. Is that everyone? Of course not. HubSpot absolutely means it when they say you can be a high-performing individual contributor your entire career (I am one). But for people who want to move up the org chart, and have the chops to do so, HubSpot absolutely provides the framework and the support to give someone that chance.

The perks are nice. Beer and unlimited vacation and a barista and all that good stuff is nice, but it's actually secondary. Because we have those perks, it means we only have people who can have those perks and not abuse them. The caliber of the "average" HubSpotter is anything but average. Every single HubSpotter has something to learn from and be impressed by.
cons:
Remarkably few. One, because HubSpot is willing to take risks on people and helps them move up the ranks, people sometimes do get promoted before they're ready for it. There's nothing more demotivating than a bad manager, and I've seen entire teams underperform for months while a bad manager is either coached or replaced. I'm not sure there's an easy fix here. On the whole, it's a good thing that HubSpot gives those people those chances. There probably needs to be more guardrails and mentoring around this to identify where a newbie manager is potentially having cascading negative effects.

Second, and this one is some tough love from me, but it needs to be said: You need to toe the line on some things. If you're politically conservative, keep it to yourself. If you're liberal, preach it from the rooftops. HubSpot, for all its diversity and inclusion efforts (which are admirable!), does not allow for certain political viewpoints to be shared at all, and certainly not respected. On the one hand, it's not surprising that the majority of the company is more liberal. However, the Women@HubSpot and LGBTQ Alliance use Hillary Clinton campaign slogans in their "official" materials. I get it, I'm solidly liberal, and I don't think it's done with any sort of malice, but I've seen people basically shouted down and degraded for expressing any view that isn't solidly on the left side of our political spectrum. I know a few conservative folks at HubSpot, and I know for a fact they fear for their careers to even engage in debate on certain issues. It's never good for anyone to feel silenced, and in this manner, it's happening here. It's a glaring dark spot on HubSpot's supposed openness, and it needs to change. I am sure that it will in time, but it's something to be aware of if you are in that set and are considering HubSpot to work for right now. Hopefully in a few years, this won't be the case.

headline: Great place to work. Seriously.
pros:
There's a reason HubSpot keeps winning best place to work awards. It really is a great place to be. The company truly cares about the wellbeing of their employees and shows that through great benefits and perks, transparency with employees on the direction of the company, and a strong management team. 

There's a culture here where, no matter your role, if you have something to say, your voice will be heard. 

The people working here are consistently whip-smart, super hard working and generally fun to be around. Come for the free candy wall, stay for a great career.

Benefits include:
Tuition reimbursement
Unlimited vacation
Free books
Stocked kitchen
Waffle Wednesday
Dog-Friendly office
Regular team outings
Flexible work culture
And of course, the CANDY WALL! (my favorite)
cons: As we become a bigger company, we're going through the growing pains of a scale up.  On the upside, everyone's aware and making an effort to create simplicity in all processes.

headline: HubSpotters
pros:
- Health insurance coverage has been the best I've had - lowest of costs and the company takes care of the deductibles.
- The pay is fair or above market value - the employee reserved stock units is often what makes your pay exceed the market value
- New hires are pliable and extremely coachable, experienced hires are people who are "remarkable" at their prior roles; I've learned a lot from my peer.
- Work-life balance is real here, same with unlimited vacation. You take what is needed and the team absorbs your absence with a plan. 
- People care about other people - so much that we'll often sacrifice our own goals to work on someone else's project that requires our expertise so that it succeeds. 
- If someone spills coffee in a meeting, the following will happen without fail: the closest people will drop their surroundings to help, the people on the outer ring will look for paper towels, and then the hive mind solves the problem. 
- The company structure changes every year, to best facilitate problems that need to be solved in the near future.
cons:
- Free waffles on Wednesdays occasionally gets cancelled
- Boardgame nights start way too late in the day
- Mystery Dinners (eat with a C-suite, chat, paid by HubSpot) favors a younger crowd without family commitments
- HubSpotters feeling "entitled" to company perks (like all three mentioned points mentioned above)
- On a more serious note, the company structure will occasionally make employees lose morale. Turnover tends to occur during those times, but it is still way below the industry average.

headline: Challenging and rewarding work
pros:
HubSpot is an incredible place to work and grow your career. I find the work to be challenging in the best way. I've got a manager who supports me wholeheartedly, an executive team that listens and takes action, and peers that are insanely smart, talented, and driven. I've been given the tools I need to succeed, but I have to work hard to provide value for our customers and hit my numbers. 

Something I really appreciate is that the company practices what it preaches with HEART and our mission. Being in such a transparent workplace is even better than I expected, and the company is open when we aren't meeting goals. It's pretty cool to see it all in action. 

Another thing I really value is the number of opportunities I have to get involved outside of the 9-5. A few awesome things I'm involved with are Women at HubSpot, People of Color at HubSpot, HubSpot on the Town, book clubs (thanks, free book program!), Healthy at HubSpot, and even a Ru Paul's Drag Race fantasy league.
cons: It is an incredibly fast-paced place, so it's not built for everyone.  For example, I used the unlimited paid time off to take a 2-week vacation and when I came back there were a number of big changes that took place in what seems like the blink of an eye. I personally love this, but it can be tough at times.

headline: Commitment to culture is incredible
pros:
- Colleagues that care. 
- Commitment to diversity and inclusion (at a level I've never seen before, and I've been in tech for nearly a decade)
- Incredible transparency into the business
- Moving to be a product-driven organization which is amazing
- Perks :)
cons: - Change happens frequently and quickly, it's hard to stay on top of

headline: Great time to be a HubSpotter
pros:
This is my first job out of college and I absolutely love it here. I work on challenging problems and often lead systems design on these projects. The people I work with are brilliant and I learn a ton from them. Working in BET I also get to learn a lot about how our business runs and how we're helping it grow. This is not something I expected when I joined, but has been an unanticipated benefit. 

Beyond the work itself, HubSpot is a great place to be. The benefits are fantastic and the company really cares about its employees
cons:
A lot of growing pains that I'm sure many companies experience. It often feels very siloed between departments and cross functional projects can be extremely difficult. The level of politics within the company as a whole has risen during my time here and sometimes it feels like we're doing things to placate peoples egos rather than move the company in the right direction. But these are exceptions rather than the rule. 

It also feels like we love starting big new initiatives and then abandoning them without notice after about a month. We should have more follow through or be more transparent about our focuses changing.

headline: Overall an awesome place to work.
pros:
As you'll hear many of us say, we're never the smartest person in the room. Our colleagues are top notch and the recruiting team does an excellent job at hiring folks who will add to the teams and bring fresh creative ideas into the workplace. I am constantly learning from those around me. 

Great perks and benefits comparable to other tech companies these days.
Flexible schedule and work  from home capability
"Use Good Judgement" policy allows autonomy
Tuition reimbursement offered
Management does a good job of hearing complains and acting on them as soon as possible.
cons:
Sometimes working from home and working on a flexible schedule can get you into hot water with your manager or team. Use good judgement and you will be fine.

If you don't focus, you WILL burnout. We're growing at a rapid rate and it's important to keep up.

headline: Believe The Hype
author_position: Global Partner Program, Strategy and Operations Analyst
pros:
A terrific company culture contributes to a sense of possibility where hard work is rewarded,  not just from a compensation point of view, but career growth.

- Performance is valued above experience
- The company tries hard to retain its start-up agility whilst growing fast
- Just a terrific group of people
- Dogs, beer, rooftop terrace, meals, the works.
- Significant potential to grow your career quickly.
cons:
- Super-fast growth makes it at hard times to keep up with the layers upon layers of internal systems
- Growing pains surrounding internationalisation and keeping in mind the global rollout of US-born ideas.
- HubSpotters work, hard.

headline: Work/Life Balance + Intense Career Growth
pros:
HubSpot is an amazing place to work. Being here for a little over a year, I've seen us scale in number of employees, overall revenue generation, perks, and professional development opportunities.  We've seen hardships along the way, but I can honestly say that 80% of the changes we've made have been undoubtedly for the betterment of the company as a whole, and have spilled over unto us as individuals, to enrich our daily work life. Our constant push to always be improving really affects each of us in unique ways, and in my opinion it's always for the better.  

One of the top reasons I stay at HubSpot is because of the work/life balance and flexibility to make your own schedule.  Although my friends and family may not at times think I have the best "work/life" balance, the way I structure my time is completely up to me, and I capitalize on our Unlimited Vacation policy often.  It's incredibly refreshing to be able to map out your own days and schedule, and be able to enjoy things in life outside of work, whether they are during the typical work day or not. 

I've been able to grow on my own at HubSpot in numerous ways due to the autonomy that has been given to me, and our Culture + L&D teams have done tremendous work in making sure that outside and internal trainings are available and top of mind to anyone who would like to attend.  There are so many leaders here that actually care, and it's just an amazingly collaborative environment that I feel truly stems from our upper management and executive team in a trickle down effect.
cons: Although we are self-proclaimed "policy averse", there are times when policy and direction are paramount to success, and I think we fall flat there in many areas. I think we can do a better job of operationalizing our day to day, without losing sight of our customers as the main focus.  I think in a lot of ways HubSpot isn't a company that appeals to everyone, and I think we need to change this approach as we grow.  While this may be okay when we are a mid-sized company, this won't be an optimal way to operate once we become very large.  There are many "cultural issues" we face as an organization, and while I feel our company culture is mostly positive, I think there are pockets of teams here that operate in ways that wouldn't work for every type of background/personality/culture, and in my opinion we need to look outside of our bubble more often to create a more conducive environment that serves all types of people around the globe if we want to stay relevant as a Global leader in our industry.

headline: Best Company I've Ever Worked for So Far!
pros:
Incredible sense of transparency... 
The company LIVES by the Culture Code... It's not just a marketing stunt.
Everyone has incredible passion and love for the company. They genuinely want to help and do the best they can to make HubSpot's users successful and in turn, make HubSpot successful. 

Team independence is awesome as well. You don't get buried by processes... move fast, ship it and measure!
cons:
A few growing pains... Nothing out of the ordinary but super interesting time to be a part of the company if you're OK with change. 

Salaries can be a bit lower and the benefit packages less than a major corporation... but every company has it's give and take. Salary might be a bit lower but you get a whole lot of culture and excitement in your day-to-day which more than makes up for it in my opinion.

headline: Decent place to get started, but doesn't reward tenure
pros:
HubSpot is tremendously transparent internally and owns that 'T' in the culture deck. Hand-in-hand with the transparency, many challenges/opportunities are available for anyone in the company to take initiative on. Moreover, I've always felt that I have the autonomy to manage my work schedule and design my own approaches to solving problems. 

The people of color culture is great, and it's fantastic to see enough people who truly gets it and care about it enough to push through with many initiatives to drive D&I.
cons:
The compensation is considerably lower than market value, and raises will get you stuck perpetually in catch-up mode because they're positioned as % raises. 

As HubSpot has grown, I have felt the business > team > individual paradigm of "use good judgment" erode. Now it feels more like team > individual > business. More time is spent "talking about talking" to see which team gets the credit rather than simply doing a piece of work that benefits the business. Team priorities are set up similarly so forget about helping another department with something quick (even if it takes <1 hr and has a high impact on the business) because "it's not on the roadmap". The only ways to overcome this has been to either positioning the ask so they see what's in it for them or going to upper management.

I've seen many top, A-level people leave as a result of either compensation or bad management, reducing them from someone who was tremendously helpful to others to having to deal with politics and become jaded.

headline: Account Executive
pros:
Great culture 
Smart people 
Great long term vision
cons:
Work life balance
Constant change can be challenging

headline: Hubspot Review
pros: Great autonomy, plenty of project opportunities to lift your career experience, incredibly motivated and intelligent co-workers & fun environment!
cons: Not a con - but you definitely have to put in significant time and effort to succeed and get noticed which can sometimes hinder work/life balance

headline: Finance
pros: Intelligent, hardworking coworkers, good management, great perks, and always being challenged to do outstanding work
cons: Can be difficult to disconnect, however time off is encouraged

headline: Finance
pros: Exciting energetic environment, good growth opportunities.  Strong company culture code - makes for good blend of people who want to "GSD" get stuff done and in turn get to enjoy numerous perks within the offices, as well as fun company wide and departmental outings.
cons: Lengthy hours at times - but overall worth it.

headline: I couldn't imagine working anywhere else
pros: High energy, inclusive, flexible, reward hard work, fast paced. Not a day has gone by in the last several years where I haven't felt challenged, and appreciated. I work with so many smart, hard working individuals who are passionate and fun. I love that we are always looking to grow, improve, and solve. Mediocrity is not part of the Hubspot language and I love the momentum felt daily working at Hubspot.
cons: Sometimes we take on a lot at once, which can feel stressful at times, but unlimited vacation always makes the busy times worth it, as we can take the time needed to recharge when it makes sense

headline: Working at HubSpot
pros:
Great people
Great benefits if you take advantage of them
cons:
Pay is not great
The turn over rate is high
The internal growth is laughable at best 
401k match is sub-par

headline: Finance
pros: Great company to work for, and everyone is very friendly & willing to help
cons: Keeping up with the diversity

headline: Becoming more than just one tool...
pros:
To use a baseball analogy, truly feel like we are in the 2nd inning here at HubSpot even with a lot of success thus far. There is nothing that fires me up more than being on a growing team and moving from a mere application, to a stack of tools, to eventually a platform and figuring out how to become a facebook, amazon, oracle, etc. catered to SMBs. The possibilities really are endless for the company from that perspective as they have gone from Marketing tools, to Sales tool and more.

As an individual contributor, the possibilities are endless as well for what career path you want to carve out assuming you can over perform.
cons:
What makes me nervous as we push to this idea of becoming a platform, is the speed in which we do it. I've worked for companies where they thought the timing was right to add fuel to fire and as a result essentially spontaneously combusted because things needed to be ironed out internally first before truly thinking up hyper growth.

Also, transparency I think is becoming more of an issue. As an organization who preaches how transparent we are, I think this has become a little distant compared to years past for front line employees to the c-suite....even though we say we are transparent. January is shockingly not that far away and I think there is a ton of unknown still on a month to month basis.

headline: Great place to work!!
pros: Flexibility, culture, work life balance are all pros at HubSpot.
cons: I will say diversity is currently a con but I see forward progress.

headline: Overall positive experience
pros:
-Smart and talented coworkers. Can honestly say I don't have any coworkers that I don't enjoy working with.
-Employees are actually given the autonomy to work when/where is most convenient as long as the work gets done and is done properly.
-Amazing benefits/perks/culture (great insurance, work from home, kitchen, coffee garden, PTO, casual dress, dogs etc.)
-The transparency here seems to be pretty unprecedented for a company of this size. It's insightful to have access to founder/C-level thoughts on topics ranging from corporate strategy to hiring initiatives. 
-It is refreshing to see hard-working people promoted from within.
cons:
-Cyclical work and growth leads to work-life balance being an issue sometimes. There are some late nights required by a lot of people to keep this place running.
-I could likely receive a higher compensation package while working less hours in a similar role elsewhere.

headline: Fantastic place to work!
pros: Love my coworkers and the culture at HubSpot. Huge room for career growth since we are growing so quickly.
cons: Deadline driven which does not always allow for ideal worklife balance

headline: Great place to learn and grow your career...
pros: HubSpot is a place that really values growth and professional development. I can't even begin to count all of the awesome opportunities I've had -- from taking on exciting new projects that push my limits and allow me to develop my skills to attending workshops, trainings, and more.
cons: Things at HubSpot move quickly. It's a trait that I've learned to love from my time working in the startup industry, but the ambiguity can be difficult for some at times.

headline: The smartest and most helpful people
pros:
I'm pretty new (a little over a month) and I can honestly say I've learned more in the last month than in the last 6 months at my previous company. Everyone here is SO smart, and so willing to help teach. I feel like I can go to my manager and team with any question, and rather than just tell me an answer they genuinely make sure I understand the concepts. Everyone motivates each other and encourages each other, and there's none of the cut throat politics like other places. Yes you work a lot, but its enjoyable because everyone wants  you to succeed. 

Also, TONS OF FOOD!!!!!!!
cons: Training is nuts. A month of class in a school classroom setting, and a "new hire project" that's pretty intense.

headline: HubSpot
pros:
Challenging
Great Culture
Pay is Great
All team members are unique and great at what the do, making you better
Management is ready to teach at all times.
Endless access to resources to better yourself.
cons: I have not come across any cons yet.

headline: Doing the right things
pros: Constantly examining itself, relationships with customers, culture.   Pushing on diversity.
cons: No POC at executive levels

headline: 2017 Review
pros: Great growth trajectory, dynamic work environment,  unique challenges associated with being a scale up
cons: Always connected, so it can sometimes be hard to step away

headline: Great Company with Fantastic Opportunities
pros: HubSpot provides you with all the resources you need to succeed. They are fair and treat their staff with respect, they really do care.
cons: Not a con depending on your perspective but it is worthy to mention there is a lot of additional learning and training to be done outside of work hours

headline: Great company to have an impact at and continue to learn
pros:
- Smart coworkers who are willing to help you.
- Interesting and relatable company mission and product impact.
- Growth opportunities at a global scale.
- Challenged professionally to do your best work.
cons: - Growing this quickly and at the size we are already at can be challenging.

headline: Keep on Pushing to Be Better and Bolder
pros:
-Autonomy
-Flexibility 
-Incredibly Smart Coworkers 
-Global First Attitude 
-Honest Interest in Employee Growth
cons:
-Growing Pains are showing in some of the larger departments 
-Communication can be tough
-Comp is not fully transparent

headline: Autonomous, Energetic, Rewarding
pros:
My two years at HubSpot has been the most rewarding and challenging (in the best way) two years of any job I've held. 

HubSpot deeply care about our customers, our employees, and our product! 

- Autonomy 
- Balance 
- People
- Challenging
- Learning 
- Leadership
cons: As a HubSpot employee, you have to be willing to work hard. This fast paced environment isn't for everyone, but it's incredibly rewarding if you're an ambitious person.

headline: Great company, culture and co-workers
pros: Great culture, great learning experiences,  brilliant perks , autonomy,  lots of opportunities, a rewarding and enjoyable working experience everyday
cons: none that I can think of

headline: Finding the right fit
pros:
I've been at HubSpot for a little over two years and am now in my third role  - two in the same department, one (and currently) in a completely different one. While people usually talk about career growth and opportunities in terms of climbing the ladder, HubSpot (and of course, the people) have helped me find opportunities and roles that fit me better so that I truly want to grow IN this company and the company itself. 

In a nutshell, a major pro of HubSpot is that they help you develop your career.
cons: I know the company is working on it, but diversity is still a weakness of HubSpot.

headline: Great
pros: Love it. It's great. Nothing better.
cons: None. But stop getting in the way of your own success.

headline: The Unicorn of Companies
pros:
where to start?! Besides the amazing benefits: 
- The people are all very friendly and supportive. 
- The office environment is like no other. 
- There are always opportunities for you to advance and grow professionally and personally. 
- They truly understand and promote work life balance. (WFH opportunities and unlimited PTO)
- diversity everywhere, with the multiple offices all over the world you get to meet so many different people and form international connections. 
- DOGS - pet friendly office means puppers EVERYWHERE, ALL DAY, EVERYDAY
cons:
- They don't have a slushy machine. 
- Parking is a little pricey, but it is everywhere in the city. They do offer passes at a discounted monthly rate though!

headline: Best place I've ever worked
pros:
- Amazing people, perks, and benefits
- Empowered to do great work & given great autonomy
- Management listens and responds to feedback extraordinarily well
- Real commitment to diversity & inclusion efforts from leadership
- Katie Burke is a gem and having her as our Chief People Officer is the best thing to ever happen (not exaggerating)
cons:
- We are definitely underpaid (especially in engineering)
- Only 12 weeks of paid maternity leave, which is pretty low for this industry
- Still mostly white dudes, especially in sales & engineering (and leadership overall)

headline: Best company in my 20 year career.. and the best days are still to come
pros: I've worked at five companies in my career and seen many others and HubSpot is, hands down, the best on so many levels. I have been able to work with some of the smartest people I've ever met, been given incredibly challenges to solve, have had a ton of fun, and have been able to help our customers succeed. While HubSpot has already accomplished a lot, the best days are still ahead.
cons: If you are coming in with a lot of experience, come in with an open mind. HubSpot is different from any place I've ever worked at -- and that's a lot of what makes it special. But if you come in unwilling to embrace those differences and always talk about "this is how we did it at my last company", you will struggle.

headline: A great place to learn and grow as an engineer
pros:
Great co-op / intern program 
Small teams with complete ownership over your team's part of the product
Amazing co-workers to learn from and have as mentors 
Great culture of learning from mistakes 
Can work from home multiple times a week
cons: Work life balance can be a little rough at times depending on your role but being able to work from home and unlimited vacation definitely help.

headline: A great place to grow and be part of something big
pros: Full of opportunities and people willing to help you in your career.
cons: Things can change really quickly. Need to be willing and able to think on your feet.

headline: A great place to grow and be part of something big
pros: Full of opportunities and people willing to help you in your career.
cons: Things can change really quickly. Need to be willing and able to think on your feet.

headline: Great company to grow, be challenged and innovate with self-initiative
pros:
- GREAT culture! Culture touches so many parts of the company and it makes it an awesome place to work at.
- There is a lot of freedom to do your best work using good judgement. Decisions are made based on data and you can always try something new provided you make a case for it
- Everyone in the company (including execs and founders) is pretty accessible due to our flat structure. This allows you to meet many people internally and learn from them. No one is "too important" to not grab coffee and chat with you for a few minutes
cons:
- Monetary compensation is a bit below average for tech industry (but we also get a lot of non-monetary perks)
- If you are an external hire new to the company, it may be a bit hard to get adjusted at first because of the unique culture and the "HubSpottiness" flying around.

headline: HubSpot is an awesome place to work!
pros:
Great Management team
tons of transparency, which really makes the employee feel like we are working towards a shared goal
perks are next to none
cons: work a lot, sometimes the work/life balance gets blurred.

headline: Remarkable team and mission
pros: There are so many.  First, the transparency and autonomy you are given is remarkable at a company of this size.  You are given all the tools and autonomy to do your best work.  Second,  the team is fantastic from top to bottom.  Third, the company is still laser focused on the mission and not solely on the quarterly earnings.  Finally, it's amazing to see a company of this size balance scale and growth.  It's like a Mini-MBA.
cons: Legacy internal systems are being rewritten which makes some of the day-to-day more difficult than it should be.  You'll have to have an ounce of patience as the team catches up.

headline: Growing, improving, iterating
pros:
HubSpot is an incredible company and I am still excited to come into work every day several years into my tenure. I think you'd be hard pressed to find a better tech company in the area, especially as an engineer. Business wise, stock and metrics continue to improve. Growth is difficult to sustain and not easy, but I'm bullish that we will continue to find ways. The company is not perfect, but the best thing about the culture is that it is willing to admit faults and improve where things are not great. 

* increased investment and revamping of training and leadership
* always introspective, refining, improving processes and culture
* transparency of operations and business from top down
* growing, lots of hiring, opportunities to move up
* great office, perks (coffee garden, tea, barista, ping pong, beer, snacks)
* strong, trusted leadership
* smart coworkers
* flexibility in time
* overall a fun environment to work in, great social events
* autonomy, power to have impact
cons:
Naturally as the company has grown, the only constant has been change - which is fine. But HubSpot, like most growing startups/scaleups is not great at change management. There is good transparency, but that does not necessarily equate to good communication. There is thrash at times because the org structure does not support the goals that leadership sets for the company (which seem directionally correct, but execution is lacking).

The company is very young and lacks diversity in many areas (race, women in leadership, etc), though there is a genuine effort to improve here.

headline: Sales
pros: If you get an opportunity to work at HubSpot, take it! It will be the best career decision ever.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: By far best job I've ever had
pros:
People. I know it might sound cliché, but people is HubSpot's secret. It's not only that. Culture, Opportunities, Transparency, Flexibility. The list goes on and on and on and on. At HubSpot I learned that you can have life/work balance. I learned that life happens people will stop, listen and help. The environment is perfect for you to grow as a person and professional. 
Bottom line, for anyone reading this, if you have the chance to work at HubSpot, go for it and fully embrace the opportunity, it will probably be the best experience in your life, it will forever change your perception of work and people (for the best).
HubSpot made me a better person and a much much much better professional.
Kudos to all People Operation, you are doing a fantastic job on creating and maintaining a great work environment.
cons: There's still small cultural subsets here and there that doesn't quite fit the company culture. Those subsets become more visible when there're parties and alcohol involved which always makes a lot of room for misunderstanding/misinterpretation.

headline: Fantastic environment
pros:
HubSpot is a great place to learn and grow in any field. There is so much going on here that it is impossible not to take on great projects. 
The employees are friendly and very giving with their time. 
Flexible workplace and they do really want their staff to have a life outside of work. 
They promote meeting meeting employees from different teams which grows your internal network and also helps you learn about other roles here should you like a change.
cons: Overall package is very good but a little more contribution on the pension would be fantastic.

headline: Territory Manager
pros: Culture is good, many benefits, innovative company
cons: A lot of stress due to monthly quotas

headline: Culture is Key
pros: A welcoming, creative, and flexible culture with many amazing benefits such as unlimited paid vacation and sick days, flexible work from home hours, generous parental leave, a private coffee shop, an onsite gym with free workout classes and showers, remarkable employees, and so much more.
cons: I really can't think of any cons about working here. I love the team I work for and the creativity and drive that every employee I have met has. The culture is what's key about this company.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
- Flexibility
- Focus on diversity & inclusion by C-level
- Rapid growth of business
cons:
- Internal communication can be difficult with current system used
- Rapid global growth leading to a period of catch-up around scaling systems that work across offices

headline: The BEST place ever to start your sales career
pros:
HubSpot has done an amazing job at balancing what's important. There's so much autonomy within the organisation, paired with carefully thought-out and rolled-out processes. 

I started as an Inbound Sales Coordinator and am now in a Principal BDR role. The promotion path in sales is incredibly transparent, and hard work is both recognised and rewarded. My managers have challenged me and been incredibly supportive since day 1. 

The people at HubSpot are some of the best you'll ever meet, both incredibly helpful and hard-working. The culture code isn't a PR front to get people in the door — sure, it's a little cheesy, but it really is embedded within the entire org which is so wonderful to be a part of. 

It's hard not to love your job when you work at HubSpot.
cons: There isn't a tonne of opportunity for frequent international travel as a BDR/sales rep here. Only a con if you want to travel for work!

headline: BDR
pros: Fantastic training set you up for your future in sales.
cons: Management not as experience, very early on in the career.

headline: Senior customer tech support
pros: Fastpaced and challenging place to work
cons: Salary is not competitive with the market

headline: HubSpot After Two years
pros:
- Autonomy: Being able to have your ideas heard and then given the space to achieve those ideas 
- Working culture: HubSpot is becoming known for our culture and having a culture where you can be yourself to achieve the most amount of success both personally and for HubSpot is one of the best reasons to work if not the best reason. 
- Flexibility: I have a family outside of the East Coast and being able to visit them and having my team and HubSpot understand that is a priority is amazing
cons: Currently, the only downside I see at HubSpot is that we are only located in the Eastern part of the United States which limits our ability to reach out in the States for other talent.

headline: HubSpot lives with HEART
pros:
The company focus on helping SMBs grow is motivating. The executive team is inspiring, coworkers are fantastic and the work is challenging. 

Many organizations have mission statements or sets of company values. HubSpot lives the company values from the bottom up and the top down. The management team believes in hiring people with HEART (Humble, Empathetic, Adaptable, Remarkable, Transparent). When you trust the people around you, you let the politics of a typical workplace slide away, and focus on delivering a fantastic customer experience and product.
cons:
The majority of employees are young professionals (which is dynamic and fun), but sometimes lacks years of real-world experience. The executive team has made up for this over time by hiring more experienced managers/directors/VPs. 

Sometimes the focus on 'career growth' seems like if you're not getting your next promotion, you're not growing. This mentality is starting to shift though.

headline: Great people, experiences, and culture
pros:
- Vacation  (little stress in taking time off)
- People (smart, friendly, and helpful)
- Culture (makes you feel like the company cares about you)
- Team size (small teams promote better collaboration)
cons: - Scaling, but still small teams (lots of new people and changes make it more difficult to keep up with what's happening around the company)

headline: Couldn't be happier!
pros: I've been working at HubSpot for a little over a month and couldn't be happier. Great interview process, even better onboarding process, and my coworkers are genuinely some of the best people I've ever met.  I have great faith in the leadership and management teams,  and feel very blessed to be working among such bright and motivated individuals. On top of all that, HubSpot has wonderful perks and benefits, and employees literally live and breathe the company culture and values.
cons: Would love to see more dogs in the DubSpot office :)

headline: Renewal Manager
pros:
Perks (Kitchen is my fav)
Commute
Intensive Training
Everyone is super helpful and ready to get you going on whatever project your are taking
cons: Not a very diverse environment but I hear they are working on it. ( Make sure to try and retain qualified minority talent throughout all orgs not just sales)

headline: Rocket. Ship. Continues.
pros: Company growth and future #1.  Culture, talent, benefits, salary, flexibility, ESPP.
cons: None! Every now and then someone accepts a role here and it's more than they can bite off and find something to complain about. Happens at every company - even less so here, luckily.

headline: Find peace past the kool-aid
pros:
- Flexibility with working hours. As long as you get your job done, no one bats an eyelid at what time you're online
- Great level of autonomy with projects and day-to-day
- Good compensation (for Singapore)
- Lots of learning opportunities
- Cross-department interaction is strong and always highly encouraged
cons:
- Requires a great level of self-direction (can be a pro, too). Some colleagues struggle with this in terms of career growth or when they face ambiguous questions with no clear-cut questions
- Dynamic and constant learning can be a tiring (can be a pro, too)
- Strong sales culture, very cult-like, so some people may find the energy level quite disruptive
- Some Product teams are messy, so morale is affected

headline: Best company I've ever worked for
pros: Everything is amazingly transparent and the culture is incredible. By no means does it feel like an 1800 person company. If you do your job, the flexibility and autonomy they give you is absolutely amazing. Your ability to grow here is unsurpassed - between everything they do internally to how they cut you a check for 5k each year to go out and take classes.
cons: Monthly quota can tire you out but if you're able to build out a good system, it really blends together and doesn't end up being too much of an issue.

headline: Few tech companies in Dublin compare
pros:
- Smart, authentic and transparent leadership
- A strong product that is always evolving - the marketing product really slowed down for a few years but the current work to take customer feedback seriously and future-proof is impressive
- We get to solve for the mid market and SMBs. This is so much more interesting than chasing enterprises or being beholden to large customers. We can make a real impact on our customers businesses
- Employee onboarding and training is taken very seriously - you are given what you need to succeed
- We have real functions outside of the US (product, BI, legal, operations) - this is rare!
- If you have a case to make and have the data and logic to back it up you can get access to whoever you need to make a change. People are accessible.
cons:
- If you don't want to give and receive feedback (good and bad) constantly then it's not the place for you - you can't be sensitive or take things personally - not really a con for me but be aware.
- Need to do a better job at setting expectations around career growth and putting people in the drivers seat. We can pander a little bit to much to every piece of feedback
- It's become increasingly difficult to execute a new idea quickly - BET, systems and reporting are slow and very centralized. I understand they have so many competing project and priorities and I'm confident we will get to a better place but this makes true autonomy difficult

headline: Best place I have ever worked
pros:
The culture here is truly second to none
The product is above reproach 
Leadership is very transparent 
Never have to fight for commission getting paid
cons:
Growing really fast and focusing a lot on the global growth so things can be sloppy sometimes 
Career growth can be challenging, but just start a conversation

headline: Channel Account Manager
pros:
-Great product
-Great people
-Strong brand recognition
-Work has all the millenial bells and whistles (snacks, beer, barista, team outings)
cons:
-Going through some growing pains, need to focus on who is made a leader/manager
-Been a high amount of attrition
-Highly competitive space, space is becoming saturated
-Growing fast, but infrastructure/operations are not keeping up
-Claims a world of work life balance, pretty impossible in sales while scaling portfolio

headline: Great place to start
pros: Opportunities for growth early on in your career. Transparency across departments and ranks gives you an opportunity to network and learn from different departments.
cons: Average age is pretty young and lots of first time managers

headline: Great place to work
pros: I genuinely enjoy working with everyone on my team. I have autonomy in my work, schedule, and I feel fully supported by my manager. Lots of opportunity for career development.
cons: I wish there was more of a clear path to advancement for my current role. Sometimes the upper management says they will do things or make something more clear but then it doesn't happen.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Cool work perks, great product training
cons: Sub par work life balance

headline: Sales
pros: HubSpot is a great place to work
cons: Fast paced environment. Don't come here if you don't like constant change. If you do though, it's a great place to work!

headline: Working at HubSpot
pros: Large focus on employee growth
cons: Entry-level pay is not competative

headline: Working at HubSpot
pros: Large focus on employee growth
cons: Entry-level pay is not competative

headline: Good Culture and great people - no career growth in sales
pros: Great product and team. Enjoy going to work every day. Great product to sell that is highly competitive
cons: No career growth opportunities anymore. Dumb metrics in which they promote by.

headline: Not for me
pros: It's a nice office space, with some really great people. Most are excited to be there and there is opportunity to advance your career if you're willing to put in the hours
cons: I had a hard time making HubSpot my whole life. I felt like I had to in order to be accepted by my coworkers. Work life balance is not working from 8 - 5, and then telling your team that it's family time from 5:30 - 7:30, but then you're available. When you have managers saying these things, it puts too much pressure on employees to be just as readily available, 24/7.

headline: Subtle agism and not so good changes.
pros: People. Most amazing talented people I've ever had the chance to work with. Fun environment.
cons: Most departments are run by young people, when older folks come to talk about their needs they are mostly not taken seriously. Some inappropriate behavior/comments/suggestions from management can be seen when alcohol is involved. Sometimes it feels like the company is trying to hard to look like a grown-up company but the actions to achieve that are not quiet right.

headline: Review
pros: Growing business providing useful tools to small and medium businesses
cons: Lost management with no real direction at this point. Expanding without a plan

headline: great
pros: compassionate, supportive, path for growth
cons: competitive, rigorous, not many more

headline: Growing company with great growth opportunities
pros: Great place to grow career in a dynamic working environment. The company is great at rewarding top performers.
cons: Challenging place to work with high expectations. Some thrive in that type of environment, some don't.

headline: Great appreciation for people
pros:
- Smart, motivated colleagues
- Focus on helping other companies grow
- Consistent desire to get [stuff] done
- Wholehearted dedication to maintaining a positive culture
cons: We're grappling with dramatic growth. Balancing current needs with structured project planning is a challenge.

headline: Joining HubSpot was the best decision I ever made
pros: I started at HubSpot with limited sales experience, but a love for the Inbound mission and a relentless desire to contribute however I could.  I did my day job well, took on new challenges, and no one ever told me no or to slow down.  Instead, my colleagues taught me more, and pushed me to continue to improve.  Nearly 5 years later I am in a key leadership role in sales and have elevated my career beyond my wildest dreams.  I love HubSpot.  There is an ever thriving startup culture even as the company scales, and I get an opportunity to learn from and be challenged by incredible people every single day.
cons: HubSpot is not a place that you can come in, "do your time", and climb the corporate ladder.  You need to do remarkable work to get noticed at HubSpot, but if that excites you, you will flourish at HubSpot.

headline: Customers first
pros: Customers first. Endless opportunities to learn and get better.
cons: The usual politics and popularity contests.

headline: Learning something new every day
pros: There is never a dull moment at HubSpot - I am constantly challenged which helps me develop as a professional.  We work hard but the people I work with mean everything.
cons: I appreciate the fast-paced nature of the company isn't for everyone.

headline: Couldn't ask for better
pros: Consistently challenging and amazing opportunities for career growth.
cons: Keeping the hiring bar high as we grow.

headline: The Rate of Growth and Learning at HubSpot is Unmatchable
pros: HubSpot is a fast pace, challenging, and energetic place to work. The aspect I like best is that you get out of out HubSpot what you put into it. You are given autonomy regardless of your tenure which makes the rate of learning unmatchable.
cons: You have to be all in. If you are not, you won't move up.

headline: HubSpot Review
pros: People, culture, opportunities, growth, team
cons: Small knits like some employees not appreciating all HubSpot has to offer and that this is not a typical company

headline: Hubspot assessment
pros: Creative, passionate teams, lots of intelligent discussions and room for experimenting and free reign for improvement
cons: Some complexities in current system setups due to scaling from a start up to current stage

headline: Most Admired CEO
pros: Flexible place to work and great people/atmosphere.
cons: A very fast paced place to work.

headline: HubSpot review
pros:
- Management team that truly cares about the happiness of employees
- Surrounded by bright, hard working and motivated people. 
- Very flexible work environment.  Mentality is come in, get your work done, and leave.  Managers never expect their people do be at their desks just for face time.
- People are encouraged to think outside of the box and if there is a better way to do something you are encouraged to speak up and recommend/implement change.  You never hear anyone say "well that's how we've always done it so we can't change"
cons:
- Company is growing very quickly and is in scale up mode.  Always a lot to do, pace can be very hectic and you have to expect and be comfortable with constant change.  This kind of environment definitely isn't for everyone.
- There is a decent amount of "group think" on various topics given the young demographic of employees and the company's front line leaders.  If you don't feel the same way about certain topics there is a tendency for the "group" to dismiss your opinion - you'll need to be comfortable speaking up and challenging people if you want your voice to be heard and you're not aligned with the vocal few that are passionate about the topic at hand.

headline: First time in my career that I look forward to coming to work
pros: Autonomy, velocity, meaningful work, culture, transparency, perks & benefits, work/life flexibility and modern facilities.
cons: Career paths are not clearly defined and compensation isn't competitive with peer organizations.

headline: I don't think I'll ever find a better place to work!
pros:
-Able to challenge myself everyday. 
-Amazing community feel, especially in the Portsmouth office! Literally feels like a second family. 
-Being a member of the tech industry is exciting, particularly because HubSpot is so proactive in paving the way for Inbound Marketing to become the way of the future.
-The company encourages career growth and makes it very easy for you to explore different options. I've been encouraged and felt supported throughout this process.
cons: I have no cons! Very happy to be here.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Flexibility, transparency, colleagues, challenges to grow
cons: nothing here as of yet

headline: Amazing place to do great work and grow as a human.
pros: Great people, great perks, they trust you to do your work.  Free beer, and I feel like my hard work is valued.
cons: None that I can really say.  I am not a huge fan of commuting but I have the flexibility to work from home as needed.

headline: Great for fresh grads, experienced professionals look elsewhere
pros:
Autonomy
Flexibility/ WFH
Office perks
Great product
Company invests heavily in onboarding
cons:
Lack of career growth opportunities
Young and inexperienced management
No diversity especially in the sales org
Not the place for strong female leaders to succeed
Your past experience and education is of no value once you join, expect to wipe your slate clean and start over
Perks and compensation is more suited for young professionals in their early 20s

headline: High expectations with high impact at HubSpot
pros:
HubSpot hires smart people, sets high expectations, gives them the opportunity to make a big impact, and helps them grow to do even more :)

For a company of HubSpot's size is surprising (and lucky) to have access to the company's founders (CEO Brian Halligan and CTO Dharmesh Shah). Invite one of them to a team lunch and if they are available they will go and answer everyone's questions and listen to concerns.
cons: The Cambridge location can seem too far and the traffic too daunting for people who live out of town but the commuter rail solved that problem for me.

headline: Great Place to Work (Sales rep)
pros: HubSpot really is a great place to work.  The product, people, and culture are industry leading and, as long as you enjoy a fast-paced/challenging environment, you'll grow and learn a ton.
cons: Career/compensation progression is a little slow.  Great place to start your career but older reps might find themselves hitting a ceiling.

headline: Great place to learn sales
pros:
focus on sales coaching
good teammates
powerful brand authority 
great perks
competitive pay
cons: pretty big team now and difficult to move up in the ranks

headline: A Very Special Company
pros:
HubSpot was somewhere I called my 2nd home for a little over 3 years. In those 3 years, the company naturally changed due to being in a hypergrowth phase, yet I will always have extremely fond memories. 
- Company culture is outstanding. Employees are genuinely valued, relationships are built and the office is generally a very fun place to be. 
- Fantastic environment for those who like to learn. You are challenged but never without appropriate support. You work with very intelligent people that help you upskill in a way that will not only help you in your current role at HubSpot, but will benefit the rest of your career.
cons: -There sometimes can be an air of elitism when it comes to hiring and an inflated sense of ego. Nothing extremely detrimental, but enough to think "Hey, don't take yourself so seriously."

headline: Energizing work at a fast-growing company
pros:
Growth makes everything more interesting and rewarding. 

The company keeps expanding: to new international markets, with new products, new ideas, and new people. There are ample opportunities to solve interesting challenges, have real impact, and experience firsthand how a company and product scales. This experience feels unique and invaluable.
cons: Not everything is figured out. You may be expected to jump out of your comfort zone or own the solution to a problem. There are lots of people doing things for the first time in their career. This is exciting but it is a learning process.

headline: Truly a great place to work
pros:
- Transparency from management on decisions and direction
- And willingness of management to make the hard decisions/make changes to the business & model, effectively distrupting ourselves & not allowing ourselves to rest on our laurels, continuing to innovate & not just grow through acquisition
- Health benefits are top notch, very minimal/essentially zero out of pocket expenses for the employee (except for the premium), which is great as a new parent
- Focus on flexibility: I feel like I have the ability to take the time I need, come in later/leave "early," work from home, etc. This is supported at the highest levels (CEO) and feels like we're doubling down on it as we speak.
cons:
- Typical growing pains of moving from a start-up to scale-up (i.e. systems/data challenges, not yet the best at being a global company where international employees feel just as "in the loop" as those at HQ)
etc.

headline: What do you want to learn? Do it here.
pros:
This place has pushed me in a lot of ways -- it's almost overwhelming the number of different skills, tactics, knowledge, frameworks, etc. that I could choose to focus on and learn from my colleagues, customers and prospects. 

I love the autonomy, I love the opportunity to move around internally and work cross-functionally. If you are comfortable seeking out opportunities and taking big jumps in your career, this is the place to do it. 

Brian Halligan, Dharmesh Shah and JD Sherman are some of the most transparent (and very different from each other!) leaders I've ever worked with. The fact that we have access to their thoughts, concerns, vision, etc. in REAL TIME and at our fingertips at any minute means we can all do our jobs that much better. 

Plus - you can't beat the community, friendship, and honestly, family that you meet here. I spend more time with my co-workers than my actual family, so they better be good people. And let me tell you - they are.

Some highlights over the years -- I've worked with executives who have opened doors for me and written recommendations that I would never have even met in person at a different company. I've had a diverse set of mentors that seem to have fallen in my lap -- something I never found though sought at other companies. I take classes every year that HubSpot pays for to help me add to my skillset and my value to this (or any other) company. I work when I want, where I want, and have a team to support me. I have a manager whose #1 goal is to see me get promoted and succeed, whether it's on her team or not. I have equity as a top performer. I get to travel globally to meet customers and speak at events.
cons:
Things have certainly changed over the course of the past half-decade (what company doesn't when going from 300-1500+ employees that rapidly?) We've retained our culture but our processes and day-to-day workflows have certainly changed.
