This isn't a con so much as a result of growth that any employee must learn to adapt to at any growing company. If you're thinking of joining -- know that you are NOT joining a startup. The culture feels like it, but experience in a larger company and how to navigate throughout an org will be a huge value add. 

You're never going to get paid the highest salary at HubSpot. It's just not the case, but there is huge opportunity and benefit outside of your annual salary. Read the last paragraph of my Pros section -- if you care about money more than these things, you may find this as a con at HubSpot.

headline: Fantastic please to grow
pros: Smart people, great product and great benefits
cons: Communication can be better to offices outside HQ

headline: Exciting company to work for you are looking for personal growth
pros:
HubSpot is a dynamic company in a fast-growing technology segment. The company never sits still and you can sense that the excitement through the constant new products and features being launched. And the management never flinches from making bold decisions that has a major impact on the entire company.

One of the great perks in working in HubSpot is that you are surrounded by some of the smartest people in the industry. More importantly, because of the transparency in the company (particularly through the internal wiki), you can understand the thoughts and debates behind many important decisions made in the company. That makes it for a great learning experience if you are willing to invest your time and energy.

On the sales team, there is a strong structure and data-driven process around it. I feel HubSpot is a great place for a salesperson to start their career (especially if they want to build a career in tech sales) as they learn so much, not just learning from more senior colleagues, but also from learning the process.
cons: The constant changes, while mostly positive and much needed for the company as a whole, can take its toll on individuals. On the sales side of things, the changes can impact your ability to do your job but you still need to hit your quota so there is a lot of adapting needed. It's probably not so much a con but a challenge that comes with working for a company like HubSpot.

headline: Excellent Co-op Experience
pros:
Working here at HubSpot provides an excellent window into modern software engineering coupled with excellent mentorship for new-hires. From as early as the first week on the job you can be developing and shipping real production code that can directly improve the lives of our customers. Wether it's front-end or back-end development or somewhere in-between there's something exciting here to work on.

Specifically for co-ops and interns there is a lot of effort on behalf of the Product team to organize events and reach-out and address any concerns. Overall this has been the best co-op I've experienced.
cons: Commuting from anywhere outside of the Cambridge area or downtown Boston can be a painful experience. The MBTA commuter rail lines and inner city rails are not always on-time and generally pretty expensive.

headline: Impressed with the Direction & Vision
pros: HubSpot had a fantastic idea 10yrs ago that changed the marketing landscape. Interestingly the idea has not just changed the marketing landscape, but changed the lives of those involved in the journey. Working for HubSpot is by no means easy, they expect you to go above and beyond to help make their legacy great - but isn't that the point in working in an industry, with great people, selling innovative products where you are truly passionate and fulfilled by the work?
cons: For those that are not looking to elevate their career or unwilling to work hard for big wins, this is not the faint of heart. People here work hard, I mean really hard, and if that's not something you enjoy (despite getting better from it) HubSpot is not the place for you.

headline: Challenging and fulfilling work while giving me flexibility to accomodate my growing family
pros: HubSpot is an amazing place to grow and learn. I've been at HubSpot for over 7 years now and there hasn't been a day in my time here where I didn't have the opportunity to learn something new. The evolution of the company over the years has been truly remarkable and it is something I'm very proud to be a part of. I look forward to coming to work every day to be a part of something big and interesting. The coworkers I have are brilliant and fun to be around, the work is challenging and fulfilling and the flexibility I have to accomodate my growing family means the world to me.
cons: Opportunities to grow and learn are everywhere, but you have to be adamant about seeking them out. As soon as you start looking you are bound to find them, but you have to take the initiative to look.

headline: Services Team
pros: Amazing place to grow your career, fantastic supports and team all round. Really at the forefront of marketing industry and proud to work there.
cons: Could be handling the rapid growth a bit better. Get management in place and upskilled before teams grow too big rather than struggling to fill management roles once teams have grown.

headline: Genuinely is a best place to work
pros: flexibility, autonomy, challenge, culture, growth
cons: things change super quickly, have to be able to deal with ambiguity

headline: Amazing place to grow your career as a leader
pros:
-huge degree of autonomy over your work. Employees are given a lot of latitude to tackle meaty challenges across the business and drive results. Given how quickly we're growing there's plenty of opportunity to make an impact
-unlimited flexibility. This isn't a face-time culture, and employees are encouraged to find a schedule that works with their life
-benefits are amazing. The health insurance offers great coverage, $5K annual tuition reimbursement for continuing education, and every employee is offered restricted stock as part of their compensation package
-incredibly smart, driven, motivated people who constantly inspire their peers to do their best work
cons: -feeling some growing pains that are totally characteristic of a scale-up: equipping front line managers with the tools and skills they need to successfully manage their teams, becoming more globally focused

headline: An Incredible Place to Learn
pros:
1. Lots of good humans here. I especially like the wide variety of life experiences. I hope as we get bigger, we keep taking risks in hiring to bring in more high potential people with atypical backgrounds. 
2. Love my manager.
3. With the growth and breakneck speed of the company, you get so many learning opportunities just by doing your job and keeping up with company communication. I've been able to work on really interesting, high-impact projects, and I'm confident that this will set me up for success in the future, where it's at HubSpot or elsewhere.
cons: Like most workplaces, there are some politics and there are some jerks. There's a fair amount of preaching around how we don't stand for politics and don't hire jerks - this seems a bit silly. They exist. Would love to see us be better at holding people accountable when they poison the well.

headline: Senior Marketing Manager
pros: Great place to work, fast growing company
cons: Only 2 offices in the US, both in New England

headline: Couldn't be happier!
pros: Autonomous environment, lots of career growth opportunities and never a shortage of work, great networking and collaboration opportunities, work/life balance and benefits.
cons: No big complaints. Very fast paced and lots to learn so onboarding/work can be overwhelming for those who don't go in with 100% effort.

pros: Challenging, fast paced, super sharp and motivated employees.
cons: Things change pretty quickly around here, but that keeps things fresh and exciting at the same time.

headline: Super challenging and rewarding company
pros:
- fast pace
- challenging environment
cons: - sometimes you feel like you're drinking from a firehose

headline: Great spot!
pros:
- great team dynamics
- career growth opportunities
- autonomy
- transparency
cons: - can be an intense work culture. you will definitely work hard and learn a lot.

headline: Channel Account Executive | Partner Strategist Midwest Territory
pros: Really great environment. Skill development was top notch. Really learned how to do inside sales the right away.
cons: I don't have anything negative to say. great place. great people. As the market pivots HubSpot's super quick to also pivot. this is why it's light years ahead of the competition

headline: Work hard, play hard, rewarding
pros: Smart people who respect the value individuals bring to an overall team/corporate goal. Paid for performance. Excellent perks. Gym, health, education allowance. Breakfast & lunch provided. Free beer & wine & ping pong.
cons: Work hard play hard. Lot of decisions made in US head office. More localized decision making required. Increased promoting opportunities for individual contributors needed.

headline: Love the culture!
pros: The culture at HubSpot is second to none. You'll love your coworkers and enjoy all the different perks and activities that are included.
cons: It can be hard to move into a completely different department than the one you start in. We're still growing so there are some career paths that just haven't been established yet.

headline: Awesome company if you are on the right team/department
pros: HubSpot is one of the best companies I have worked for and it is amazing how many smart and inspiring people work here. Transparency is everything and you can really grow professionally if you want.
cons: The biggest problem of this company is the first line management team, who is full of inexperienced people, who have been promoted because of their great performance as an individual contributor, but not necessarily for the ability and potential in managing people. Unfortunately these managers are not enabling the success of their team members, but they are mostly interested in showing upper management that they are as cool as managers as they were as individual contributors.

headline: Mid-Market Account Executive
pros: Really great product and a ton of leads. Culture is fun and it's an easy job.
cons:
Salespeople are not talented there and super over-confident. All the good ones have left and either started companies or gone onto sales leadership positions at growth stage startups. Territories have shrunk a lot, which is to be expected.
The BDR program is a joke and I heard it is getting worse which is hard to believe.
All in all cool place, but got really big really fast and individual contributors are no longer valued.

headline: BDR
pros: Awesome job. I don't ever want to leave.
cons: None. Really don't have anything negative to say.

headline: Overall, fantastic
pros:
HubSpot has a pretty fantastic work environment with amazingly smart co-workers. Every day I'm encouraged to push further than I did the last while knowing that I have the full support of those around me.
Free breakfast and lunch are fantastic perks, as are perks such as the on-site gym (and gym re-embursement which just about covers the cost of a budget gym like Flyefit down the road). We also have unlimited paid holidays, but I don't know if anybody has ever gone significantly over the 25 days marked in contract.
I'm now at the point in my career (generally two years at a company, in tech at least) where I could be earning significantly more if I were to jump ship and join a different company. I have no real desire to make that jump, I'm still learning new things at HubSpot every day, and can see the effect that my work has on the people who use our tools.
cons:
Dublin seems to be in a constant state of running out of desk space.
Pension contribution remains subpar.
Some minor politics creeping into the Dublin office. You sometimes have to be friendly with the right person to get something done.
We have a new internal mantra that HubSpot is becoming a product driven company. I have yet to see any real life examples of this - it still feels very much a sales driven company. I've no strong issues with a sales driven company, but I'd prefer to call a spade a spade, at least until the transition has been completed.

headline: Running out of orange kookade
pros: Usual IT perks- free food, free sweets, free beer. Educational allowance. Laid back attitude when performing well from most managers.
cons:
The lack of proper planning is glaring at times - the let's see how things go and then react attitude may work for management in terms of staying flexible but it affects the sales floor morale, stress levels and promotion path. 

US centric thinking, the company hasn't mastered the art of localisation. There's a real sense of the have and have nots.

headline: Fun place to work with plenty of opportunity once you leave
pros:
HubSpot was a window into a workplace you can actually enjoy. The employees are intelligent and fun. You have access to a snack area, beer fridge, ping pong table, games, hammocks, etc., and you learn a LOT while you're on the job.

Despite the Cons listed below, this is still a really great place to work.
cons:
Into salary is on the lower end of the scale (but by no means is it unlivable or far below average). With enough rear-kissing, you can move up, even if you're not qualified. If you're exceptionally talented, you can move up. 

Once you've worked here, you have the skills to be successful and desirable/attractive to other companies who will gladly hire you and at a hire salary than you made at HubSpot.

headline: Life as a BDR
pros: AMAZING. COLLEAGUES. They are some of the smartest people I've ever met, and the most friendly and easy-going. Definitely the kind of people that you'd like to stay in touch and stay friends even after if and when leaving HubSpot. Good job recruiting the brightest people out there!
cons:
A LOT depends on your manager, which can be good and bad. Every manager manages their team differently, and that reflects on the flexibility of where/when/how you work sometimes regardless of how much you deliver.

Also, not much of a con depending on some people, but there is a lack of teamwork in a day-to-day. Of course there are plenty of times when we reach out to others for help/guidance or confirming something, but most of the job is done alone.

headline: Overall Great Company!
pros: HubSpot invests in people, diversity, and culture. No workplace is perfect, but HubSpot is always taking serious strides to get there anyway. Very flexible workplace if you take advantage of it, and overall good experience.
cons: Intense work environment, high expectations, and work flexibility depends on your manager. Some coworkers feel judged by their managers if they don't get into the office at before 8 am or if they leave before 5 some days. (I don't personally experience this but it all depends on the team and manager you work with). HubSpot isn't as diverse or inclusive as it should be, but is working toward it.

headline: A Company That Cares
pros:
I have only been working at HubSpot for four months but I could not be more pleased. It is extremely evident that this company cares about the well being and success of its employees. Yesterday, for instance, I had a customer address me with extremely hurtful and inappropriate language. Shortly after the call, I was contacted by a fellow colleague who assured me that I did absolutely nothing wrong and that she would be following up with the customer to explain to him that he cannot treat HubSpot employees with such disrespect. If you end up deciding to work at HubSpot you will constantly have a team of amazing and talented individuals to stand up for you and guide you to success. 

Other Pros: 
*I am constantly learning new and amazing things about the inbound marketing space. 
*Unlimited Vacation & Sick Days
*AMAZING co-workers
*Room for advancement 
*The negative customer interaction that I chatted about above is extremely rare. I would say 95% of my customer interactions are extremely positive and rewarding.
cons: I have not experienced any cons.

headline: Jaded, But Thankful
pros:
The company has a great and unparalleled culture. In fact, one of the main reasons why people come to the office is to be with their peers and everyone is an expert at something.

The open work environment is great for collaborating and it's easy to speak and chat with someone for almost anything - work related or otherwise.

The folks here give a damn about their job and it's a wonder why most everyone is very successful at their jobs and stay to advance, or move on to better things.
cons:
The hustle and grind. 

It's fine to have a busy work day but for some positions, it's unreasonable to 'solve for the customer' for every customer each and every day. Some positions tout 'having the flexibility to control and manage your day' when it's simply not true with customers demanding more and more when you only have so much to give on a daily basis.

Some positions are better off than others; there's 'unbalance' between various services positions that brings one's fully booked, back-to-back day into question against someone else with 'nothing to do.' Something like that tends to decrease morale, doubt whatever fairness there is in the office, and isn't helpful to customers.

headline: Great Culture
pros: Amazing co-workers, vibrant and innovative culture, career growth opportunities and management invested in growth
cons: Work life balance turns into more of a work life blend.

headline: HubSpot
pros: Great place to work, great people and great perks
cons: A bit of a boys club

headline: Beautiful Company Inside & Out
pros:
Unlimited vacation (omg?), candy walls, well stocked pantries, lovely office space and the list goes on, but I thought I'd narrow it down to the top 3 intangibles (aka things you won't see from pictures/articles) 

1) Work life balance.
 
Love the point of 'making your work fit into your life'. It feels truly awesome going to work and doing your best with wonderful (or any adjective that's synonymous with super amazing) colleagues who tough out the day together; it ain't easy, but that's why it's fun. Why work 12 unproductive hours when you can work 8/9 good ones and enjoy the well deserved break at the end, right? 

2) Genuine effort by management to engage with staff at all levels

It is very heartening to see executives leaving personal notes on replies (eg., Glassdoor) by employees because it shows that they truly care. Beyond the gesture, I think it speaks volumes of the transparency and accessibility all employees enjoy within the company. 

3) Career development

The career development track in HubSpot is so so so clear. What I really LOVE about it is the fact that everything is so well defined through metrics, definition and time frame (as with everything else in the company actually).  The beauty of this system is it gives you ample time to prepare/gear up for the outcome, while also giving you a well structured and balanced framework to measure your current performance against the target- no ambiguity there + accountability for personal growth.
cons:
1) Feedback channels get abit messy/ convoluted

This is a tricky one because it's difficult balancing openness and feedback efficacy. The issue with having an open door policy with almost anything that goes on in the office, is that yes, you get fantastic feedback that could bring about the next big change, but on the other hand, it's getting pretty messy (with the company expanding so quickly). 

Surveys and regular 1-on-1 sessions with managers are effective in garnering qualitative responses, which are useful in identifying pain points/ suggestions. But the issue arises when qualitative responses are gathered through open channels (i.e., internal forums/ company wide surveys); discussions get increasingly lengthy and difficult to measure. Is there a way to streamline the process?  

2) Updates about the development of global offices

With the company expanding pretty rapidly, it would be great to know how the other offices are doing (i.e., growth plans / head count) because this gives employees more time to chart their career growth based off what is currently in works.

headline: Amazing company
pros:
I just started a month ago at HubSpot and was surprised how accurate the culture code is. People at HubSpot are really genuine. There are no hidden agendas (or I haven't noticed them yet). Everybody is there to help each other. 

Just a month in the C-level trusts us with a lot of information. It's impressive how transparant HubSpot is considering the cize of the organization. Employers really feel involved. Because of the expansion of the company there is great perspective for career growth. 

++ Career opportunities
++ Culture
++ Involvement management
++ Salaries
cons: Overall I'm really content with everything HubSpot is doing. But it would be good to see some improvement on the cooperation between headquarters and the EMEA office.

headline: The best of the best
pros: I've worked in great companies like LinkedIn and Microsoft and this is by far the best place I've ever worked. It's all about the culture and the transparency and autonomy it lives and breaths by. Great people across the board and growing super quick with tons of career opportunities that they deliver on. Couldn't be happier. Also, love the way they've created global roles in the company, a lot of folk in here working across multiple regions with 3 owning global departments.
cons: I really don't have any to share from my personal experience.

headline: HubSpot is the best place I've worked
pros: Of the four different companies I've worked for, HubSpot has, by far, been the best. The people are collaborative, eager to help, and not afraid to tackle hard projects. And, management puts their money where their mouths are- investing in a thriving culture (not just surface-level tech perks like candy), ardent focus on our customer experience, and transparency at all levels.
cons: The overall age of the company skews a little young. However, as we continue to scale, management is being more fleshed out with tenured professionals which helps the company to mature.

headline: Middle of the Road
pros: Hubspot does have a great culture. It seems since their growth that they do want to change and get back to the original culture
cons: Tough to move out of your department or around in general. There are a few people who have moved and they use them as the poster children

headline: Good place to work.
pros:
- The culture here is very nice. all employees are encouraged to work with passion.
- Very transparent environment.
cons:
- the salary is understandable but not competitive. 
- Autonomy is first priority so that sometime the things are messy.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Awesome benefits, awesome people, fast paced, you will never stop learning.
cons: Experiencing some growing pains, but overall I think their minds are in the right place looking to the future.

headline: Highly recommended
pros:
Great attitudes of staff - Have never heard the words 'that's not my job'. everyone is very willing to help out.
Very clearly career progression path laid out before you on day one. Pretty objective, based on your activity and output, not what somebody thinks of you.
Company growing really fast so lot's of opportunity to carve out a niche if you want.
Relationship with clients is generally based on the 'you're a human, I'm a human' basis. They appreciate our support and in return we do our best to help them overcome challenges rather than simply so 'no, we don't do that'
cons: Workload can be heavy and requires some flexibility but this is returned in freedom to work when you want and where you want, so long as you continue to meet goals and expectations.

headline: Sales Engineering
pros:
Culture
Work/Life Balance
Awesome Team!
Clear growth plans
Multinational staff
Diversity
Benefits
Perks
Sound Management
Full Transparency
Further Education, Up Skilling, Learning, etc.
Food - Catering
After Work Events
Charity Events
Team Bonding Events
Snacks
Beer & Wine
Table Tennis
Fifa Tournaments
Xbox & PlayStation
Massages
Yoga
Fitness Room
cons:
It's always a good sign when I find this section hard to write about anything...
If there was really anything, I would say the Salary for an Sales Engineer is lower than waht is on offer in the market in Dublin, however, did you see my list of Pros....

headline: Great place to work and grow your career
pros:
-No micro-management : I'm trusted to get my job done in my own way without someone breathing down my neck

-You're encouraged to keep learning and growing in your career. There's a generous education bonus, lunch and learns and a book scheme. If you decide you'd like to try something else careerwise, that's also an option (eg. support to marketing or sales)

-Great people to work with. Cross-collaboration across teams is common with people sharing their experience with others so you can learn from everyone.

-Conveniently located offices in Dublin city centre with transport access to many areas of the city

-Work life balance is great. If you need to work from home that's not an issue. If you have a family emergency then you can tend to that without guilty or stress. Generous holiday options. 

-Very flat hierarchy. People are treated like equals so a lot less pretense and posturing than at other companies I've worked at
cons:
-Some growing pains with new processes, but management are very receptive to feedback and actively listen to concerns from staff

-Thankfully in a minority, but there are a few entitled people who don't appreciate the efforts our facilities and culture teams put in to providing us with amazing benefits like free lunches, beer on tap, nights out and more

headline: Incredible people with an incredible vision
pros:
I've been at HubSpot for over 4 years and there are so many things that I love about HubSpot that it's hard to count.  The people that I work with are some of the best of breed - they're smart, creative, hard-working, helpful, and sincere.  In many ways it's inspiring and challenging in raising the bar; it also reinforces that this is the way you should feel about the people you work alongside with (ie a team).  HubSpot recruits for very particular values and has a process that is proven to work, and nurtures employees to those values to ensure they grow too.  

HubSpot's software has come so far in the years that I've been there, and is now a world-class technology stack.  The product team that we have is incredible in liaising with people on the ground so that we have a constantly evolving and improving vehicle for customers to derive growth from.  This happen - ie bugs, but they work tirelessly to do right by our customers.  This ideology of "solving for the customer" is present in every being at HubSpot, and I love that.  This means that we aren't selling something and leaving that person hanging, it's about ensuring that they know how to use it, apply it to their business, and learn from it so that they can own their own growth.  That is really powerful stuff that makes it easy to be passionate about selling.  Seeing the results that they achieve is pretty incredible too.

HubSpot also let me move to being a remote employee - I am so thankful for being given that opportunity.  If you propose an idea and it makes sense (quantitatively first, then qualitatively), HubSpot is willing to try just about anything.  That is a really empowering feeling.
cons:
Big changes happen frequently within the sales organization and the admin is sometimes difficult to transition to.  Sales team is also very political.

Selling Marketing Automation isn't easy, requires a lot of work to first learn, then qualify, differentiate, and close.  We find that 18months in is when reps start to hit their stride, and it's true.

Inbound leads only is a thing of the past - you have to prospect outside of what you are given if you want to be successful

headline: Why Work at HubSpot?
pros: Where to begin! Stock options, dental care, health care, free breakfast and lunch, continual education and training, openness of direct and upper management. HubSpot is exponentially good for benefit. The promotion path for sales is also very clear and achievable once you put the work in.
cons: The workload is heavy, but manageable. You can expect to work 10 hour days as opposed to the traditional 9-5, especially when you're starting out and trying to develop a pipeline. That said, the days go quickly as you are so busy.

headline: Incredible company for women
pros:
-HubSpot truly invests in it's employees, and allows you to chart your course as an entry level individual contributor. 
-HubSpot knows the value of diversity, and put a lot of time and resources into supporting women in the workforce.  
- HubSpot's flexibility makes it a great place to work - big part of what keeps me here
- HubSpotters are such smart, interesting people, and it is an honor to work alongside them everyday - I look forward to coming into work and seeing my colleagues
cons:
- Love my work, but work a lot 
- Not for people unwilling to chart their own course and make their own job descriptions 
- Some work to do in salary for those outside of product or sales departments

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
- Being able to speak up when you feel it's necessary and being heard
- Freedom to pursue the side projects you care about - it's great for really driven individuals
- HubSpot is an incredibly transparent company
- It's a collection of folks who love to take on big problems
- Who doesn't love free coffee?
cons:
- The pains that come with rapid growth
- If you're not a fast pace person, it might be tough

headline: INCREDIBLE place to work - Boston's Best!
pros:
- Fast-paced environment; no day is the same and the work is challenging and rewarding.
- Transparent; very few companies, whether privately held or public, share information with their employees the way HubSpot does. 
- Forward thinking, agile and responsive to the needs of our customers when it comes to our product.
- Dynamic and energizing; interesting people working collaboratively.
- Excellent perks (unlimited vacation, on-site gym, beer on tap, food, access to C-Suite)
- FUN! It's genuinely a fun place to come to work at every day.
cons: - Salaries in some roles are lower than the market average

headline: Serious period of growth
pros: This company is no longer a start up but not yet a 10k person company. This is an awesome time to be here because we have the structure of a successful, public company but we have lots of wiggle room as individual employees to explore areas of the organization. Also love that executives are accessible and information is readily available/we are transparent.
cons: Some growing pains. As we scale we're readjusting some areas and figuring some things out as we grow.

headline: Great place to learn and grow as an engineer
pros: Tons of room for growth and lots of opportunity for driven individuals. Each team really is autonomous and empowered to make their own decisions. You decide the scope of your role and how much impact you want to have. Coworkers are awesome, there is constant investment in keeping our technology up-to-date and making our engineering team as productive and happy as possible.
cons: Not necessarily for everyone. If you're just looking to be spoon-fed tasks and coast by, this probably isn't the company for you.

headline: Great Experience!
pros: Love so many things about HubSpot- the people, the growth, the benefits.
cons: So much constant change that its hard to keep up with.

headline: Great entry-level role
pros: Fantastic culture, non-hierarchical company structure, transparent promotion path for sales roles
cons: Growing pains from scaling so quickly

headline: Incredible
pros: you have a voice and are encouraged to share it from day 1.
cons: being my first "real" job it set an impossibly high bar for subsequent roles

headline: Work hard, play hard
pros:
- Excellent salary
- Extremely dynamic, fast growing company with a 'start-up' vibe
- Excellent benefits (Excellent stock purchase plan, education allowance, free Kindle books, health insurance, dental plan, free breakfast and lunch, snacks, beer on tap etc. etc.)
- Lots of passionate, smart people to learn from 
- Excellent platform team / technology stack
- Everyone is incredibly friendly - people go out of their way to make you feel at home
- No expense spared when it comes to 
- Very very transparent when it comes to business plans and progress, the management team go out of their way to give you the latest facts and figures from the Exec's
- Lots of opportunity to advance your career

I could honestly go on all day about the pro's......
cons:
- They heavily promote from within their own ranks so lots of first time managers, I don't have any negative experiences to speak of so far but it's a little risky
- They allow you to run a personality test comparison with any current employee - I find this a little disturbing, people should be able to opt out

headline: Not the time to be a hubspot employee
pros:
-Culture at hubspot is great
-compensation is competitive
cons:
-Lots of changes going on right now
-Lack of support from management  
-HubSpot prides itself on transparency - but you still feel like you don't know what is going on most of the time 
-I wouldn't recommend taking a sales role right now at Hubspot

headline: Not the time to be a hubspot employee
pros:
-Culture at hubspot is great
-compensation is competitive
cons:
-Lots of changes going on right now
-Lack of support from management  
-HubSpot prides itself on transparency - but you still feel like you don't know what is going on most of the time 
-I wouldn't recommend taking a sales role right now at Hubspot

headline: My People
pros:
1. Hubspot has values. At my first company meeting, I discovered Hubspot hired Ta-Nehisi Coates to speak at their yearly conference. If you don't know Ta-Nehisi Coates, he writes about being a Black man and a Black father in the United States. You can't have a speaker like Ta-Nehisi Coates and feign indifference. Being someone who also cares about Black people and issues of racism, I was so grateful I started crying at the company meeting. Hubspot was willing to ruffle feathers and lose business to stand behind someone they believe in. It was refreshingly honorable.

2. Hubspot hires people who are both sharp and kind. At almost every job I've had, someone has always made me feel small or uncomfortable. At Art.com, a woman would completely ignore me whenever I'd try and communicate. I'd try to talk to her in the hallway and she'd act like I'm invisible. It made me feel horrible and it made me incredibly inefficient at my job. At Hubspot, I've never met someone I haven't liked. Consequently, I'm a happy person, I collaborate easily with new people, and I'm efficient in getting work done.

3. Hubspot is a big company with a small company feel. Big companies get overly political and bureaucratic. Culture is often lost and you quickly become a bee in a hive-slogging through process after process to get your job done or to accomplish any HR task. You feel like your voice is lost. Hubspot has maintained an incredibly friendly, free atmosphere as a 1500 person company. There is a shared culture of getting things done, putting ones ego aside, and asking questions. Everyone is responsive and accessible from the Head of Culture to the VP of Product. You're empowered to do what's best for your team and to lead your own charge in your own way.

4. Hubspot has great design managers. It's common to promote the loudest, most extroverted, outspoken people. Hubspot is different in that they promote a variety of personalities into management positions. My boss is a soft spoken, incredibly empathetic person. His boss (the head of our department) is a super creative, nurturing type who's always looking ahead and reexamining the way we work to ensure we get what we need. My therapist says I've never been this happy. She says all this time, I've just been looking for a good manager.

So what about that Disrupt article that guy wrote-the one that talks about how Hubspot is a frat house filled with 20-year-olds? Here is what I can say:

- I had read the article and I was skeptical about the seemingly very young people who interviewed me.
- They won me over in minutes with their smarts and lack of ego (to me, this has nothing to do with age).
- I've never experienced any of that fratty behavior in Product.
cons: I moved to Cambridge from Oakland, California. Winter is cold. I could do without the winter.

headline: Senior Inbound Marketing Specialist
pros: Great benefits, nice culture and great product. They also hire very smart people which keep you wanting to improve and grow.
cons: Fast pace, so I do not recommend it to people that do not like constant change. There are lots of new initiatives that can pan out great or go completely bust. If you join one that go bust, be ready to potentially go down with it.

headline: A great place to learn and grow
pros:
The culture is amazing, the learning and growth opportunities are endless, and the people are great.

Management is awesome. They try to know everyone by name and do a really great job of keeping tabs on the state of the office and the product. And since they have such an ear to the ground approach, they are always open to suggestions and questions.
cons: Housing! It was so hard to find housing for 6 months, especially since I knew nothing about the area. HubSpot, please do something to make sure your coops have housing!

headline: What the *&^ is wrong with this place? (Hint: all the right things.)
pros:
*Transparency*
HubSpot shares all company performance data, financials, and executive meeting notes with all staff. Other companies don’t do that. Other companies hoard, and filter, and release bitesize chunks of “digestible” information to their frontlines. But HubSpot's commitment to transparency means that every employee deeply understands how the company works, why the strategy is what it is, and why our execs make the decisions they do. It also empowers every employee to knowledgeably identify opportunities to improve the company — our founders openly share their thought processes (and their concerns and their blindspots) because they want everyone at HubSpot to have a founder’s mindset. You’ll learn more about business, leadership and decision-making in 1 year at HubSpot than you could at any business school.

*Dynamism*
Our leadership team refuses to fall into complacency. Good is not good enough. Even if we’re beating the industry average on some measure, if they know we can do better, they will push us to do better. They’re not afraid to break what works in order to find something better. Other companies would be happy to make small tweaks to earn incremental progress. At HubSpot, you’ll learn best practices, but you’ll also learn to constantly challenge the status quo, whether that’s around sales tactics, go-to-market strategy, product innovation, or customer service. 

*Professional Growth*
Many entry-level employees will start with concrete tasks and a clear plan, but as you grow, you will increasingly have to define your own roadmap. You will be expected to experiment (and fail), you will be expected to digest as much knowledge as possible (through coffee chats and devouring the internal company wiki), and you will be expected to take advantage of unlimited free books and thousands of dollars available to support classes/training. Other companies puts people in boxes and make them climb a pre-defined ladder; HubSpot takes a build-your-own-adventure (with some guardrails) approach to professional growth. 

*Autonomy*
Use good judgement. Take as much vacation as you need. Work from wherever you are. And get sh*t done. The results you produce matter more than whether you’ve followed every instruction in some hundred-page employee handbook (see: other companies). Some people prefer structure, rigid expectations, clear lines of authority, etc. — there’s nothing wrong with that, but that’s not HubSpot. If you like freedom + delivering on high expectations, you’ll thrive at HubSpot.
cons:
Many of the things that make HubSpot great are also the things that can be frustrating.

*Autonomy*
Lots of autonomous individuals and teams acting in loose harmony can lead to duplicative efforts — e.g., two smart people both recognize an opportunity and chase after it without “someone in charge” recognizing that they’re doing the same thing.

*Transparency*
Holy torrent of information. Given how much information and data is made available, it’s sometimes hard to know what I should know and care about. At best, this can simply be a time suck; at worst, it can be overwhelming.

*Manager Growing Pains*
As the company as grown rapidly, we’ve promoted a number of first-time managers. Young staff look up and say, “Hey. I could be at least as good as that manager!” Which leads to frustration, more inexperienced managers, and misaligned expectations about what professional growth should look like at its best. I think we've recently made a number of good investments to alleviate some of this pain.

I understand that these downsides are inevitable given the choices we’ve made. I wouldn’t have chosen differently.

headline: Good place to work, decent career progression, sometimes a bit hectic!
pros:
* Great perks: free hot breakfast/lunch, beer on tap, lovely offices, health, dental, stock... etc.
* Great colleagues: most people are friendly, helpful and open.
* Room for career progression: they're pretty helpful in trying to get you to the next level.
* Autonomy: "unlimited" holidays, the ability to work from home, flexible hours... etc. Just get the job done!
cons: * Work/life balance: they hire overachievers and so the culture is a bit of a workaholic one. However, it can be manages if you're good with time management and saying no.

headline: Software Engineer Intern
pros:
Lovely people. Small autonomous teams. Treated as equal with full-time engineers. Could discuss design decisions and what the best approach is. You're not just thrown in the corner, playing with cardboard boxes. Really good place to intern at.
+Free Lunch and Breakfast
cons: Was an uncertainty to the level expected of Interns.

headline: An impressive company with a strong future.
pros: Intelligent employees, brand recognition helps in sales, fun environment and a great launching pad for a software career. Fun environment and definitely easier to appreciate for younger members of the work force.
cons: Don't quite drink their own cool-aid as much as they say regarding marketing and sales processes. Training has become a bit outdated for their product and market. Clearly I'm really picking to find cons.

headline: Hard to find your feet, but very rewarding.
pros: Great people to work with. Fantastic offices and amenities. Autonomy to work on projects I think will positively impact the company. Amazing parties and yearly conference. Top of the line tech. Truly believes in unlimited vacation (if one gets their work done). In the 2016 year, I took 20 days vacation with less than 2 years service. Given time to explore different solutions, trusted to find the best. Everyone is pleasant, which is a first for me after 10 years in Boston tech industry. C-level executives available to talk.
cons: Not everyone is a good fit. People can join and leave quickly. Finding a support structure is very important for when time gets tough. HubSpot is a 'drink the kool-aid' company. The company skews very young, but is improving.

headline: Best place I've ever worked
pros: Fantastic work/life balance, brilliant colleagues, dog friendly
cons: Interview process can be lenghthy, not my experience though

headline: A Great Place to do Your Best Work
pros: I stole the title of this review from our COO - but I really believe in it.  HubSpot is a place where people really pour their heart into their work.  Many do it because they believe in HubSpot's mission, some do it because they believe in their team and their coworkers, others because they want to succeed personally.  But the one common thread with everyone I've reported to, worked alongside, and even hired, was the passionate commitment to doing their best work here.  This has led to me, specifically, experiencing an incredible amount of personal growth - as I'm constantly learning from amazingly wise and intelligent people.
cons: HubSpot's grown rapidly over the last several years, and despite our 'startup like culture' (which is a phrase that has become ubiquitous and meaningless) HubSpot is a big company.  Our cultural values have helped us maintain a high bar for employees, but there's a near-constant battle being fought against complacency, routine, and excessive process.  You really do drive your own success here, but you'll occasionally need to carry the weight of others on the way to the top.  If you come in with the expectation that HubSpot is a mythical unicorn that every employee rides off into the sunset, you will be disappointed.  You need to work hard, and put up with the occasional amount of bulls*%&.

headline: Always Learning & Growing
pros:
HubSpot is in its 10th year as a company, and is really hittings its stride.  Other the years we've really learned a lot as a a company and as a culture.  There's room to grow in ones career, make lateral movement, try new things, hear your ideas be heard, and so much more.  

The culture is one of a kind, as well as the people within.
cons: HubSpot isn't a corporate company, in terms of culture.  There's a lot of autonomy and not a lot of strict black and white rules.  If you're looking for that structure, this place will be a tough transition.  It's up to the individual and the employees as a whole to ensure everything runs smoothly.

headline: Still in Love After 6 Years
pros:
In my 6 years at HubSpot there's been an incredible evolution from 170 to well over a thousand employees.  We've gone from a scrappy startup to a legit business. 

While quite a lot has changed, the reason I joined is the reason I stay - I'm constantly surrounded by bright, engaged, dedicated colleagues.  People who work at HubSpot really care about the company and we've continued to attract exceptional talent.  

What this means for me is that, while the business has evolved, I've never had to have a meeting with a manager who's too busy to help or a colleague who's disengaged.  This is a drama-free environment because the people who work at HubSpot are here quite voluntarily. 

HubSpot is generous with employees - but it's not over the top.  Motivation to be work here is largely *intrinsic.* We're not here for a free breakfast, lunch and dinner, free dry cleaning, or whatever nonsense other tech companies divert into retaining employees.  I find my managers, my colleagues and my team are here because they love the work.

And when you enjoy your work and the people you work with, it's an awesome place to forge a career.
cons: As we grow, it's been difficult to keep track of what's going on across the business.  This is a little disorienting because I had been used to better understanding all of the moving parts.

headline: This company gets it
pros:
Hubspot is a company that really thinks about how modern people work, how to get the best out of them and how to ensure they feel fulfilled in their role. 

Read the Culture code to get a feel for what Hubspot is about.

I've now been an employee for a year and I can tell you that they really do stick to their culture code and when they don't, they admit it and work to correct it. 

So many pros!

- Recognition for work
- Smart, kind and caring people, no matter which department
- Challenging work
- Have not seen workplace politics
- Amazing offices, in great cities
- Many external speakers are invited in, to share their insights
- Learning is strongly encouraged 
- Opportunities to grow, if you want it
- Flexible work hours for most roles
- Clear goals and transparency from the top down 
- Regular office events
- International footprint
- Hubspot is growing like crazy which is a great time to work for any company
- Ping Pong! Free Beer! Candy walls! Waffle Wednesdays! EOM Pizza! I hope you have strong willpower
cons:
None that I have experienced so far. 

If you have a problem, you have many avenues to voice your opinion. Quarterly employee NPS, weekly feedback apps or you could just talk to your manager, who is always willing to listen and help.

headline: Manager
pros:
- Great career growth opportunities but also the support from the team to achieve the growth
- Challenging, fast paced, work environment
- Personal flexibility (time off, WFH, bring your dog to work)
-The people
cons: -Sometimes people who don't enjoy the fast pace environment join the team which means that HubSpot isn't a great fit for them

headline: Great company
pros: Great product, smart people, high ambition to grow and develop as a company
cons:
Sometimes things go a bit to fast and things might not always be thought through all the way before making a change. On the other hand hubspot is quick to learn adapt. 

It's a high performance company with high expectations on their sales reps. But that's what we sign up for so not really a con...

headline: Inbound Marketing Specialist
pros: Great people, involved culture, great benfits
cons: No cons, loved my time there

headline: Software Engineer
pros: * You can have dogs in the office
cons:
First things first, they tell everyone at the company meetings to go on here and rate 5 stars, take the reviews here with some salt.

* Slightly below market rate pay
* Laughably horrible 401k match
* "We deploy 300 times a day" means "we expect you to get a lot of work done, do all your own QA, and then get paged in the middle of the night when something goes wrong"
* Excessive focus on the stock price
* "We don't care how long you're in the office, only that you get your work done" means spending more time in the office, not less
* Their biggest expense is people, and it shows in ugly ways when they're reducing costs
* Office is cramped and provides no privacy
* Witnessed some unethical, borderline illegal behavior in support and product groups

headline: It's all about the people
pros: My biggest driving factor in joining (and staying) at HUBS is that I'm surrounded by people who are smarter than I am. Good conversations. Good challenges. Good coffee
cons: Lechmere isn't the easiest for public transportation.

headline: Great place to work on the web
pros:
* Leadership cares about employee well-being and success
* Technical challenges are interesting, lots of scale and hard problems with distributed systems
* You own your success as an engineer
* Modern tech stack and platform
cons:
* There are a lot of dogs in the office
* Some people seem more interested in the perks and work/life balance than building something remarkable

headline: Grow and help others Grow
pros: Really great environment to learn and grow - and to help others do the same.  The commitment to the purpose of helping customers grow is palpable.  It finds it's way into every conversation and every decision across all functions and levels within the company.  The obvious reason to be committed to this purpose is because it means we at HubSpot will grow too, but it's deeper than that.  There is a strong belief that we are changing the way the world chooses to engage in commerce...and the "we" driving this change is an awesome group of talented, quirky, driven, and giving game-changers.
cons: Having lived in many other company cultures, it's hard to find a con.  Other reviews talk about the pace of change, the high levels of accountability, the expectation that you'll simply need to get great work done fast - these are all challenges certainly, but if that's what you are looking for, you'll find it.

headline: Amazing Place to Work, and to launch a career!
pros:
Culture: Everything I read about the HubSpot culture code was accurate. The company does a great job of hiring incredible people and creating an environment where they can thrive. As a new employee I had the opportunity to actively add to the culture here. 




Growth: There is many paths you can take through out the company, and management actively supports you growth. The resources provided allow us to grow with in our role but also earn valuable education/skills that can be transferred anywhere. I started with almost no technical skill but have found a passion for it here and I continue to make progress.
cons: none so far. But a West Coast office would be great!

headline: Renewal Manager!
pros: The Renewal Management team is a great team to be on. We are a new team but growing very quickly. It is always exciting to be a part of something new. Obviously there are some growing pains but the process has been built out extremely well for us.
cons: None that I can see right now!

headline: HubSpot Intern
pros: Great internship program. They truly valued my work and gave me great opportunities.
cons: No major cons for this internship.

headline: Best place I've worked.
pros: Smartest people in the industry work here, agile teams, still feels like a startup. People and product focused.
cons: Culture can feel cliquish to new employees, I've heard, but with the caveat that it's no different from any other mid-sized tech company in that regard.

headline: One Of The Best Account Management/Consulting Jobs In ANZ
pros:
- Amazing culture 
- Made me a better professional from day 1 
- Best perks (Unlimited holidays, flexability to work from home as long as you get the work done etc) 
- HubSpot's culture is well known but Sydney's culture is something different all together. Amazing
- The thorough recruitment process means everyone in the office is on the same page and working towards the same goal
cons:
- It's not a 9-5 job, you're constantly plugged in 
- You have to bring you A game every day as everyone is extremely talented (not necessarily a con if you have what it takes!)
- Daily pressure from multiple accounts

headline: Account Executive
pros: Great work environment, and excellent opportunities for internal upward mobility. Fast pace of product development makes for great up-sell and cross-sell opps across your book of business. Access to sales leadership, and training is second to none. Great place to cut your teeth and hone your sales skills. Awesome company vision.
cons: If you are not flexible in your work style, the fast pace of change, development, and product releases can be overwhelming. I see it as a positive however.

headline: Gave me hope in the corporate world
pros:
Being my second job out of college, HubSpot completely changed my view on what a job is. This place makes me exited to go to work everyday. 

Great people, challenging job and amazing culture throughout the company.
cons: Few, but sometime going the extra mile is not recognized in specific positions.

headline: Heaven Found!
pros: Have you ever thought of a place that you would actually love to wake up for? That's as simple and as close to the reality of how amazing this place is. Bright and yet humble people, with a great product that is changing the way we work with each other in the market, to get it more efficient. It feels really good to be part of the work that is being done and thought for the next years and years to come!
cons: I can't even think of one - I've been mulling it over...nothing...let's keep doing more of what we're doing!

headline: Onwards and Upwards!
pros: Great company to work for. Perks aside, you get to work with some extremely smart people who are encouraged by the organization to set and go after SMART - Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Timely - goals.  Management takes great effort in being transparent with employees. Fun Fact - This is probably the only company that has a culture code deck that runs in excess of 150 pages. You have to check it out.
cons: If you are the kind of person that enjoys cruising in a job, this is not the place to be. Be prepared to be challenged and work long hours. Yes! you will fail from time to time, but you will be expected to rise up and crush it the next time.

headline: Good Job
pros: Coworkers, perks, flexible schedule, relaxed environment, culture.
cons: Pay, management structure (growing pains).

headline: Go work at HubSpot
pros: Great environment , good connection between management and staff.Very much word hard/play hard. First class training . Fantastic career move.
cons: Stress and high staff turnover. Compensation is excellent but they demand HIGH achievement. If you fall below that , you're done.

headline: A Wonderful Place to Grow a Career
pros: HubSpot is a great place to work! Working in a fast-paced tech start-up gives me the opportunity to learn something new each day, and tailor my goals/interests into a career path. Also, the culture is fantastic. Everyone is very supportive of each other, and always willing to share knowledge.
cons: I cannot think of any!

headline: Amazing place to work
pros: I have worked in the software industry for a lot of years, in both startups and corporate. I joined HubSpot less than a year ago in Dublin and I literally pinch myself every day, as to how I got so lucky to join such an amazing company. I know it sounds a little unbelievable but there is no politics and everyone is hugely talented and interested in just doing a good job. In my experience of other corporates - that is not always the case. People are so friendly, supportive and generally fabulous (and fun) to work with. I don't think some of the younger employees, who haven't worked in other companies, realize how good they have it!
cons: The company is focusing on diversity and this needs to continue - we need more grey hairs!

headline: Excellent culture, amazing people, long hours
pros: HubSpot is an incredibly fun place to work. You're a part of some of the most interesting conversations around marketing in the 21st century, and you're having them with incredibly smart and driven people. Culture amazing, pay is decent, workplace is energetic and coworkers are great. Really enjoy working here.
cons: Certain teams (especially within Sales) tend to be somewhat culturally exclusive, though that might be expected. The work/life balance can seem a bit tough, as everybody is expected to work long hours.

headline: Love telling people about where I work
pros: Really great company to get a career in tech started. Entry level Support position is a great way to learn the product and there a lot of opportunities for advancement past that.
cons: The pay could be better. They scale you up quick though with a 5k raise after 6 months and another 5k raise at the 1 yr mark.

headline: Challenging Work, a lot of transparency
pros: Good Perks, Pay is a bit low, work is challenging
cons: Pay Is a bit low, career growth can be unclear at time

headline: Time flies when you're having fun: 2 years flew by like 2 weeks
pros:
HubSpot is always improving - the motto "If its not broken why fix it" DOES NOT apply here - teams across the company are always working to make HubSpot the best place to work in the world and that is the #1 Pro in my book 

To name a few of my other favorites: 
Transparency from senior management
Exceptionally smart people 
Exceptional diversity across teams 
Unlimited Vacation Policy 
Great office space
Clear promotion + compensation path
Fantastic benefits
Best of class technology and tech support 
Access to senior management (Director, VPs, and C-levels) 
Co-founders consistently in the office hard at work 
Dog-friendly office
Possibilities for internal job movement/ promotion 
Gym in the office + fitness discounts in Boston
cons: Is having too much fun at work a con? What about having too many friends at work? OR What about there being too many puppies in the office?!

headline: Balance. Yes, it's possible.
pros:
As a 40-something in the fast-paced, ever-changing world of tech, current sentiment would be that it's near-impossible to succeed in your role as professional AND a parent. Luckily, at HubSpot, that's top of mind for the company and I can honestly I'm making it work. There are flexible workplaces on paper and there are flexible workplaces in practice. I work at the latter. Halloween party at in the afternoon at daycare? I'm there. Child sick? Work from home. Vacation? I take it. Really. There are no weird looks. There is only acceptance and support from my team and colleagues. I can't say how much that makes me want to work harder and give my all.

Which leads me to the work. It's challenging. It's collaborative. It's evolving, which is a good thing for those who like change, and perhaps scary for those who want solid footing in knowing exactly what their day will look like. But it's always "all hands on deck" to solve a problem, to get to a goal, to make things work. 

Which leads me to the people. They're smart. Really smart. But they're consistently GOOD people. I find the more people you talk to at HubSpot, the more you find they hire people who care about others, who are curious, and who want to do what's right. 

Also, great opportunities for international collaboration; autonomous project development (passion projects); employment benefits like wellness programs, food, learning stipends, etc.
cons:
HubSpot is growing (really) fast and is a SaaS company that serves the mid-market (SMBs), which means it lives in a precarious situation of being a bit of an outlier that has to figure things out without proofs of concept out there in the world. That may be scary to some people.

Growing pains, though normal, mean that organizations within the company may need to re-org from time to time. Again, not an issue for someone who embraces change, but could be disruptive to certain personalities.

headline: I never knew how "meh" my old jobs were until I joined HubSpot
pros:
- The people are some of the brightest I've ever met
- The transparency from top-down is shocking and awesome
- I have never been more excited (or less sad) to wake up on a Monday
- HubSpot is actively working on their culture and their employees
- Free books program is remarkable
- Tuition reimbursement proves that HubSpot really does want the best for employees
cons: It seems like the employees over-emphasizes tenure. "How long have you been at HubSpot" is a common ice-breaker and those who state the longest have an odd sense of bravado. It's even plastered on several display screens around the office. "The pre-IPO days" are reminisced upon as if they were ages ago and those who came afterwards missed out on the good-ol-days.

headline: Intern
pros: Able to see a start up turn successful and work in an open environment. Food always available, with a gym, nap room and more.  If you do your work, you have the freedom that you want.
cons: Depending on the position, you may only be involved ad hoc jobs.

headline: Smart, driven, passionate, challenging and rewarding.
pros: Amazing people and an amazing culture will enable you to achieve amazing things. You will be rewarded if you are a star. Company is not stingy about equity compensation when you deliver but you will work for it. Huge opportunities to learn and grow.
cons: You will be among stars so be prepared to be humbled. You will not be the smartest person in the room. The market the company competes in is highly competitive and getting more intense. It's unclear whether the incredible culture will remain through the challenging times ahead. Like all software/tech companies the diversity is substantially lacking but the company's management is very aware and working hard to improve.

headline: Losing Focus on Employees
pros: Used to be a great place to work where you could work hard and play hard with coworker and manager alike - a lot of camaraderie. Now, it feels like more of a work hard or harder kind of place.
cons: Don't feel valued by management. Trainings are solely focused on product changes; there's absolutely no focus on career advancement or employee growth. Feels like you need to know someone in other departments in order to branch out within the organization career-wise.

headline: Sales
pros: Free food, young environment, good location, great salary.
cons:
Targets unrealistic - need to be addressed
Poor management - little to no training/support  when people are below target
Training in Boston is torture - worse than a month in prison
Drink their own kool-aid - brainwashed
It's like the Wild Wild West in there - robbing leads etc.
Holidays.. very hard to get.. c'mon guys.. people need a BREAK! even when they are underperforming
I could go on forever....

headline: Support Engineer
pros: After going on many interviews with a lot of companies I must say that the process with Hubspot has been the most positive/rewarding. Everyone I spoke to (8+ people) were so kind and really seemed to love the company and their job. The company offers unlimited vacation days and a positive environment filled with candy walls, video games, and beer on tap. HR is completely transparent throughout the process and very compassionate especially when being compared to that of other companies. Overall I would recommend Hubspot to any passionate individual who is interested in marketing, technology, and working with smart, driven individuals.
cons: If you do not live in the Cambridge/Portsmouth areas it may be hard to relocate.

headline: HubSpot Sales
pros: Great work life balance and strong management at the top. Awesome product touching various parts of the marketing funnel. People help each other across departments willingly.
cons: Some issues with rapidly growing sales team. Lots of switching of managers and territories can cause friction. VAR / Partner team struggling to work deals with HubSpot internal sales teams.

headline: Happy Employee
pros: Collaborative, open workplace fostering a culture of innovation. Truly feel like employees are all working toward a common goal and fully vested in the future mission of the company.
cons: Would love the chance to earn performance based bonuses

headline: Great company, exciting future head
pros: I've been working at HubSpot full time for several years now -- and never before have I been as excited about the future.  The company is in the midst of transitioning from a single (marketing) product company to having multiple products and -- most importantly -- a free CRM that we expect to be widely adopted.  The product is great and fun to image where we can take it.  The energy and excitement around the office is remarkable and hasn't changed from my starting days pre-IPO.
cons: As with any company that's growing rapidly -- with multiple offices around the world, new products and new go-to-market models -- there is some growing pains.  For many 'managers' this is their first time managing someone, and sometimes they're not great at it.  Additionally always staying on the same page about everything that is going on can be tough and while people try to always post to the wiki, that's hard to keep up with.

headline: Hubspot
pros: Super smart hard working people - and super nice.
cons: Competitive - we opened a new market and it didn't work out - so I didn't have the numbers to show to move to another role.

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: My HubSpot experience was an exceptional one; tons of people to learn from, at all levels of the company, and my career is the better for it.  The company has a can-do, GSD culture that will set you up for success in the future.
cons: Especially on the sales side, things do get a little bit bro-y.  It's an odd feeling seeing a 22 year old grabbing a beer from the taps in the kitchen -- at lunch -- and I think that there could be more proactive steps taken to address that type of thing.

headline: Being a part of a brilliant team
pros: Amazing company culture, emphasis on transparency, trust, huge potential for upward mobility, networking
cons: Starting salary--but there is so much room to grow

headline: sales
pros: exciting compay to enter the market
cons: bad sales model, a bit to fond of themselves

headline: Overall great experience at a rapidly growing company
pros:
-Amazing coworkers
-Great product for the most part
-Benefits package is impressive
-Get to be part of a real industry leader
cons:
-Pay advancement is not clear
-Inexperienced managers
-Other typical start up pains

headline: Channel Consultant
pros: Fast paced, always challenging but inspiring place to work.
cons: Long hours. Life/work balance can be a challenge.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
I've been reading a lot of the reviews here and paying attention to 'Cons' part. Some people aren't happy that you have to work very hard, or that HubSpot has a specific culture, or that you're promised X but get Y - not something that I've experienced.

I get that as companies grow there will be some pains and because we're dealing with people.. you can't please everyone, but people need to take a step back and stop venting - we're all human and trying really hard to make a fantastic working environment. 

Unless you've worked some crappy jobs (and I have) than I don't think you can appreciate just how much we're given.

I'm also a little confused why some people are upset about working hard: You get out what you put in, particularly if you're in sales. The amount of support, training and help you get is outstanding. It's the only company that I've ever worked in where you have: free food, gym, an onsite trainer, where you can ask any manager for help and get it, you can ask any team member for help... and get it, you can ask the tech team for help and they solve the problem within minutes - this doesn't happen in other companies!

Additionally, the perks are better than most other companies: free food/drink, alcohol, games room, education, training, gym... the list goes on.

Pros
- Best solution on the market
- Fantastic working environment
- Competitive environment
- Very talented employees
- Food/Drink etc
- Great CEO who speaks to you like he appreciates what you're doing for him and the company
- Really nice people who care about their job
- Great opportunities for upskilling and career path is set in front of you
cons:
- Brian Halligan needs to stop saying "top of the mornin' to ye" when he's on the radio in Ireland - nobody in Ireland says that.
- Where the hell is the ping pong table in the new Dublin office?
- Sometimes too many meetings
- The free beer runs out too often. Also, while I'm on this subject: the keg room isn't refrigerated so when we have to (manually - there should be a robot that does this for us) change the kegs, the fresh beer is warm - this must be fixed. Btw, thanks for changing the taps
- Not enough women on the sales side. I understand that this is because far less women apply for a sales roles, but it would be nice

headline: Amazing place to start a career
pros: Internal mobility if you succeed at your current role, and seek out networking opportunities within the organization. Not to mention unlimited vacation, a great 401k policy, etc. Great coaching and mentorship opportunities as well.
cons: Only domestic office is located in Boston, which can often be a bummer for those of us looking to get a bit more out of our comfort zone

headline: Outstanding and fun place to work!
pros:
- Working with extremely smart, yet humble, people
- Exciting product that is disrupting the marketing world
- Fantastic C-level leadership
- Transparency
- They treat you like an adult (working from home, unlimited vacation, etc.)
cons:
- Sometimes the working hours could run well into the night (I had clients in Japan and Australia, and had to work at 9pm for client calls)
- Moving internally around different departments is encouraged, but you better know what you're getting into, as if you don't excel in your new role, there are always 15-20 potential hires chomping at the bit to replace you

headline: Great
pros: Time I work at home I have my on hours the job is fabulous  I wouldn't have it any other way
cons:
No cons great place to work fabulous  so happy I think  I'm blessed to have this opportunity  so thankful. .
.

headline: Great Company
pros: Fantastic vision, product, management and colleagues. HubSpot provides a competitive environment where hard work is rewarded. Employees are extremely helpful and transparency is high.
cons: With growth comes constant change and associated pains. While the general trend is improvement, some changes cause strain on certain areas of the business and have caused problems in the past and present.

headline: Best software employer in Dublin
pros:
Unlike a lot of other bigger companies, HubSpot has a product & engineering team in Dublin that does real work. Core components of their business are developed here--it's not just some satellite office that does reliability.

They have very good pay, good benefits, a very nice office, and just an all-round great team here.
cons: Ever since it's gone public and as the company has grown, a little bit of corporate-ness is creeping in. The "startup" feeling is slowly leaving the company. People are in place to try to combat that, but there's a limit to how much they can really do.

headline: HubSpot is everything I could have imagined...and more!
pros:
- career growth: my manager and coworkers are great mentors and genuinely want to help me grow my career and learn each and every day. 
- perks: unlimited vacation, food, beer, nap room, gym, Equinox classes, AMAZING PEOPLE AND CULTURE! 
- immediate impact: I started at HubSpot about 8 months ago and I immediately felt like I had an immediate impact on my team and the company. It's truly amazing how each and every segment of this company is important. Each department feeds off one another to operate this amazing organization and product. 
- transparency!!
cons: compared to other similar companies it seems like our compensation is lower. However, the perks HubSpot has really does outweigh any small gap in compensation.

headline: Able to make a huge impact early in my career
pros:
I think the thing I love most about HubSpot is that it's at a place where we're established enough to have the resources and the wisdom of a company that's figured out what we're doing, but still small enough that a single person can make an enormous impact. For a designer like me, that's huge. At a larger company, like Facebook or Google, I'd never have as much autonomy to make the design decisions that I currently do as the sole designer for my piece of the HubSpot software. That's given me an incredible opportunity to grow my craft and has made me so invested in the part of the product that I work on.

Besides that, the people I work with, especially my immediate team, are fantastic people - they genuinely care about their coworkers, the company, and the product we're building, they're smart, they're helpful, and they have good senses of humor. I couldn't imagine a better group of people to work next to every day. In addition, I've never had a problem with work life balance at HubSpot - I set boundaries for myself before I started working full time (like not working on nights or weekends except in extreme circumstances, not responding to emails or chats after hours, etc). Of course it's easier for my role, since I don't have to be on call like engineers do in case something breaks, but I've found that my coworkers are very respectful of my work hours.

In general, HubSpot is a fantastic place to work, and I'm incredibly happy at my job.
cons: Things change as the company gets bigger, and as it gets bigger it gets a little harder to make sure the right information gets around to the right people. There are a few growing pains like that, but they certainly pale in comparison to the pros.

headline: BDR
pros: Great culture and awesome people that really  push you to grow and reach for your absolute potential
cons: I do not have any so far

headline: Business Development Representative
pros:
Working with awesome people
Clear path to promotion
Everyone willing to help if you work hard
cons: High expectations - starting pay is low

headline: Excellent for people looking to grow their careers
pros:
I've been at HubSpot for a little over 6 months now. Leaving my last job I wanted to make sure I was going to a company that I could grow in and learn a lot.
During my interview I was quick to admit that I would have a lot of questions in order to learn more and get to the point where I would be a strong contributor to my team and to the company. I was nervous that saying this would make them want to go with someone else. Perhaps, someone with more experience. The two people interviewing me told me that anyone I ended up working with would be more than happy to mentor me, they weren't kidding.
I have been overjoyed with the amount of guidance and support I've received from everyone on my team since I started.
Not only my manager but every single team member takes the time to answer any questions I have and help me out with anything I may need. 
This type of accepting and collaborative environment is truly amazing. 

Since I started my manager has worked with me tirelessly to make sure I'm working towards a promotion and feel that I'm growing in my current position. She is always telling me what I'm doing right and what I can improve on. The constant communication, mixed with praise and criticism, is exactly what I need in order to succeed. 

The benefits and culture are an added bonus. Nothing beats having the flexibility to work from home and take days off when I need to. A lot of people that I talk to about HubSpot ask about how realistic Unlimited Vacation is. To answer that question, it is very realistic. As long as you are getting your work done then taking time off will not be a problem.

Other perks are a gym onsite thats open 24/7, only for HubSpotters, that includes multiple different classes every week, fresh fruit and veggies daily, constant communities service opportunities, lots of social/team building outings, and so much more.

I could go on forever about the perks of working here but what is most important is what I mentioned first. People actually care about helping you grow your career and getting you to where you want to go. You don't see that many places but you definitely see it here. 
Coming to work every day is easy when you believe in the company and the company supports you.
cons:
Lot's of perks can be distracting.
You have to know how to manage work and play. 
It is easy to get caught up in fun things that the culture team plans but you need to know when to say no and focus on your work. 
It can be difficult at first to find this balance and if you don't find it you obviously wont succeed.

headline: Amazing place to learn, grow, and start a career
pros: I've been working at HubSpot since I graduated college a few years ago and can't really imagine being anywhere else. Since day 1, I've been given complete trust in my work and projects. I started on the marketing team doing everything from writing email copy to creating offers and ebooks, to publishing blog posts, to coming up with social campaigns to promote HubSpot's global presence. There's always something to work on and anyone can say "I think this is an important project so I'm going to lead it and see what happens".
