I didn't realize how rare that was for a recent grad to be able to do until I talked to friends of mine who were working on things that would never actually be customer-facing. The biggest reason though I've been able to succeed in that environment is because of the people, particularly managers. I've read a lot on Glassdoor and other platforms about HubSpot's management, and while I can only speak to my experience, I've had amazing managers my past 4 years here. They know when to be hands-on and hands-off, and they don't just manage, they're impressive individual contributors which has made me work harder. Beyond managers, the people here are great. They go above and beyond to teach (someone led intro to HTML and coding classes during lunch time for anyone who wanted to learn and it was super helpful), and I truly enjoy being around them. People I work with are wacky, quirky, and kind. I'm going on 4 years here and I'm excited for what's next!
cons: There are some growing pains like any company and things still being figured out, but I think that's normal.

headline: Amazing Career Growth, Culture & Leadership
pros:
I've been working at HubSpot for over two years and the career opportunities that I have been afforded have been nothing short of amazing. HubSpot is a fast paced, energetic environment and if you put your hand up to get involved with projects that help with the growth of the company, you can be given the opportunity to make an impact. 

I love how HubSpot has become a truly global company in the years since I've joined and there are no barriers when it comes to opportunities for collaboration. I work daily with colleagues at our US HQ and very often with my counterparts in our Sydney and Singapore offices which can be so insightful in terms of cultural perspectives and has been wonderful for my own professional development. 

Some of my favourite benefits/perks that make my job even more enjoyable or show that HubSpot cares about my growth & well-being:

- Annual Gym Reimbursement
- Tuition Reimbursement (night classes to up-skill in my new role at a top university) 
- On-site massages
- Free book program

The most valuable benefit of all is working with some of the most hardworking and inspiring individuals I know!
cons: The interview process can be tough but it is designed to see if the opportunity could be as good of a fit for you as you could be for HubSpot.

headline: HubSpot
pros: Great people, great food and environment
cons: Management is all over the place

headline: Great for experience, not for advancement
pros: Fun, dynamic environment. Work with (some of!) the best.
cons: Hierarchy of politics. Don't get on the wrong side of the fence. High turnover.

headline: Great Company
pros: Fast growing, always improving.  Individual autonomy and freedom to develop the best ideas.  Recognizes and values smart, GSD people.
cons: Growing and organizational pains, although that's an area of focus.  Diversity is pretty weak.

headline: Performance is key
pros: Super sales process. Have processes worked out for most sales and marketing activities. Excellent transparency in terms of performance related growth/promotions/plans. Clear understanding of what you need to do to succeed.
cons: HR policies still being built out

headline: Incredibly impressed
pros: Before coming to HubSpot, I thought that there was no way a company could be this great. But it is. The combination of flexibility, autonomy, awesome coworkers, awesome management, and clearly-defined promotional paths is just the tip of the iceberg. Going deeper, you'll find a stable, people-first culture that makes this whole thing work. Working at HubSpot was the best decision that I ever made.
cons: The pay is a little lower than the industry, but it's worth it when you look at the perks. I'll take slightly lower pay at an awesome company with amazing perks over the reverse any day.

headline: Great company culture. Start-up mentality with customer-centric approach. Two thumbs up!
pros: Incredible growth opportunities for individual contributors. Proper mentoring and continuous feedback to set employees for success. Transparent and positive working culture to keep employees engaged and motivated to achieve more. Did I forget to mention about our unlimited vacations policy? No complaints thus far!
cons: The bar is set very high and everyone is expected to either meet or exceed expectations. A lot of emphasis on achieving results which are clearly defined on a quarterly basis.

headline: SydSpot = Home
pros: I've been working at HubSpot for nearly 5 years, and came to Australia to set up our Sydney office in July 2014. Over the past two years, I've had the privilege to interview and onboard a high percentage of our current ~45 person team. Each new SydSpotter brings a fresh perspective, and adds to the culture which we are constantly evolving. Having worked in the Dublin & Cambridge offices, I'm lucky to have a benchmark for how Sydney is going comparatively to the other offices. In many ways we operate autonomously as a startup, but with massive support, guidance (and requisite performance expectations) from HQ and our APAC head office in Singapore. HubSpot (globally) is a very special place where I've had the chance to massively develop my career while helping others do the same. Oh, and the product is also amazing/improving everyday.
cons:
1. There simply aren't enough hours in the day to do what we have the potential to achieve in ANZ.

2. We run out of bananas in the kitchen, occasionally.

headline: Channel Consultant
pros: Unlimited Vacation Policy, Great People, Competitive Environment, Opportunity to grow career quickly.
cons: Pay averages a bit lower than other companies with the same position.

headline: Amazing
pros: It is a loving place and everyone is very nice.Yeah its amazing. Bye thanks.I loved it there so much.so i love it
cons: Its a fun loving you will feel like its your home and its a good place and yeah thats a bout it.

headline: Inbound Marketing Specialist
pros: Awesome Culture, hands on training, great people.  They are always looking for ways to make their product better and keep customers happy.
cons: I have nothing bad to say outside of the pool of companies that you can sell to continues to get smaller and smaller but that is bound to happen when companies grow.

headline: Things are not what they Seem
pros: Best Benefits Around, Gym, Unlimited Vacation....?(will explain on the Cons), Free Food, overall though depends on where you actually work, but just cause you have unlimited vacation....yea you will probably work more then 40 hours a week regardless.
cons: Depends on the department you work in, but the manager is horrible. They do not know how to actually manage, the company was built on helping the employee's out, but the manager brings in the way of managing for a old fashion company who does not have unlimited vacation, which Hubspots motto is "As Long You Get Your Job Done" they tend to make you work more then you have to so they look good, along those lines, they do not praise the employee who actually does the whole work in the department, as for me...i did all the work...while the manager got all the benefits...promotions and bonuses...it's a slap to the face to watch someone (your manager) get the rewards you work for and nothing towards you.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
1. you're surrounded by some of the best talent in the whole industry - tons of opportunities to learn more.
2. there's a real openness to be entrepreneurial, learn more about different functions and to grow your own reputation. HubSpot does everything to help you here.
3. there are endless progression opportunities - moving horizontally or vertically, you'll have loads of opportunities to try new things regardless of your experience.
4. we have free lunches, a gym in the office, free beer and chocolate. You can work from home when you like and the office environment is VERY relaxed (not a suit in sight and more sofas than office chairs).
5. when you work here, you genuinely care about the company.
cons: 1. the company is growing really big at the moment so making a huge impact can sometimes be difficult, but those that put the hours in will achieve this.

headline: So Many Opportunities
pros:
HubSpot really cares about its people and its candidate experience. I'm constantly impressed by the level of expertise demonstrated by my colleagues.

The workplace benefits are really just the icing on top of an atmosphere that is consistently interesting and challenging. It's clear to me that my career growth is valued.
cons: So far I haven't found any worth noting here. It's easy to get overwhelmed with information, people, perks, but anyone is willing to point you in the right direction if you take the time to ask!

headline: What It Is Like to Build Your Career at HubSpot
pros:
Pro= A great place to grow your career.

Here is my personal experience working for HubSpot for a little over 5 years: Before I joined the HubSpot sales team I had ~8 years sales experience, so like a lot of folks on the Sales team here, I was pretty well along into my career. I understood sales when I joined the company, but 5 years later I've also had the chance to learn and do a lot more than I'd bargained for.

Here's just a small sample of what I've gotten to work on so far: - Refine my sales skills with the best sales org in the business -Create and build my own team from scratch- going from experiment stage to fully functioning cross-functional team -Learn how to hire, build, coach and manage a team -Learn how the operating system of a top-notch business is run, and how to replicate those processes - Learn how to go from start-up to scale-up.. which is incredibly valuable in the market. I have been trusted to do all this with a ton of autonomy, but also with the support and guidance of a very smart group of people.

I can't imagine how else I could have learned, and actually *done* all of this any other way, any other place.. in such a short time. Hundreds of my colleagues have a story a lot like this one, and there will be hundreds more, I'll bet. All of these challenging opportunities have made this more than a "job", but really a fast track for my professional (and personal) growth.

It is a privilege to work for and learn from an extremely bright and talented executive/management team. Our founders, and especially our CEO, have been a couple of the most influential people in my career. It is worth mentioning that I am also a mother with young kids, and have found an exceptional work/life balance here because our leadership genuinely cares about the team and creating an environment where working parents (of which there are many) have the flexibility to take care of our families and our careers at the same time. I've been able to balance everything that is important in my life while earning a very good living to provide for my kids. I am proud of the company, our product, the smart team I get to come work with every day to help our customers be successful in their businesses, and the fact that we have a lot of fun while we do it.
cons: This is, for sure, very hard work and the bar is high here. Since tech moves so fast, and what our customers need is always evolving, we all need to move fast too. That means always being out of our comfort zones, updating skills and iterating. That might not be the right fit for everyone. You really have to thrive on that, I think, to get as much out of your work here as I have.

headline: Sales at HubSpot
pros: A lot of upward mobility for someone starting out their career in sales. If you perform well you'll get promoted
cons: Typical cutthroat SaaS sales culture. Not much job stability

headline: Support Engineer
pros: HubSpot Support is a really amazing team. Everyone has eachothers backs and as far as I know there is no backstabbing or nepotism. The perks are amazing and I enjoy coming into work every day and being able to proudly tell others about my place of employment.
cons: The salary. The salary is so low. It is nearly impossible to live in Boston on 35k a year. This is a very technical job and Support Engineers know more about how to use and troubleshoot our product than anyone else in the company, and the salary/level of respect we get does not reflect that.

headline: Strong Leaders & Strong Culture
pros: The amount of autonomy you are offered right out of the gate gives you a feeling of true mutual respect. There is an underlying message of "you are here for a reason and we are so excited to see what you can do!" It's a fast-paced and fun environment where there's always a new project to tackle and a strong team to support you in the process. The commitment to true transparency encourages HubSpotters to ask questions and hear real answers. HubSpot also understands that not everyone works in the same way and really solves for the employee by offering both tangible and more abstract opportunities to build a work environment that's best for you (e.g. nomad desks, unlimited vacations, common areas for co-working).The flexibility and true investment in its people makes HubSpot a great place to build a career and has so far been a great place to find my professional voice.
cons: With the company growing quickly it can be really easy to be be complacent and not get to know too many of your colleagues. Continuing to encourage these interactions will be invaluable!

headline: Extreme toxicity in a place that claims 'Culture is King'
pros: The seductive elements that are evident at most hip tech companies these days.  Free food, free beer, great benefits, 401k, decent pay, free gym, attractive office space, stand up desks, the works!  You'll feel like a real king for quite some time with all the nice perks.
cons:
This is the 'outstanding' culture that Hubspot prides itself on that I honestly witnessed on a near daily basis:

- Male colleagues who VERY openly talk about which Hubspot girls they wanted to sleep with or thought were hot, in the most vulgar of terms.  If a certain Hubspot female was coming to the office, you'd sure hear about it!  

- Coworkers who VERY openly make fun of and gossip about colleagues on and off their team.  Know that when you are out sick that you WILL be talked about behind your back, and might have a meme or two making fun of you and shared to the whole team.

- A boss, who you are supposed to respect, that gets beyond wasted at nearly every company event.

- Coworkers who talk openly and loudly about topics ranging from the size of their genitals, the girls they slept with that week, the drugs they took that week, and the coworkers (on the same team) that they dislike.

- People who are so genuinely awful that they make the 'no jerks policy' look like a complete joke, but have complete impunity because of their particular relations to the boss.

- Coworkers and bosses who openly start drinking the free beer at 3pm.

- Expletives and extreme vulgarities dropped openly and loudly left and right, regardless of the subject matter, but most often when complaining loudly about coworkers or customers. 

- Bosses and managers that are so inexperienced, incompetent, and juvenile that they not only set the precedent of the above behaviors, but in the face of real professionals waste no time in passing all 'smart people' work off onto them, taking credit for all their ideas and accomplishments without thanks, and running to them desperately for support and counsel in their never ending crisis's.

- Middle-Upper management who know all too well about all the above problems (because they have absolutely been told directly or via TinyPulse) but ignore them by remaining conspicuously absent and silent, or firing the people that have the balls to speak up in more adamant ways.

headline: Massive Opportunity for Growth & Innovation
pros:
Being part of the global expansion of HubSpot is very exciting and presents huge opportunity for career growth.  The progression path is fast and wide open, and there are no boundaries when it comes to innovation and growth of new regions. 

HubSpot has an amazing culture and the best people.  I constantly feel challenge and learn something new everyday.
cons: It is not so much a con, but there is so much opportunity, you can tend to take on too much.

headline: Always Be Learning
pros:
Overall, the people and culture make HubSpot such an amazing place to work. I've worked at a  previous tech company with a similar feel but what puts HubSpot above that is the enormous amount of autonomy and training that you get. Senior management is also 100x more approachable! No egos whatsoever

At HubSpot, there is always something new to learn and you won't get bored here
cons: The opportunity to move across global offices is still limited but I'm sure that will come as the company continues to grow.

headline: Want to feel humiliated and belittled? If yes, it is perfect for you!
pros: Great product and they practice their culture code well in their HQ. Great coworkers in HQ and If you join their new team, they will treat you really well during your new hire training..
cons:
For a company that heavily prides itself on culture, humility and transparency, none of these were brought onto their Singapore office. 

1) You will be told to ask for help when needed, but you will then be shamed for needing help

You will ALWAYS be told to "ask for help or questions" and that you would be provided support, but when an employee bravely asked for help on things they were not certain on to help them in their role, is it "support" to be shamed by the management for not knowing it? Shamed and belittled for voicing out, by the same people that were hired to lead and support the team?


2) Even if you hadn't applied for the job but they had reached out to you, they will interview you, look at your CV, offer you the role after several rounds of interviews and hire you. Then they will tell you you are "inexperienced to work with them"

Is it good leadership to constantly tell an employee repeatedly that they are "very inexperience and it is clear that they need to face more of different situations for them to get the experience" but then not providing them the support? If they had thought of an employee as inexperienced, why would they hire the person in the first place, and then only give them 3 months to prove to be exceptional in the role?

Additionally, don't be surprised if they also belittle you by saying that your "English and Communication skills are very poor".

These comments come from the same people who hired you. Your confidence will be chipped away daily.


3) If you are a local with expertise in the region, they will hire you as a "local face" and also to be someone who can help the company find a middle ground between the local business culture and their American practices. But once you're hired, don't expect the management to want to listen to your feedback. 

During my tenure, the local/expat Management were adamant of having a "we have tried, tested and proven results for these in the US & Aus, Hence, it would work in the Asia region and you should just follow what is told" mentality.  Is this really how you want to Solve For The Customer? 

4) Want to know what your progress is like and where you stand in the company? Don't bother asking the management. They will tell you things to deceive you so you would trust them, and then next thing you know, they're done with you. Transparency level = Opaque


5) Your understanding of your jobscope & skill sets needed, your global co-workers in the same roleas understanding, and the local management's expectations of your role will be extremely misaligned. So be quite prepared to be confused and "inexperienced".


6) Understand the features of the products but need more help with explaining them more succinctly? You can ask for help with fellow co-workers and even request for some time to do product training. 

But don't be surprised that as per Point #1, you will be shamed by the management for being transparent about the help you need and they will spin a story telling other employees that you do not know even the bare minimum. Yet somehow, you passed your New Hire Training. 


7) If the company is done with you and you resign on the same day, they will pay you to leave immediately, treat you like a criminal, humiliate you by saying you are not allowed back in the office to pack their own things, like a Bank's retrenchment.


8) For a company that prides themselves on hearing feedback, when an exit interview was requested, it was immediately refused. It required me to go up to the upper management before I was provided one. 


These were only the few out of many bad experiences I've had with the company; more specifically, the management here in Singapore. It is fine that the company felt that I was not a good fit, but it was absolutely uncalled for to treat someone with such hostility and humiliation.  It has left an extremely bad taste in my mouth, and also for the current employees to see how I was mistreated. 


SUMMARY: My whole time with the company since I returned from their New Hire Training in Boston was handled extremely poorly. Let's just say that for a company who prides themselves on a "great culture (code)" and a "no-jerk" policy, they did not carry that over from their HQ to their other offices (in this case, Singapore).

headline: Great place to learn and grow
pros: There are a lot of modern technologies being used here, and lots of people that are very knowledgeable to learn from. There's minimal overhead in the develop-test-release cycle. Career growth is something that's actively discussed between managers and team members. Company culture is something that's at the forefront of people's minds; people want to make this a great place to work.
cons: Due to the autonomy given to teams, things can sometimes seem disorganized, or the same problem may be solved two different ways by two different teams.

headline: Amazing Place To Work
pros: Wonderful work environment for motivated individuals. Great opportunity to grow and make a difference.
cons: Many of the individuals who are in VP/Management roles have risen the ranks at HubSpot which is wonderful. It is important to occasionally bring in talent from the outside for these types of roles since they will enter with a different perspective and have the ability to use a fresh take.

headline: Inbound marketing Specialist
pros:
Great People.
Awesome offices
Sabbatical after 5 years
Stocked Kitchen
cons: Unlimited vacation policy - company has high attrition rate and the "benefit" is that Hubspot does not pay out vacation time if you leave

headline: Great Place
pros: Great people, atmosphere, vision, leadership, & platform. Truly cares about the success of its customers and employees
cons: I went to the kitchen and out of all the free food, my favorite trail mix was out of stock. They addressed this in the next hour though.

headline: Great company, great people, great experience
pros: Lots of opportunity to grow! From the moment your foot is in the door you have the opportunity to meet with higher ups and really figure out what you want to do and what you like! The company is an awesome place to see what a "hot and booming" business looks like.
cons: Honestly, none. They treat interns like full time employees and really invest in them.

headline: Some improvements can be made, but overall a good place to be.
pros: Non-monetary benefits and perks are great. People are absolutely awesome to work with and hang out with.
cons:
Compensation, Career Path. 

Wanted to second something another reviewer said about the Services team - everyone seems to say we are highly valued but it doesn't match in terms of compensation or career options, especially when compared to Marketing and Product. Since we're more of a boots-on-the-ground team that doesn't get a lot of exposure to other teams (we're always on the phone with customers), it's hard to feel valued beyond words.

Easy advancement was a huge selling in my first year. now that I'm at the spot where it's time to look for a new opportunity, there aren't as many non-management paths as I would have hoped. I'm sure it's still better than a lot of companies out there.

headline: great place to learn sales
pros: amazing training and help to be successful in business development
cons: you have to work hard to hit your numbers

headline: Ups and Downs but I wouldn't want to work anywhere else.
pros: Culture is a huge plus!!
cons: Compensation, Career growth at times

headline: Great place to work
pros: Unlimited vacation, smart people, flexible hours, culture, prioritize people
cons: Normal growing pains, some bureaucracy. Lack of diversity.

headline: Amazingly great place to work
pros: You've got the freedom to chart your own course and decide how you want to grow, either in your role or in a new one within the company. Freedom, to an incredible extent, to choose when, where, and how you'll get your work done (using good judgment, naturally). Freedom to be yourself, which I particularly appreciate after some of the more oppressive places I've worked. Play to your strengths and find a way to make your strengths benefit your team and the company, and you'll love going to work every day.
cons: This much freedom isn't everyone's cup of tea. You do need to be able to chart your own course and define what success means to you. Huge progress has been made in helping employees grow and learn as they take on new roles, but you still do have to do a lot of the heavy lifting yourself. But that's the tradeoff of a place that treats you like an adult -- you have to actually act like an adult and make things happen. It's a price I'm quite willing to pay.

headline: Sales
pros:
Challenging and Fast Paced
Tons of Career Opportunity at an Incredible Rate
Colleagues become great friends
Continued Learning
cons: You shouldn't expect any downtime

headline: Adventure Starts Here
pros:
HubSpot inspires me everyday to want to push myself and be a better person. This is my first full time job as a graduate and within my first month I was given so much respect and trust in my role that I exceeded even my own expectations. The culture, the people and the transparency is what inspires me everyday to try harder tomorrow which I think is pretty darn cool!
The perks are also second to the people, as a woman starting out in a fairly male dominated industry I was worried I wouldn't fit in but I feel like an equal and a friend. HubSpot has really encouraged me to find my own voice they've provided me with the education and the platform to do so.
cons: Sometimes I feel because everyone is so intellectual and progressive I can't keep up, especially being located in Sydney for an American company you don't want feel like you're missing out.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great management, great opportunity for career growth. Move up the ladder very quickly.
cons: Sometimes growing so quickly hard to address everyone's needs. Talks about being open and culture but when trying to help give honest feedback managers don't always listen and disregard your input.

headline: Great Culture and Place to Develop
pros:
The management team is very transparent with the employees, sharing all types of financials, guidance, and big bets for the company moving forward.  Lots of autonomy and freedom to manage your role.  Lots of great benefits like stocked kitchen, lunches, beer, admission into road races, ski weekends, mystery dinners, and more.  They invest a lot in their employees to be happy and create an environment where everyone wants to solve for the customer and grow.

The people who work here are all smart in their own way.  Development from your direct peers is something I've really taken advantage as there are so many talented people to tap if you're willing to.
cons: The only area for improvement is having more structured training on an ongoing basis.  I think these are growing pains the company is going through and have made some early tweaks to improve it and still has room to improve.

headline: Great experience it was very exciting and very enjoyable from the warm atmosphere to the great team
pros: Awesome place I can even describe how amazing this job with its amazing team that was very welcoming and had open arms
cons: There were times where I felt lost and didn't know what to expect but it was all part of the experience and was interesting

headline: Associate Inbound Marketing Specialist
pros: HubSpot is a fantastic company to work for. The company prides itself first and foremost on solving for the customer, which is essential to any successful business. They also rely heavily on creating a work environment that employees love, as evidenced by the Culture Code.
cons: Sales at HubSpot is a grind as we work on monthly quotas. That being said, the pay is good as well as the benefits.

headline: As awesome as advertised
pros:
Engineering teams are fully autonomous and operate in many ways like individual startups.  The teams are only given a high-level mission and not individual features or dates to achieve.  The incredibly talented PAAS and FAAS teams allow product teams to narrow their focus and rely on systems just working. The pace of the product teams is unbelievable.

The company puts a large focus on personal growth.  There are weekly tech talks for the product team, an occasional HubTalk/Failure Forum, classes for management training, and even classes on non-work related topics.  Management reads all feedback and reacts accordingly.  The product blog is great and another way for employees to share knowledge.

The Culture Code is real.  Every employee has the HEART referenced by that code.
cons: The company puts a big focus on "Use Good Judgement" and being hands off.  That is a great way to operate, but it may not be for everyone.  HubSpot wouldn't be a good fit for engineers who need heavy processes or need to wait for someone to tell them what to do.

headline: Work hard and play hard
pros: HubSpot has won a ton of awards for a great place to work for a reason. I'm sure some things have changed as they have continued to grow but through the internal company wiki lots of information was transparent and anyone could find out what was going on. Beer fridge, ping pong, foosball and tons of free food.
cons: If you aren't looking to work hard then this place probably isn't for you. At this point I also wouldn't think of HubSpot as a startup or a place for someone really looking to have a huge impact on a company of this size.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great job with lots of benefits and a chance to work with up to date and interesting technology.
cons: Can't think of any downsides

headline: Believe the hype
pros:
- culture is amazing
- career growth is strong and opportunities are very common
cons: - VERY fast paced environment, which can make for a bad experience if you want to sit back and take your time or have a long learning curve

headline: All that and a bag of chips...literally.
pros: Everything you've heard is true. HubSpot is the best thing since sliced bread. And yes, we have that too, for employees. But its so much more than the free food/beer/casual environment. HubSpot is spurring a real culture shift when it comes to work. I honestly wish that more companies would model theirs off of ours because it WORKS. You work when/where/how you want, because at the end of the day, you know what you're responsible for and are treated with the respect to get the job done. Feeling empowered within your day to day work as though you're an owner of a start-up, yet having the support and guidance of a large international company is one of the best gifts I've ever been given. And oh yes, we get rewards and recognition for that strong performance to boot.
cons: I feel disappointed by colleagues that don't take advantage of all that HubSpot has to offer, or those that may not have experienced life outside the HubSpot world who may take these benefits for granted. HubSpot offers a lot to those that are willing to take advantage of it.

headline: This place is an oasis
pros: Hubspot values employee happiness and satisfaction. They invest heavily in helping you find the path that is best for you and helping you along that path.  Additionally they go out of their way to figure out how employees are doing and try to actively manage any developing problems. Hubspot has ruined all future jobs for me
cons: Because hubspot is such a high power shop they expect great things from their employees. Its definitely not a place for everyone. If you don't know how to work hard then hubspot isn't for you.

headline: This place is an oasis
pros: Hubspot values employee happiness and satisfaction. They invest heavily in helping you find the path that is best for you and helping you along that path.  Additionally they go out of their way to figure out how employees are doing and try to actively manage any developing problems. Hubspot has ruined all future jobs for me
cons: Because hubspot is such a high power shop they expect great things from their employees. Its definitely not a place for everyone. If you don't know how to work hard then hubspot isn't for you.

headline: Great Place to Grow and Have Autonomy
pros: HubSpot is a great place to kick off your career and develop skills in the tech world. There are a lot of different departments that can appeal to anyone coming out of college or experiencing a change in their career or wanting to take their skills to the next level. I've learned more at HubSpot over the past few years than I've learned at any part of my life. They TRULY invest in training and that's huge. Most companies miss this, HubSpot does not. It's actually sometimes sad to get out of training because you're like WOAH! I just learned a ton of incredible stuff, I've met all these great people... now I hope I can do just as well as they've set me out to be... You want to fly at this company. As you go through highs and sometimes you'll feel like you messed up (but you really didn't) if you do continue to prove yourself, you do have the ability to advance in your role, you will move up, or even if qualified, possibly join another department. HubSpot has flexibility and they are human to understand sometimes it takes a year or so to understand what really drives you. Also, the perks of after work are fun and the added benefits from mystery dinners to the gym in the office to working from HOME are huge. I love that I can work from anywhere and that I actually DO have complete trust from my manager. This company is human.. sometimes you want to jump for joy, sometimes, you feel like well, this is definitely a job, but the majority of it, what you put into the machine, you truly get back out :).
cons: Work life balance can be difficult AT times. You do have to be committed to working here. There are days with long hours and added stress due to the being in a growing company, a SaaS business model, and sincere drive to succeed here (like... people don't want to give anything other than 100+%) but that's why HubSpot isn't for everyone. It's only a con if 100%+ isn't something you don't aim for. It can be very "clicky" at times and that can be a huge bummer, but you find your way and the people who build you up and you focus on your career development.

headline: What a ride..
pros: I'm not going to write a bunch of cliche stuff in here. HubSpot provides every possible resources somebody in sales needs to succeed. Keeping your employees happy does wonders for a company.
cons: It is getting harder to meet all of the awesome new employees that come on board. HubSpot is addressing this through their culture team, so I anticipate more events with interdepartmental events..

headline: Awesome Company Firing on All Cylinders
pros: When a company is executing so well, the work goes easy. People are hard working, but work without stress and the junk that goes along with that is a joy. It's so exciting to get to produce and delight customers.
cons: It can be hard to explain to your friends what you do. Everyone has heard of Google, but HubSpot isn't so well known.

headline: Great company
pros: Great company to work for, very innovative, great work life balance, great management.  Product sells itself and there is plenty of opportunity for growth.
cons: Fast paced environment, not necessarily a bad thing, but if that is not what you are looking for this is not a good fit.  Could have a better 401K plan that is capped at $1,500 a year match.

headline: Great place to be
pros: Lots of room for growth if you work hard
cons: Middle management isn't properly trained. Compensation is low relative to competition

headline: Decent place to start a career
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Hubspot are the people. Good perks, unlimited vaca time, and flexible hours. They expect you to complete your job: not a lot of micro-managing, which is a plus for those with a high work ethic.
cons: I'm not sure what I didn't like about this place. Good culture and good management. Sometimes, you were expected to perform tasks out of your jobdescription

headline: Best Company on EARTH
pros: fantastic people, fun atmosphere, everyone works hard, very flexible with vacation and children, easy to work from home.  I look forward to being at work every day without fail.
cons: People can whine about things here and there, especially younger folks who have never worked anywhere else.  There really are no cons in my opinion that are even worth my time to mention

headline: This company is real unicorn!!
pros: The company does a great job giving employees a ton of autonomy at an early point of their careers.  The vision of transforming how companies attract, engage and delight customers makes it exciting to come to work every day.  Also the culture code isn't just a marketing document,  people live and breathe it every day.
cons: Not a negative for me but you really need to be passionate about what you do as this is not a  9-5 type of place.  The company treats you like an adult, so you work where and when you want as long as you get your job done and then you get to take advantage of unlimited vacation.

headline: Not all that was made out to be..
pros: People, Free food, Adjustable desks
cons: Poor work life balance, targets are unrealistic

headline: Great Career and Promotion opportunity
pros: Career Progression, Excited for the future of the company, Rocket Ship, The people are some of the best people I've worked with Culture, Fun place to work,
cons: The interview process is tough but fair, We're growing very fast so it's hard to feel like you know everyone now.

headline: awesome growing company
pros: Awesome culture and perks (and beer)
cons: Sales sales sales, growth at all costs sometimes

headline: Great people, great company
pros: Excellent coworkers, exciting and current tech stack, convenient location in a blossoming tech center, really good perks like a stocked kitchen, unlimited time off, and education reimbursement
cons: Very few. It's fast-paced and involves hard work that's not for everyone, but most engineering positions are well-supported and well-taken care of.

headline: Incredible Place to Work
pros:
-Leadership places a heavy emphasis on employee growth across all divisions, from tuition reimbursement to offering opportunities to take on challenges outside your core responsibilities. 
-Transparent culture from top to bottom.
-Management actually listens to employees, and makes quick changes to structure if/when needed.
-Flexible working hours.
-People here are incredibly smart and passionate, genuinely fun to work with.
cons: -HubSpot is a fast paced, results driven org that isn't made for everyone.

headline: Awesome company and culture!
pros:
- Awesome culture code (that inspires lot of other companies now)
- Awesome customer centric products and services that people love
- One of the fastest growing tech companies Worldwide, Europe included (huge career opportunities)
- Autonomy in taking decisions and actions that impact directly internally and for the business
- Fast career development in fast paced environment 
- Individual/human consideration despite a 1000+ company size
cons: - It's an involving and demanding experience which may not be for everyone but in the sales environment there is no secret between key inputs and corresponding outputs.

headline: inbound specialist
pros: A really cool place to work with even cooler coworkers. People's passions shined through and it was contagious making you want to work harder.
cons: Not the best management, little opportunity for promotion, poor work life balance, work environment can be a little stiff at times but not the absolute worst

headline: Fun Company
pros: Good learning experience and fun parties
cons: Company grew too fast and career grow potential became a limiting factor

headline: Culture Rules All
pros: The culture here at HubSpot is awesome.  You are empowered to make your own decisions so long as you "use good judgement".  That's phrase that gets thrown around a lot and management means it.  It guides pretty much everything we do here.  It allows us to have fun so long as we all get our work done.  Oh and the work itself is really fun.  I support the sales org and I love the people I work with
cons: We've grown fast so not everything is as organized as I would love it, and there is a lot of work to do on a day to day basis.  There are some small signs of becoming a bigger company (less cross-team collaboration for example) but steps are actively being taken to mitigate these.

headline: HubSpot
pros: It truly is a great place to work, people are great, manager respect and care about you personally. The benefits are pretty good too.
cons: The work/life balance you can see makes an affect on people, but it really is honestly how you control it yourself. If you are able to get your things in order you will have no problem.

headline: Great company,Whose Great Culture Should be Among It's Chief Concerns
pros: Hubspot truly cares about its customers and employees. This is evidenced by the fact that Hubspot measures employee happiness the same way it measures customer happiness. Hubspot has great perks, does some grand things like the onsite gym and sabbaticals. There are also rumors of other cool things to come and history of delivering. HubSpot's leadership is very strong. If stock performance and revenue over-achievement are any indicators we're in good hands.
cons: While Hubspot has made significant strides in identifying, hiring, and promoting well-qualified women to leadership positions; with lots of work still left here. Hubspot is sadly failing at having any people of color in leadership positions. This also extends to the monochromatic vibe in the, ironically orange-covered, office space. Put another way, Hubspot is lacking meaningful representation of people of color at all levels.

headline: All hype - no substance
pros:
Located in Cambridge, where there is a good Tech scene.
Hubspot does some work in Big data that is of interest to a lot of people trying to get into Tech
cons:
There is just so much bureaucracy and politics within the company that it creates a lot of confusion and uncertainty. You can never be sure what your career path will be at Hubspot as most decisions are made behind close doors and poorly communicated. 
Also,I am actively looking for other Tech jobs in the Cambridge area and am noticing that brand value for working at Hubspot id falling fast. 
ADVICE for new hires: Get everything in writing and don't accept any verbal promises

headline: Great team, tech, and culture
pros:
+ Smart, motivated team
+ Modern tech. stack
+ Leadership solicits and takes action on feedback, actually seems to care
+ Lots of ownership and impact even as company grows
cons: - Flip-side of ownership makes prioritization hard, more things to build then time to build them

headline: Growth & Transparency
pros: The growth here is real, you are constantly learning something new and working with individuals of different positions in different departments which makes for an amazing learning experience. The work/life balance is also a huge win - people respect that you have lives outside of work and that respect makes you work even harder.
cons: Sometimes you have a ton of projects to work on at once and it seems overwhelming but it is a great challenge and you have endless amounts of resources and individuals who are happy to help.

headline: Great learning environment
pros: -Great location, very good benefits
cons: -None come to mind right now

headline: I felt duped.
pros:
- Free food
- Free beer
- Great pay (if you are a developer)
- Fun parties
- Some cool people
- Amazing benefits 
- Free gym
- Great on the resume
- Unlimited vacation policy
- Stock options
cons:
- Frat house college type culture.  Can be fun sometimes but is mostly horribly juvenile and unprofessional.  Can be very hard to work as a serious professional in this environment.  

- Extreme lack of diversity on all counts.  If you are white, extroverted, and come from a wealthy family, you will fit right in.  If you are none of those things - good luck to you and your sanity.

- Still tries to act like a start up when there are now well over 1000 people.  The lack of structure worked once, but now it feels very messy and too loose.  A lot needs to be tightened up (in a way that doesn't lose the casual atmosphere altogether).

- Unqualified and inept management.  It appears that once you have been at HubSpot for x many years you get promoted to management, no matter if you were a developer or a support 'engineer', which is an absolute nightmare for real professionals to work under.

- Unmet expectations.  They do a great job marketing themselves to potential hires, saying how they are truly changing the world, how there is infinite opportunity in the company, how they are the best of the best, that it is harder to get into HubSpot than Yale, that culture and transparency is the #1 priority. Never in my life have I felt so duped.  When you are done drinking the Kool-Aide and realize you have been had on all counts, you will feel extremely disheartened and disappointed.

- Unmet role expectations.  I was sold on a position that was 100% different than what was offered.  When it was time to get to work, my daily tasks were far below my skill set and offered no challenge.

- Too many young people and too much drinking.  There are taps in the kitchen, and all big parties are heavily alcohol involved.  Again, if you are a frat house type extroverted person, you will love it.  if not (especially introverted developers) you will feel left out.  

- Hidden HR Department.  HR is deftly called "People Ops", and people are left in the dark about the support they can offer to employees.  When I needed to reach out to HR I had to ask several people for who to contact because I had no idea how to find them.  This is deeply troubling as many teams are rich with conflict and politics, and HR could help resolve this issues before they compound into bigger problems.

headline: Best reason to get up in the morning - working at Hubspot Dublin!
pros: I have worked in media sales for Irish companies over the past 15 years and Hubspot is by far the best company I have ever been part of.  Hubspot hires primarily for fit which involves attitude and ability. Yes the interview process is rigorous and can be long, as the policy is one of “hire to keep” rather than “hire to fire” as other companies tend to do. I love that Hubspot Dublin, Boston, Sydney and now Singapore is staffed with really smart people who are keen to learn, open to being coached, ambitious to progress and aim to help together. This would explain the exceptional global growth with everyone going in the same direction with complete openness and transparency.
cons: I have been working for Hubspot in Dublin since they opened in March 2013. This is a really busy environment where everyone’s success is mutually interdependent. There is a big focus on being both an individual contributor and being part of a team; hence working with colleagues to assist prospects and customers whilst being responsible for your own activities is huge. There is a strong focus on accountability and metrics; so if you don't do busy environments or if you are a solo operator who prefers to fly your own flag and if you are not comfortable with transparency and visibility then Hubspot is not for you.

headline: Love it here
pros: Fantastic engineering talent and culture. I can't say enough how skilled, friendly, and dedicated everyone is at HubSpot. It's awesome how much trust is put in employees to solve for and do right by the customer. So many opportunities to learn, collaborate, and grow.
cons: Getting up to speed when first joining can be somewhat intense, but once you get into the groove, it's great!

headline: Really fun, really exciting, but also challenging
pros: Everyone is smart. People don't micromanage you. You work on your own, but you also work in a team.
cons: Everyone is very smart, so you have to work harder to stand out her than you would otherwise.

headline: Learn more about growing a business than you ever expected
pros: I have worked at HubSpot for over 4 years, and have essentially received an MBA in growing a SaaS company.  Even though my responsibility is sales/management I have insight into how the marketing operations function, how pricing/packaging is determined etc...The internal wiki + transparent company culture allows young people getting started in the workforce to not only make good money and learn how to sell, but to really get the vision of the company and understand the inputs needed to get us there.  It has made me think more about solving for our customers first, than the company before myself, and this is the attitude that most employees have here.  I believe this is the reason for the high market cap and success of the company.
cons: Early on my work life balance was less than ideal.  You really have a lot to learn and it can be tough if you don't have a super organized brain.  Our leadership team takes great strides to ensure people actually take vacations and unwind, but if you come out of the gate struggling you may feel more pressure to catch up.

headline: Wonderful place to work
pros: The culture is phenomenal. It's very refreshing to work for a place that so encourages personal growth and happiness in the workplace.
cons: Advancement through the company is a daunting and not readily available process.

headline: Worst company to work for
pros:
Free goodies and Unlimited Holidays (that you can never really take advantage of)
Used to be good in the old days (according to what senior employees stories)
cons:
Lack of collaboration and communication between departments
Illusion of success (numbers get manipulated to look better)
Always looking at others instead of at themselves
Not a nice place to work - pressure with none or little rewards

headline: Best place to sell in Boston
pros:
HubSpot really does live up to its billing. There are incredible career growth opportunities, middle and upper management who care about your future, and virtually everyone is young, smart, and hungry. 

Training is very helpful and ongoing. Your manager really cares about you doing well and will do everything in his or her power to help you. Everything is very metrics-driven, so quota and ramp can be difficult, but if you stick with it and work hard, you can make it. 

You will be a better sales rep, professional, and leader for having worked at HubSpot.

Great brand. People leaving voluntarily are typically taking $200k+ sales management roles at more true startups.

Perks live up to the hype. You can operate completely on your own schedule. Team/sales/company outings at least twice a month, free beer and food, employee stock purchase plan, stock grants for sales overperformance.  Stock price has doubled since IPO 9 months ago so value of grants continues to rise.
cons:
Not for the faint of heart. If you want to punch the clock at 9, and again at 5, HubSpot is not the place for you. The learning curve is steep and the work, especially in sales (and especially in channel sales) is hard.

You're constantly stack-ranked against your peers and there's intense pressure to meet and exceed quota. Expect a challenge.

Comp is decent in sales but I know it's higher at more enterprise-level companies. Also management can feel reactionary rather than proactive.

The culture is great but the constant patting ourselves on the back for it can get annoying. Do we constantly need to be congratulating ourselves for having happy and dedicated employees? Can feel like an orange-spraypainted cult at times.

headline: Great place to be an engineer
pros: Lots of autonomy. Everything is always "what to do", not "how to do it". If you want to get involved in product decision making, you're free to do so. If you'd rather dive in and reshape the tech stack, you're free to do so. If you just want to hack and build, you're free to do so. All will be rewarded. The company does a great job matching people's skills and motivations to the work they're doing.
cons: The cadence can be spiky. The weeks before the company's annual conference can get intense with deadlines. If you're not self-motivating, you will probably not find yourself progressing in the company, as they definitely expect you to take on the responsibilities of the job you want to be promoted to first. It's a good thing for some, but I've definitely heard people feel like they lack direction for what abilities and personal traits they should be working on.

headline: Yes, it really is awesome.
pros:
- Ambitious, hard working, smart people
- Fun company events, department outings
- Free snacks/beer, good health & dental insurance
- Stocks, investment advice through Fidelity
- Good location
- Growing company
- Great vacation policy
- Productive, caring management
- Tuition reimbursement plan
- Culture focused on learning, professional and personal growth, excellence
cons:
Hmm, this is a tough one... In my personal experience there aren't really any downsides. It can be hard to meet and mingle with people outside of your department, but I think that's a challenge at any company that has over a few hundred employees. HubSpot still has a bit of a startup vibe in the sense that it's still growing, there's a high energy level, can be really fun, etc., but it's not a startup anymore, so if that's what you're looking for I suggest you go a lot smaller. 

At the end of the day, there's no other company I'd rather work for. Hands down. Everybody here genuinely cares about our customers, our company, and each other. I feel cheesy saying that, but there you go.

headline: Happier than I have ever been.
pros: I've had the benefit of working at other companies and that generated context on what the normal working world is: this isn't it.  We're encouraged to be ourselves.  The whole goal is to align an employee with what their passion is and create a start-up environment for you to run.
cons:
Come prepared to work.  We are passionate and driven.  
Don't lose perspective.  I see way too many people get upset at the smallest things here.

headline: Disappointed engineer
pros:
The company does have aggressive growth plans, or at least that is the way they lured top talent like me from the bay area. People are relatively nice and work is not too fast paced.
You get the standard perks such as coffee, breakfast, beer etc. that have become table stakes now.
cons:
Work is not as exciting as I had thought and the product managers are just some rude East coast MBAs. The quality of the software engineering talent in the company is actually pretty bad compared to the two other companies I have worked with.
It does not feel or work like a start-up. So don't let them fool you with "start-up culture". It is the same messy office politics culture you can expect in a badly run mature company.

headline: It's an overall rating of a 5 until it's a 1 - - and you don't see the 1 coming.
pros:
You get to be  passionate about your work.

The people you get to work next to, 99% of the time, are good people -  first which makes you want to work with them. They are team players who consistently strive to be exceptional for their clients, for HubSpot, for their team and for themselves last.  

People are smart, work hard and care about helping each other.  It's rare to hear anyone say they 'don't have time' or 'that's not my job.'  

It's a very special place and not everyone is lucky enough in their career to work at a company that is fun, has great people, allows you to dream big and build big - if it works, it becomes your job.  

Client service and satisfaction is a real thing here and the sincerity of HubSpot employees shows.

Clients/customers are generally awesome.

You will learn a lot from your peers and if you are willing to seek mentors, as well as, challenge yourself.

You'll meet your future business partners because people have great ideas, are entrepreneurs innately and you'll teach each other something everyday.
cons:
Sometimes bad apples slip through the cracks and don't understand that being a team isn't about anything other than delivering the best work product to your clients.  Those people are hard to work with and make it difficult for those around them.  It's rare, but when it happens it makes an impact.

Constructive feedback/1:1 meetings are mostly a joke where your manager asks you, in a way they just learned at a workshop, how they should be doing their job.  'How can I help you do xyz?'  That's not leadership.  If people knew the answers to why they weren't great at certain things, they'd solve it for themselves.  People are go getters at HubSpot, so if they aren't doing something right, their manager should be the one doing some reflection. 

If you are looking to be inspired or hope to develop as a professional, beyond the basics, you'll be disappointed.  If you have any experience or talent, you'll likely be managing up because huge growth is awesome, except when you're saddled with a new manager who may have been a great individual contributor, but is in no way a leader.  Experienced people are rarely, if ever, pumped about how much their manager teaches/coaches them  There are some great leaders and the people you work alongside are outstanding.  The reality is you'll likely end up with a mediocre, micro-manager who pretends to embrace new ideas, different tactics, but is constantly CYA-ing instead of GSD-ing.

headline: Great Company
pros: A rising star amongst consultancy companies. start up atmosphere even though it has become a 1000 person company.
cons: Too demanding and sometime could be stressful. Not very international with too many east coast americans.

headline: Get ready for growth
pros: There's no shortage of orange enthusiasm here at HubSpot.  The people are great and the culture makes every day interesting.  Can't say enough good things
cons: Honestly, I don't have any huge cons.  I think that HubSpot employees take the job with the understanding that they'll be challenged and held to high standards.  We hire the best for a reason!

headline: It's a great time but the downside is less $
pros: Great culture, great people, "work hard, play hard"
cons: Salaries are not competitive, quota's difficult and unreasonable to achieve, politics, promotion paths unclear, "churn and burn"

headline: It's a great time but the downside is less $
pros: Great culture, great people, "work hard, play hard"
cons: Salaries are not competitive, quota's difficult and unreasonable to achieve, politics, promotion paths unclear, "churn and burn"

headline: Customer Success Manager
pros: Smart people, fun environment, free food.
cons: Just keeps getting harder to hit OTE pay.

headline: The people are the best
pros: The people here are some of the most genuine and hard-working I've ever met. The company lives up to it's motto of "Use Good Judgement" far better than Google's "Don't be evil". There are almost no secrets within the company, trust is huge here. The tech stack is great, red tape is minimal, cross-team collaboration is the norm.
cons:
Current location is a bit crowded because we're growing so quickly.
The soda fountain doesn't have orange soda.

headline: Great place to learn and grow
pros: The company recently went public, so we're in a period of very high spirits and energy.  HubSpot is definitely on a trajectory toward world domination in marketing automation.  I have never encountered a HubSpotter that I really didn't like.  We do a great job recruiting, hiring and maintaining a positive culture.  (By that, I mean the type of person we hire and the way they behave in the work place is very constructive, transparent and hardworking.)
cons: Like many people, I wake up from time to time questioning, "what do I want to do when I grow up?"  So, I turn to our internal job board and scan open opportunities.  If I don't find one that strikes my interest that day, I feel a little defeated.  I don't think this is a pervasive issue, nor uncommon to other companies.   It is clear that HubSpot is focused on a particular market segment and if you are working on the fringes of that segment, it can feel a little marginalizing to realize your mission is not the core HubSpot mission.

headline: Fantastic place to work - employee happiness is top notch
pros:
HubSpot genuinely cares about producing a fantastic employee experience. The perks are fantastic - food, beer, coffee, a gym, time off, peer bonuses, education reimbursement

There is terrific access to management, who truly believe and act on transparency and helping their employees develop their careers. 

HubSpot has been making great strides and investments in diversity, both gender and racial - believing that a diverse workplace is one where a differeing view point is a valuable one.
cons: Relatively little age diversity. This is often a blast, because there are lots of young people and that feels really vibrant. The downside is being able to learn from people who've been around the block a few times.

headline: Fun, Solid Place to Work
pros: Loved it. Most of HubSpot is a really great experience where you will learn many new things. Try to keep up.
cons: Why does it care about 20 words here? The beer is less free than it used to be.

headline: No other place I would rather be
pros:
The smartest people I've ever worked with in my life -- and more importantly, the nicest too.

The rocket-ship growth and kick-ass culture don't hurt either.  But mostly, the people.
cons: It's an intense place with smart people working hard.  If you're looking for an easy place to work, this ain't it.  Personally, I wouldn't have it any other way -- but not for everybody.

headline: HubSpot continues to be better and better place to work
pros: I have been working for HubSpot for over three years, and despite its growth, HubSpot continues to improve as a place to work. I feel as though there are infinite learning opportunities and plenty of chances for internal mobility. My manager always has my back, but also constantly challenges me to push myself and deliver my best work.
cons: HubSpot has a very collaborative and meeting-heavy culture. While this environment is great for coming up with creative solutions and working with people across the organization, it also means that getting the work done often requires working outside the normal business hours.

headline: The Best Challenge of My Career
pros: HubSpot is more than a company. It sounds cheesy to say, but I've truly never been pushed as hard, or enjoyed what I was doing, as much as I do here. You will be a small fish in an ocean of amazing employees. That said, the amount of support from employees at all levels of the company is immense. Provided you're inspired by the hard work of others, you will be motivated to accomplish more (and in less time) than you thought possible here. The autonomy granted here, along with the transparency, attention to culture, and paths for career growth are just a few of the factors that make this company amazing.
cons: The work is hard. If you are intimidated by late nights, a fast pace, long hours, or the idea that you may never be the smartest person in the room, then this is not the company for you.

headline: Not for everyone
pros: Newest technologies, great people, challenging, focused and rewarding environment.
cons: Pressure is high to GSD and those that don't will have to leave. Only the strongest will survive.

headline: There isn't a good reason to not want to work here.
pros:
- Management genuinely cares of the employees (to the point where it's almost uncomfortable)
- GSD isn't just a saying, people will actually sit down and get **** done
- You're surrounded by some of the most intelligent people you'll ever meet
- Many, many opportunities to grow (they discuss career develop opportunities on the first day of training)
- They encourage entrepreneurship (as in they WANT you to have side projects outside of HubSpot)
cons: The company is huge, and growing even more. Because of that, most people don't know each other. Would be great to see more crossover interactiosn between different teams.

headline: Be as successful as you want
pros:
* Empowered and enabled to make huge mistakes or earn huge wins. 
* Amazing people who bring positive attitudes to work day in and day out. Intelligent, hardworking, friendly, and outgoing. 
* You will be doing work every day that matters and helps the companies bottom line. The sense that everyone is pulling in the same direction (up and to the right).
* All the perks: vacation policy, free beer, free snacks, 5 year sabbatical game room, food trucks, cookie days, and there's little surprises and fun days happening all the time. 
* A company that realizes you need to spend to grow. We're always able to try new technology and software if we can demonstrate the value added via POC. 
* You don't hear "no" here very often - its better to try things and 'fail fast'  (as long as you have a rollback plan!)
cons:
* Empowered and enabled to make huge mistakes or earn huge wins. <-- This isn't for everyone. For some people its scary, and paralyzing when you don't know where to start because your direct manager isn't telling you exactly what to do. 
* You will often find that you didn't get to what you wanted to work on during a particular day because something comes up and throws you all off course - you need to both be able to switch gears very rapidly, and not be bothered by it. 
* A lot of people think HubSpot is fun, and hip because we have beer etc. - but take a walk around the office after 6 or 7 pm any night, or even on a weekend and there will be plenty of people here (young and old, senior and entry level) working their @$$ off to carve our a career for themselves or help the company get to the next level. Let me be very clear about this: At HubSpot, I'm the happiest I've ever been at a job but I've also done the most work I've ever done at a job.

headline: Constantly Challenged, Internal Opportunities
pros:
- Constantly Challenged
- I made a career shift internally during my team here and it was welcomed
- Fast paced, innovative environment
- Office Space is amazing
cons: - Constantly Changing Environment - not necessarily a con, but you have to be adaptable to thrive here.

headline: HubSpot changed my life
pros: People, culture, product, company, work life balance...everything is great! Never thought a company could be this satisfying. It's truly an honor to be working here. Plenty of activities going on constantly to help the culture.
cons: Really nothing significant. Very happy to be here. If you're not an A player you may get overwhelmed.

headline: Awesome
pros:
Pay
Smart  people 
Great Tech 
Awesome Product

I  loved it till it was time to  move one
cons:
At the time I left,  people were pretty unhappy and it was a harsh enviroment. I felt  on edge and the  enviroment was poor. That seems to have improved post IPO but before it was very churn and burn.

The job become my life  and that was not  was I wanted anymore.

headline: I Love HubSpot
pros:
- Amazing, smart, funny people
- The culture is the best I have ever worked at 
- So many fun events and outings 
- Everyone respects each other 
- There is zero office politics which is a welcomed change from many other places
cons: I have been working here for a month and I have nothing but amazing things to say about HubSpot.

headline: Top-tier start-up; Competitive Sales Environment
pros: The culture! Even as HubSpot grew-and-grew there is a maniacal focus to maintain and expand a great start-up culture. HubSpotters are smart, driven and fun.
cons: At HubSpot, it is best to understand your desired career path. The company is very fast-paced and it's best to have a plan. Entry-level sales positions are best filled by candidates that strive to be promoted within sales. BDRs are less successful without larger career ambitions in sales.

headline: Management
pros: Continued expansion, customer success, and personal and team growth that continues to fuel the rocketship.  We have the chance to build a once in a generation B2B company.
cons: It's not really a con but you have to be comfortable with change, a fast pace, and always challenging conventional wisdom.

headline: Difficult and rewarding interview and training process
pros: Thoughtful and high level conversations with hiring managers and interviewers. Specific recruiter assigned and dedicated to your case. Comfortable interview process. Seriously the best interview process I've ever had.
cons: For anyone who ends up getting hired this is not a con but the process is very involved and difficult. Come to every phone and in person interview ready to talk about HubSpot. Do you research!

headline: A hands-on MBA in a fast growth (and paced) company
pros:
Smart people, innovative policies and processes, always something new on the horizon.  It's a winning team.  You get to mix it up with many different types of roles (developers collaborating with marketers collaborating with services folks, collaborating with sales reps).

Very strong brand in our industry.  Feels like we're the Apple of marketing software industry.
cons: Everything is fast.  Shifting, changing.  Growing team means growing complexity.  Things slow down, things get lost in translation, departments inadvertantly working at cross ends.  Don't get me wrong, nobody like it when they happens and people always are trying to work things out and work together.  Alignment is a regular vocab word around here.  The micro culture/work/status is not consistent across teams.  But the macro culture is strong.

headline: A hands-on MBA in a fast growth (and paced) company
pros:
Smart people, innovative policies and processes, always something new on the horizon.  It's a winning team.  You get to mix it up with many different types of roles (developers collaborating with marketers collaborating with services folks, collaborating with sales reps).

Very strong brand in our industry.  Feels like we're the Apple of marketing software industry.
cons: Everything is fast.  Shifting, changing.  Growing team means growing complexity.  Things slow down, things get lost in translation, departments inadvertantly working at cross ends.  Don't get me wrong, nobody like it when they happens and people always are trying to work things out and work together.  Alignment is a regular vocab word around here.  The micro culture/work/status is not consistent across teams.  But the macro culture is strong.

headline: Easily the best place to work in Boston
pros: Incredible place to work. Full or start-up perks such as a gym, free food, flexible hours, team outings, and dozens of other great benefits. They also hire really talented people and encourage you to try new things which makes for a great learning environment.
cons: Be prepared to get FAT! The amount of free food is kind of ridiculous.

headline: Finance function
pros:
- The management team is passionate about the product and the Company and their positive energy rubs off on the rest of the Company.
- Company is serious about hiring the best and brightest people.  
- The Company is growing at a 50% clip quarter over quarter and the rapid growth provides so many opportunities for people to expand their careers in either their current function or explore opportunities in other departments.
- The vast majority of employees will drop whatever they are doing and help a fellow hubspotter out with an issue or question - very collaborative environment.
- People genuinely enjoy working with each other 
- The vast menu of employee benefits are second to none
- Management is very transparent with the employee base.  Everything from board of directors presentations to detail employee survey results are shared on a consistent basis.
- Employees are encouraged to challenge the way thing are done.  If there is a better way to accomplish something the change is embraced by management.
cons: With the rapid growth of the Company comes increased workload from time to time and surprises that come up on a daily basis that need quick turnaround times to solve.  The fast paced, fluid work day isn't for everyone.  Someone with a "9-5 punch the clock" mentality will not last very long.  To me this is a good thing though because the people that work here are highly motivated and will roll up their sleeves and do whatever it takes to get the job done.

headline: It
pros: Great benefits, eg insurance. Nice perks.
cons: Silly culture, lots of politics.

headline: A great place to invest your time and energy
pros: Some of the brightest, most enthusiastic, and inspiring people I have ever worked with. There is a tremendous amount of potential with our market, our product, and our brand. I'm stoked about our prospects for the future, and I love coming to work every day. The work is satisfying, we're making a difference in people's businesses (i.e. their lives) and the perks are excellent.
cons: The unlimited vacation policy often turns into "limited" vacation; but that's more an issue with employees not taking the time than it is with management not making it available. Overall I have very few complaints.

headline: Best Place, hands down
pros: I have worked here 5 years and things have only improved over time. Everyone is super smart and driven. The people you work with are the reason you want to come to work. Great benefits, and flexible hours. The management is focused and selfless. People truly care about their team and those they manage.
cons: People are so driven that they can sometimes fall into workaholic routines. This isn't a result of the structure or company; it is a result of the type of people that work here.

headline: Fantastic beginning to the journey...
pros:
Katie Donohue was an absolute pleasure to work through the HubSpot application process. She's extremely welcoming, knowledgeable, and was there for anything that came up along the way. 
A large part of my choice to join the team was due to their overwhelming hospitality. It's that level of detail and the fantastic culture Katie helped to promote that ultimately sealed the deal. 
Katie is a rock star and an all around great representative for the HubSpot team.
cons: Nothing to share. Though I am yet to have my first official day, the process of getting to this point has been wonderful.

headline: Amazing team to be a part of. Happy to come to work everyday:)
pros:
Amazing leniency with being able to get your work done where you feel like you work best. I have never worked with a smarter group of folks. The interview process is tough, but it's for a good reason once you see the character of folks you are surrounded by. 

Perks and benefits are unparalleled, and people do not take advantage of them! 

I am beyond grateful to work at HubSpot
cons: At times, role changes can be adamant, yet that is the kind of environment HubSpot has- we are never done improving and never done growing :)

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: They walk the walk. The culture deck is clearly something that everyone in the company strives for, even if we're not perfect.
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Great people, product, customers, mission, leadership, and culture
pros:
Honestly, I love working here. Here's why:

1) Company leadership is incredible. I have never worked at a company where I had such trust in executive leadership. They are transparent with our goals and current state and it is obvious that they are all scary smart. 

2) The focus on culture is like no other company I know. HubSpot definitely cares about its employees. Google the culture code that we have if you'd like to get a glimpse.  Dharmesh is such an awesome leader with this.

3) The employees are dedicated, smart, and just a ton of fun to be with. 

4) The office (I work at the one in Cambridge) is super nice and conveniently located. There are a ton of perks too, including soda, free food, free beer, ping pong and other games, and the list goes on.

5) The product and customer work is great. It's downright fun working with a strong product. Working with customers, trying to grow their business, is very rewarding. 

Great, great place to work.
cons: I don't have complaints yet. I'll be sure to update my review when I do, though.

headline: Ambitious Without Being Aggressive
pros: HubSpot is ambitious. Seriously ambitious. It doesn't want to be merely a great company; it wants to define an era. And yet it somehow manages to convey this aspiration internally without the aggressiveness that one would think would naturally accompany it. It somehow delivers the message with a laugh and a plan.
cons: The focus on culture can be a bit self-aware at times. For example, it can be awkward to measure others (and be measured oneself) in terms of how humble the person is.

headline: Believe The Hype
pros: HubSpot really is the amazing place it seems to be from the outside.   I have been here for over 3 years now and still love it just as much (if not more) as I hoped I would.   The people here challenge and support me, there is room to make mistakes and try new things, and the work is fun and rewarding.   Yes there is a nap room, and yes there is free beer and yes there is a great new gym but those things are not enough to make me stay at a job for 3 years.  The people and the work keep me smiling everyday I walk through these doors.
cons: We are growing so fast.   We could use some more HubSpotters to help us grow and take the company to the next level.

headline: Account Executive
pros:
Fun and exciting workplace
Surrounded by really smart and talented colleagues in all departments, so your constantly learning and making great connections
Transparency - this is the most transparent company I've ever been a part of. 
Career Growth - the company is growing rapidly and there are lots of opportunities to grow your career
Support - the company is dedicated to making sure that everyone has the tools and support they need to succeed
Flexible work from home policy & vacation policy
Vision - Everyone is on board with the vision and direction of the company so everyone is working towards a common goal
cons:
Would like to see some more benefits around child care and 401k matching.
